=== [[Talk:Cold War II#rfc_CD6F6EF|Talk:Cold War II]] expired 2016-02-27 09:01 ===
* Id: CD6F6EF
* User: Sunrise
* Date: 2016-01-28 08:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|704878784|UNSORTED 704878784}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|707183219|UNSORTED 707183219}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
== January 2016 '''

I've been watching this unfold, so I made an edit to finish the reduction in article scope in keeping with the RM closure and the comments in the most recent RfC. I removed the content that focused on foreign relations (which was nearly everything except the lead), and copied it here so it can be merged elsewhere. 

{{hat}}
{{fake heading|sub=2|Geopolitical shifts after the dissolution of the Soviet Union}}
{{see also|Foreign policy of Vladimir Putin|Foreign policy of the United States|Foreign policy of Barack Obama}}
[[File:Russia-NATO.png|thumb|upright=1.82|Following the 1991 [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], several former members of the [[Warsaw Pact]] and three [[post-Soviet states]] (light green) joined [[NATO]] (green), a move that alarmed Russia (orange).<ref name=LPeter/> The other [[post-Soviet states]] (yellow) are also shown on the map.]]
Following the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]] in 1991, each of the fifteen [[Republics of the Soviet Union]] became [[Independence|independent]] states. The Russian Federation, whose territory was defined by the administrative boundaries of the defunct [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic]], emerged as the sole legal [[Succession of states|successor]] to the Soviet Union. Russia inherited the USSR's UN [[United Nations Security Council|Security Council]] [[Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council|permanent membership]] seat as well as most of its [[Strategic Missile Troops|military nuclear capacity]]. The Cold War definitively ended with the dissolution of the Soviet Union in December 1991.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2014/8/russia-ukraine-coldwarputin.html|title=US and Russia renew Cold War rivalry|date=7 August 2014 |accessdate=7 August 2014 |publisher=America Aljazeera.com/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/141537/robert-legvold/managing-the-new-cold-war|title=Managing the New Cold War|date=August 2014 |accessdate=7 August 2014 |publisher=Foreign Affairs.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news 
|url=http://time.com/3028057/in-russia-crime-without-punishment|title=In Russia, Crime Without Punishment
|date=24 July 2014 |accessdate=7 August 2014 |publisher=Time.com|first=Simon|last=Shuster/Kiev}}</ref> Relations between Russia and the West warmed further during the 1990s, as Russia moved towards [[democracy]] and the [[market economy]].<ref name=MHirsh>{{cite news|last1=Hirsh|first1=Michael|title=Ukraine and the Clash of Civilizations|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/white-house/ukraine-and-the-clash-of-civilizations-20140305|accessdate=23 December 2014|publisher=National Journal|date=5 March 2014}}</ref> [[Boris Yeltsin]] served as the first [[President of Russia]], and the West generally supported Russian President [[Boris Yeltsin]]'s successful [[Russian presidential election, 1996|1996 re-election]] over Communist leader [[Gennady Zyuganov]].<ref name=Eclipse>{{cite news|last1=Remnick|first1=David|title=Watching the Eclipse|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/08/11/watching-eclipse|accessdate=2 January 2015|publisher=The New Yorker|date=11 August 2014}}</ref> In 1999, former [[KGB]] officer [[Vladimir Putin]] became [[Prime Minister of Russia]]. Putin made the reestablishment of a strong Russian state his top priority, and crushed internal enemies such as [[Chechnya|Chechen]] rebels and dissidents.<ref name=Eclipse/>

Between 1999 and 2013, eleven countries that had been either Warsaw Pact members or part of the Soviet Union, chose to join both the [[European Union]] and NATO. Russia voiced deep concern over this [[Enlargement of NATO|NATO enlargement]] and was particularly opposed to NATO's expansion to the [[Baltic states]].<ref name=LPeter>{{cite news|last1=Peter|first1=Laurence|title=Why Nato-Russia relations soured before Ukraine|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-29030744|accessdate=19 December 2014|publisher=BBC|date=2 September 2014}}</ref> In addition to seeing the expansion of NATO as a threat, many Russian leaders also saw the expansion of NATO into Russia's former [[sphere of influence]] as an insult to Russia's status as a [[great power]].<ref name=SWard>{{cite news|last1=Ward|first1=Steven|title=How Putin’s desire to restore Russia to great power status matters|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/monkey-cage/wp/2014/03/06/how-putins-desire-to-restore-russia-to-great-power-status-matters/|accessdate=3 January 2015|publisher=Washington Post|date=6 March 2014}}</ref> Russia also voiced concern over the [[United States national missile defense]] plans, as it saw both the NATO expansion and the US missile defense program as a potential threat to Russian national security.<ref name=LPeter/> In 2012, the [[Chief of the General Staff (Russia)|Chief of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Russia]] and First Deputy [[Russian Ministry of Defence|Minister of Defence]], [[Nikolay Yegorovich Makarov|Nikolay Makarov]], said that if the United States were to deploy an anti-ballistic missile shield in [[Poland]] and [[Czech Republic]], Russia would respond by deploying [[9K720 Iskander|Iskander]] missiles in [[Kaliningrad]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/9243954/Russia-threatens-Nato-with-military-strikes-over-missile-defence-system.html |title= Russia threatens Nato with military strikes over missile defence system |work= The Telegraph |first= Bruno |last= Waterfield |date= 3 May 2012 |accessdate= 15 December 2014 |location=London}}</ref> After a four-year stint as Prime Minister of Russia, in 2012 Putin returned to the Russian presidency and continued with new vigour to advance a brand of ideology known as [[Putinism]], which promotes conservative Russian values and opposition to the West, particularly the United States.<ref name=Eclipse/>

In October 2014, Putin delivered his [[Valdai speech of Vladimir Putin|Valdai club speech]], which sharply criticized the Western powers' foreign policy and actions, especially those of the United States — who, in his opinion, "having declared itself the winner of the Cold War", had taken steps that threw the system of global and regional security as established after World War II "into sharp and deep imbalance": <blockquote>The Cold War ended, but it did not end with the signing of a peace treaty [...]. This created the impression that the so-called ‘victors’ in the Cold War had decided to pressure events and reshape the world to suit their own needs and interests. If the existing system of international relations, international law and the checks and balances in place got in the way of these aims, this system was declared worthless, outdated and in need of immediate demolition."<ref name=Vald>[http://eng.kremlin.ru/news/23137 Meeting of the Valdai International Discussion Club] October 24, 2014.</ref></blockquote>

{{fake heading|sub=2|Russia and NATO: End of cooperation and military build-up}}
{{see also|NATO–Russia relations}}
[[File:QRA Scramble to Intercept Russian Blackjack Aircraft MOD 45151233.jpg|right|upright=1.1|thumb|The [[Russian Air Force]] [[strategic bomber]] [[Tupolev Tu-160|Tu-160]], pictured being intercepted by an [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] [[Panavia Tornado ADV|Tornado F3]] (below), is to carry up to 12 new long-range [[Kh-55#Variants|Raduga Kh-101]] ([[:ru:Х-101|X-101]]) cruise missiles]]

Relations between NATO and Russia, established in 1991 within the framework of the [[North Atlantic Cooperation Council]],<ref name='natorelations'>[http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/topics_50090.htm NATO’s relations with Russia]</ref> began to appreciably deteriorate prior to 2014,<ref name=LPeter/> due to Russia's displeasure with the NATO expansion and Putin's Russia being increasingly assertive in what it refers to as its [[near abroad]]. Russia increased its military budget from $10 billion in 2005 to over $50 billion in 2015, ending the years of disinvestment that had followed the end of the Soviet Union.<ref name=ceinhorn>{{cite news|last1=Einhorn|first1=Catrin|title=Russia Rearms for a New Era|url=http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/12/24/world/asia/russia-arming.html|accessdate=24 December 2015|publisher=New York Times|date=24 December 2015}}</ref>

{{fake heading|sub=3|2014}}
On 1 April, in response to the [[2014 Ukrainian crisis|Ukraine crisis]], NATO decided to "suspend all practical civilian and military cooperation between NATO and Russia".<ref name="end coop">{{cite news |author= |title=Ukraine crisis: Nato suspends Russia co-operation |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-26838894 |newspaper=BBC News |location=UK |publisher= |date=2014-04-02 |accessdate=2014-04-02}}</ref>

In spring, the [[Ministry of Defence (Russia)|Russian Defense Ministry]] announced it was planning to deploy additional forces in Crimea, which had just been [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|annexed by Russia]], as part of beefing up its [[Black Sea Fleet]],<ref>[http://rt.com/news/157064-black-sea-fleet-deployment/ New subs, warships, SAMs, troops to be deployed in Crimea] RT, May 06, 2014.</ref><ref name="riabeefup">{{cite news |author= |title= Россия усилит Черноморский флот новыми кораблями|url=http://ria.ru/defense_safety/20140506/1006684494.html |newspaper=[[RIA Novosti]] |location=Russia |publisher= |date=2014-05-06 |accessdate=2015-12-03}}</ref> including re-deployment by 2016 of nuclear-capable Tupolev [[Tupolev Tu-22M|Tu-22M3]] ('Backfire') long-range strike bombers — which used to be the backbone of Soviet naval strike units during the Cold War, but were later withdrawn from bases in Crimea.<ref name="bbcbombers">{{cite news |author=Pavel Aksenov |title=Why would Russia deploy bombers in Crimea? |url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-33649298 |newspaper= |location=London |publisher=BBC |date=2015-07-24 |accessdate=2015-12-03}}</ref> Such moves alarmed NATO: in November NATO's top military commander US General [[Philip M. Breedlove|Philip Breedlove]] said that the alliance was "watching for indications" amid fears over the possibility that Russia could move any of its [[Russia and weapons of mass destruction#Nuclear arsenal of Russia|nuclear arsenal]] to the peninsula.<ref>[http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/nato-very-concerned-by-russian-military-build-up-in-crimea.aspx?pageID=238&nID=74852&NewsCatID=359 NATO 'very concerned' by Russian military build-up in Crimea]</ref> In December, Russian Foreign Minister [[Sergey Lavrov]] said this would be a legitimate action as "Crimea has now become part of a country that has such weapons under the [[Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons]]."<ref>[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/239978.html Crimea became part of Russia, which has nuclear weapons according to NPT – Lavrov]</ref>

At the NATO [[2014 Wales summit|Wales summit]] in early September, the NATO-Ukraine Commission adopted a Joint Statement that "strongly condemned Russia’s illegal and illegitimate self-declared "annexation" of Crimea and its continued and deliberate destabilization of eastern Ukraine in violation of international law";<ref>[http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/news_112695.htm Joint Statement of the NATO-Ukraine Commission], 4 September 2014.</ref> this position was re-affirmed in the early December statement by the same body.<ref>[http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/official_texts_115474.htm Joint statement of the NATO-Ukraine Commission], 2 December 2014.</ref>

A report released in November highlighted the fact that close military encounters between Russia and the West (mainly NATO countries) had jumped to Cold War levels, with 40 dangerous or sensitive incidents recorded in the eight months alone, including a near-collision between a Russian reconnaissance plane and a passenger plane taking off from Denmark in March with 132 passengers on board.<ref name="closeenc">{{cite news |author=Ewen MacAskill |title=Close military encounters between Russia and the west ‘at cold war levels’ |url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/nov/10/close-military-encounters-russia-west-cold-war |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |location=UK |publisher= |date=2014-11-09 |accessdate=2014-12-28}}</ref> An unprecedented increase<ref name="increase">{{cite news |author= |title=Russia Baltic military actions 'unprecedented' - Poland |url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-30429349 |newspaper=[[BBC]] |location=UK |publisher= |date=2014-12-28 |accessdate=2014-12-28}}</ref> in Russian [[Russian Air Force|air force]] and naval activity in the Baltic region prompted NATO to step up its longstanding rotation of military jets in Lithuania.<ref name="jetslith">{{cite news |author= |title=Four RAF Typhoon jets head for Lithuania deployment |url=http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-27183642 |newspaper=[[BBC]] |location=UK |publisher= |date=2014-04-28 |accessdate=2014-12-28}}</ref> Similar Russian air force increased activity in the [[Asia-Pacific|Asia-Pacific region]] that relied on the resumed use of the previously abandoned Soviet [[Cam Ranh Base|military base]] at [[Cam Ranh Bay]], [[Vietnam]].<ref name="Stopflights">{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/11/us-usa-vietnam-russia-exclusive-idUSKBN0M71NA20150311 |work=Reuters |title=U.S. asks Vietnam to stop helping Russian bomber flights |date=2015-03-11 |accessdate=2015-04-12}}</ref> In March 2015, Russia's defense minister [[Sergey Shoygu]] said that Russia's long-range bombers would continue patrolling various parts of the world and expand into other regions.<ref name="shoigu">{{cite news |author= |title=Russian Strategic Bombers To Continue Patrolling Missions |url=http://www.rferl.org/content/russian-strategic-bombers-to-continue-patrolling-missions/26877218.html |newspaper= |location= |publisher=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]] |date=2015-03-02 |accessdate=2015-03-02}}</ref>

In July, the U.S. formally accused Russia of having violated the 1987 [[Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty|Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces (INF) Treaty]] by testing a prohibited medium-range ground-launched [[cruise missile]] (presumably R-500,<ref>[http://csis.org/publication/russian-inf-treaty-violations-assessment-and-response Russian INF Treaty Violations: Assessment and Response]</ref> a modification of [[9K720 Iskander|Iskander]])<ref name="nytcruise">{{cite news |title=U.S. Says Russia Tested Cruise Missile, Violating Treaty |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/29/world/europe/us-says-russia-tested-cruise-missile-in-violation-of-treaty.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |location=USA |publisher= |date=2014-07-28 |accessdate=2015-01-04 |first=Michael R. |last=Gordon}}</ref> and threatened to retaliate accordingly.<ref name="nytcruise" /><ref name="guardcr">{{cite news |author= |title=US and Russia in danger of returning to era of nuclear rivalry |url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/04/us-russia-era-nuclear-rivalry |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |location=UK |publisher= |date=2015-01-04 |accessdate=2015-01-04}}</ref> In early June 2015, the [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] reported that Russia had failed to correct the violation of the I.N.F. Treaty; the U.S. government was said to have made no discernible headway in making Russia so much as acknowledge the compliance problem.<ref name="inffailure">{{cite news |title=U.S. Says Russia Failed to Correct Violation of Landmark 1987 Arms Control Deal |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/06/world/europe/us-says-russia-fails-to-correct-violation-of-landmark-1987-arms-control-deal.html?_r=0 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |location=US |publisher= |date=2015-06-05 |accessdate=2015-06-07 |first=Michael R. |last=Gordon}}</ref> The US government's October 2014 report claimed that Russia had 1,643 [[Nuclear weapon|nuclear warheads]] ready to launch (an increase from 1,537 in 2011) – one more than the US, thus overtaking the US for the first time since 2000; both countries' deployed capacity being in violation of the [[New START|2010 New START treaty]] that sets a cap of 1,550 nuclear warheads.<ref name="nuclear">{{cite news |author= |title=Russia’s deployed nuclear capacity overtakes US for first time since 2000 |url=http://rt.com/news/193604-russia-nuclear-capacity-start/ |newspaper=[[RT (TV network)|RT]] |location=Moscow |publisher= |date=2014-10-06 |accessdate=2014-12-28}}</ref><ref name="MTOvertake">{{cite news |author=Matthew Bodner |title=Russia Overtakes U.S. in Nuclear Warhead Deployment |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/business/article/russia-overtakes-u-s-in-nuclear-warhead-deployment-/508409.html |newspaper=[[The Moscow Times]] |location=Moscow |publisher= |date=2014-10-03 |accessdate=2014-12-28}}</ref> Likewise, even before 2014, the US had set about implementing a large-scale program, worth up to a trillion dollars, aimed at overall revitalization of its [[United States Department of Energy|atomic energy industry]], which includes plans for a new generation of weapon carriers and construction of such sites as the [[Chemistry and Metallurgy Research Replacement Facility]] in [[Los Alamos, New Mexico|Los Alamos]], [[New Mexico]] and the [[Kansas City Plant#National Security Campus|National Security Campus]] in south [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]].<ref>[http://cns.miis.edu/opapers/pdfs/140107_trillion_dollar_nuclear_triad.pdf The Trillion Dollar Nuclear Triad] [[Monterey Institute of International Studies#James Martin Center for Nonproliferation Studies (CNS)|James Martin Center for Nonproliferation Studies]]: Monterey, CA. January 2014.</ref><ref name="nyt">{{cite news |title=U.S. Ramping Up Major Renewal in Nuclear Arms |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/22/us/us-ramping-up-major-renewal-in-nuclear-arms.html?_r=0 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |location=USA |publisher= |date=2014-09-21 |accessdate=2015-01-05 |first1=William J. |last1=Broad |first2=David E. |last2=Sanger}}</ref>

At the end of 2014, Putin approved a revised [[Military doctrine of Russia|national military doctrine]], which listed NATO’s military buildup near the Russian borders as the top military threat.<ref>[http://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/articles/14758/russia-s-new-military-doctrine-hypes-nato-threat Russia’s New Military Doctrine Hypes NATO Threat]</ref><ref>[http://news.nationalpost.com/2014/12/26/putin-signs-new-military-doctrine-naming-nato-as-russias-top-military-threat/ Putin signs new military doctrine naming NATO as Russia’s top military threat] [[National Post]], December 26, 2014.</ref>

On 2 December 2014, NATO foreign ministers announced an interim [[NATO Response Force#Structure|Spearhead Force]] (the 'Very High Readiness Joint Task Force') created pursuant to the Readiness Action Plan agreed on at the NATO [[2014 Wales summit|Wales summit]] in early September 2014 and meant to enhance NATO presence in the eastern part of the alliance in response to Russia.<ref>[http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natohq/official_texts_115551.htm Statement of Foreign Ministers on the Readiness Action Plan] NATO, 02 Dec 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.neurope.eu/article/nato-condemns-russia-supports-ukraine-agrees-rapid-reaction-force NATO condemns Russia, supports Ukraine, agrees to rapid-reaction force]</ref>

{{fake heading|sub=3|2015}}
In early February 2015, NATO diplomats said that concern was growing in NATO over Russia's nuclear strategy and indications that Russia's nuclear strategy appeared to point to a lowering of the threshold for using nuclear weapons in any conflict.<ref name=threshold>{{cite news |last1= |first1= |title=Insight - Russia's nuclear strategy raises concerns in NATO |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/02/04/uk-ukraine-crisis-russia-nuclear-insight-idUKKBN0L825A20150204 |accessdate=6 February 2015 |publisher=Reuters |date=4 February 2015}}</ref> The conclusion was followed by British Defense Secretary [[Michael Fallon]] saying that Britain must update [[United Kingdom and weapons of mass destruction|its nuclear arsenal]] in response to Russian modernization of its nuclear forces.<ref name=fallon>{{cite news |last1= |first1= |title=Supplying weapons to Ukraine would escalate conflict: Fallon |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/02/06/us-ukraine-crisis-fallon-idUSKBN0LA1Q820150206 |accessdate=6 February 2015 |publisher=Reuters |date=6 February 2015 |first=Adrian |last=Croft}}</ref> Later in February, Fallon said that Putin could repeat tactics used in Ukraine in Baltic members of the NATO alliance; he also said: "NATO has to be ready for any kind of aggression from Russia, whatever form it takes. NATO is getting ready."<ref name="natoready">{{cite news |author= |title=Russia a threat to Baltic states after Ukraine conflict, warns Michael Fallon |url=http://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/feb/19/russia-a-threat-to-baltic-states-after-ukraine-conflict-warns-michael-fallon |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |location=UK |publisher= |date=2015-02-19 |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref> Fallon noted that it was not a new cold war with Russia, as the situation was already “pretty warm”.<ref name="natoready" />

In March 2015, Russia, citing NATO's ''de facto'' breach of the 1990 [[Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe]], said that the suspension of its participation in it, announced in 2007, was now "complete" through halting its participation in the consulting group on the Treaty.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mid.ru/brp_4.nsf/newsline/DF4749F53CF96B4043257E040058061A |title=Заявление руководителя Делегации Российской Федерации на переговорах в Вене по вопросам военной безопасности и контроля над вооружениями |author=А.Ю.Мазура |work= |date=10 March 2015 |publisher=RF Foreign Ministry website}}</ref><ref name="halt">{{cite news |title=Russia says halts activity in European security treaty group |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/03/10/us-russia-crisis-europe-security-idUSKBN0M61RH20150310 |newspaper= |location=UK |publisher=Reuters |date=2015-03-10 |accessdate=2015-03-31 |first=Thomas |last=Grove}}</ref>

Early April 2015 saw the publication of the leaked information ascribed to semi-official sources within the Russian military and intelligence establishment, about Russia's alleged preparedness for a nuclear response to certain inimical non-nuclear acts on the part of NATO; such implied threats were interpreted as "an attempt to create [[Strategic ambiguity|strategic uncertainty]]" and undermine Western political cohesion.<ref name=TimesMenace>{{cite news |title=From Russia with Menace |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/opinion/leaders/article4399638.ece |accessdate=2 April 2015 |publisher=The Times |date=2 April 2015}}</ref> Also in this vein, Norway’s defense minister, [[Ine Marie Eriksen Søreide|Ine Eriksen Soreide]], noted that Russia had "created uncertainty about its intentions".<ref name=NYTNorway>{{cite news |title=Norway Reverts to Cold War Mode as Russian Air Patrols Spike |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/02/world/europe/a-newly-assertive-russia-jolts-norways-air-defenses-into-action.html?_r=0 |accessdate=5 April 2015 |publisher=The New York Times |date=1 April 2015 |first=Andrew |last=Higgins}}</ref>

In June 2015, an independent Russian military analyst was quoted by a major American newspaper as saying: “Everybody should understand that we are living in a totally different world than two years ago. In that world, which we lost, it was possible to organize your security with treaties, with mutual-trust measures. Now we have come to an absolutely different situation, where the general way to ensure your security is [[Deterrence theory|military deterrence]].”<ref name=cost>[[Neil MacFarquhar|MacFarquhar, Neil]], [http://mobile.nytimes.com/2015/06/17/world/europe/putin-40-new-missiles-russian-nuclear-arsenal.html "As Vladimir Putin Talks More Missiles and Might, Cost Tells Another Story"], ''New York Times'', June 16, 2015. Retrieved 2015-06-17.</ref>

In late June 2015, while on a trip to Estonia, US Defence Secretary [[Ashton Carter]] said the U.S. would deploy heavy weapons, including tanks, armoured vehicles and artillery, in Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, and Romania.<ref name="carterdeploy">{{cite news |author= |title=US announces new tank and artillery deployment in Europe |url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-33238004 |newspaper= |location=UK |publisher=BBC |date=2015-06-23 |accessdate=2015-06-24}}</ref> The move was interpreted by Western commentators as marking the beginning of a reorientation of NATO′s strategy.<ref name="ftreorient">{{cite news |author= |title=NATO shifts strategy in Europe to deal with Russia threat |url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/dd3604bc-19a8-11e5-8201-cbdb03d71480.html#axzz3e0cPGWLr |newspaper= |location=UK |publisher=FT |date=2015-06-23 |accessdate=2015-06-24}}</ref> It was called by a senior Russian Defence Ministry official ″the most aggressive act by Washington since the Cold War″<ref name=Reuterbeefup>{{cite news |title=Putin says Russia beefing up nuclear arsenal, NATO denounces 'saber-rattling' |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/06/16/us-russia-nuclear-putin-idUSKBN0OW17X20150616 |accessdate=27 June 2015 |publisher=Reuters |date=16 June 2015}}</ref> and criticised by the Russian Foreign Ministry as "inadequate in military terms" and "an obvious return by the United States and its allies to the schemes of ‘the Cold War’".<ref>[http://www.mid.ru/brp_4.nsf/newsline/E5ADC981E95C68DC43257E70006784BD Комментарий Департамента информации и печати МИД России по итогам встречи министров обороны стран-членов НАТО] the RF Foreign Ministry, 26 June 2015.</ref><ref name=RTMid>{{cite news |title=Russia says NATO build-up on its borders is to achieve ‘dominance in Europe’ |url=http://rt.com/news/270073-nato-russia-dominance-troops/ |accessdate=27 June 2015 |publisher=RT |date=27 June 2015}}</ref> On its part, the U.S. expressed concern over Putin's announcement of plans to add over 40 new ballistic missiles to Russia′s nuclear weapons arsenal in 2015.<ref name="Reuterbeefup" /> American observers and analysts, such as [[Steven Pifer]], noting that the U.S. had no reason for alarm about the new missiles, provided that Russia remained within the limits of the 2010 New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty ([[New START]]),  viewed the ratcheting-up of nuclear saber-rattling by Russia′s leadership as mainly bluff and bluster designed to conceal Russia′s weaknesses;<ref name=nytchicken>[[Steven Pifer]], Fiona Hill. [http://www.nytimes.com/2015/06/16/opinion/putins-risky-game-of-chicken.html "Putin’s Risky Game of Chicken"], ''New York Times'', June 15, 2015. Retrieved 2015-06-18.</ref> however, Pifer suggested that the most alarming motivation behind this rhetoric could be Putin seeing nuclear weapons not merely as tools of deterrence, but as tools of coercion.<ref>Steven Pifer. [http://www.brookings.edu/blogs/order-from-chaos/posts/2015/06/17-putin-nuclear-saber-rattling-pifer Putin’s nuclear saber-rattling: What is he compensating for?] 17 June 2015.</ref> Meanwhile, at the end of June 2015, it was reported that the production schedule for a new Russian [[Multiple independently targetable reentry vehicle|MIRV]]-equipped, [[Heavy ICBM|super-heavy]] [[Thermonuclear weapon|thermonuclear]] [[intercontinental ballistic missile]] ''[[Sarmat]]'', intended to replace the obsolete Soviet-era [[R-36 (missile)#SS-18|SS-18 ''Satan'']] missiles, was slipping.<ref name=slipping>{{cite news |title=Russian Program to Build World's Biggest Intercontinental Missile Delayed |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/business/article/russian-program-to-build-world-s-biggest-intercontinental-missile-delayed/524511.html |accessdate=27 June 2015 |publisher=The Moscow Times |date=26 June 2015}}</ref> Also noted by commentators were the inevitable financial and technological constraints that would hamper any real arms race with the West, if such course were to be embarked on by Russia.<ref name="cost" />

NATO-Russia tensions rose further after, on 24 November 2015, Turkey  [[2015 Russian Sukhoi Su-24 shootdown|shot down a Russian warplane]] that allegedly violated Turkish airspace and crashed in northwestern Syria.<ref name="natoturkey">{{cite web|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/25/world/europe/turkey-syria-russia-military-plane.html?_r=0|title=NATO-Russia Tensions Rise After Turkey Downs Jet |author=|work=The New York Times|date=24 November 2015|accessdate=29 November 2015}}</ref>

On 2 December 2015, NATO member states formally invited [[Montenegro]] to join the alliance, which drew a response from Russia that it would suspend cooperation with that country.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2015/12/02/world/europe/ap-eu-nato-montenegro.html?_r=0 |title=ATO Invites Montenegro to Join, as Russia Plots Response |author= |newspaper=The New York Times |date=2 December 2015 |accessdate=2 December 2015}}</ref>

At the end of 2015, a Swedish military analyst speaking of large-scale military exercises that Russia had been frequently conducting said, “The image that Russian official sources convey is that they’re preparing for large-scale interstate war. This is not about peacekeeping or counterinsurgency.”<ref name="ceinhorn" />

{{fake heading|sub=2|Russia–West confrontation over Ukraine}}
{{see also|Ukraine–NATO relations|Ukraine–European Union relations}}

{{fake heading|sub=3|Russia–Ukraine relations}}
{{main|Russia–Ukraine relations}}

In the aftermath of the Soviet Union's demise, Ukraine and the Russian Federation experienced [[1992–94 Crimean crisis|tensions]] regarding the [[Political status of Crimea|status of Crimea]], which had been [[1954 transfer of Crimea|transferred]] by the central government of the USSR from Russia to Ukraine in 1954, and issues related to the status of the [[Black Sea Fleet]]. The 1994 [[Budapest Memorandum on Security Assurances|Budapest Memorandum]] re-affirmed Ukraine′s sovereignty over the entire territory of the demised [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic]], as Ukraine gave up its [[Nuclear weapons and Ukraine|nuclear stockpile]] in return for assurances from Russia, the USA, and the UK that Ukraine's security and integrity would be upheld. The bickering between the two countries over the ex-Soviet Black Sea Fleet was settled by the 1997 [[Partition Treaty on the Status and Conditions of the Black Sea Fleet]]. In 2004 [[Viktor Yanukovych]] was elected president of Ukraine, but accusations of fraud led to a series of protests known as the [[Orange Revolution]]. The Orange Revolution increased tensions between Putin and Western countries, as Putin saw the Orange Revolution as a product of Western machinations and a foreshadowing of an assault on his regime.<ref name=Eclipse/> The [[Supreme Court of Ukraine]] ordered a re-run of the second ballot and the new election was won by [[Viktor Yuschenko]]. Yuschenko pursued the policy of [[European integration]] and aspired to NATO membership, but NATO chose not to offer membership to Ukraine, as many Western leaders sought to avoid inflaming tensions with Russia.<ref name=ATaylor>{{cite news|last1=Taylor|first1=Adam|title=That time Ukraine tried to join NATO — and NATO said no|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/09/04/that-time-ukraine-tried-to-join-nato-and-nato-said-no/|accessdate=26 December 2014|publisher=Washington Post|date=4 September 2014}}</ref> Yanukovych won the [[Ukrainian presidential election, 2010|2010 Ukrainian presidential election]], and announced a new policy of [[Country neutrality (international relations)|non-alignment]].<ref name=ATaylor/> Ukraine continued to maintain ties with both Russia and the [[European Union]].<ref name=OTUEUAA>[http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28038725 Guide to the EU deals with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine], [[BBC News]] (30 June 2014)</ref> The Yanukovych government negotiated the [[Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement]]. However, Yanukovych, under pressure from Russia, refused to sign the agreement.<ref name=ITraynor>{{cite news|last1=Traynor|first1=Ian|title=Ukraine aligns with Moscow as EU summit fails|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/29/ukraine-yanukovych-moscow-eu-summit|accessdate=2 January 2015|publisher=The Guardian|date=28 November 2013}}</ref> Yanukovych's decision sparked the [[Euromaidan]] protests.

<div class="thumb tnone" style="clear:both"> <div class="thumbinner"> <div class="overflowbugx" style="overflow: auto; direction:rtl"> [[File:Soviet and Russian Black Sea Fleet.jpg|frameless|upright=5]] </div> <div class="thumbcaption"> <div class="magnify">[[:File:Soviet and Russian Black Sea Fleet.jpg]]</div> Warships of the Russian Black Sea Fleet (including the flagship ''[[Russian cruiser Moskva|Moskva]]''), based in Sebastopol since 1983</div></div></div>

{{fake heading|sub=3|2014–15 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine}}
{{see also|2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine}}
[[File:2014-05-09. День Победы в Донецке 237.jpg|thumb|upright=1.1|right|Pro-Russian protests in the city of [[Donetsk]], controlled by the [[Donetsk People's Republic]], 9 May 2014]]
In the wake of the Euromaiden protests, in February 2014, Ukrainian president [[Viktor Yanukovych]] was ousted.<ref name=MErastavi>{{cite news|last1=Erastavi|first1=Maxim|title=How Ukraine’s Parliament Brought Down Yanukovych|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/03/02/how-ukraine-s-parliament-brought-down-yanukovych.html|accessdate=2 January 2015|publisher=The Daily Beast|date=2 March 2014}}</ref> Following Yanukovych's removal pro-Western businessman [[Petro Poroshenko]] was elected President of Ukraine. In June 2014, Poroshenko signed the [[Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement]], which his predecessor, Yanukovych, had rejected in 2013. The Euromaidan and Yanukovych's removal from power led to [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine]] starting in February 2014. Following this unrest, Russia conducted a [[2014–16 Russian military intervention in Ukraine|covert invasion]] of parts of Ukraine, sparking an [[2014 Crimean crisis|international crisis]]. In March 2014, the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]] held the [[Crimean status referendum, 2014|referendum]], thereby declaring its [[secession]] from Ukraine, and shortly thereafter signed a treaty to [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation|join]] the Russian Federation. The annexation was [[Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation#International response|not recognized]] by the overwhelming majority of the world community and provoked the imposition on 17 March 2014 of the [[International sanctions during the 2013–15 Ukrainian crisis#First round of sanctions|first round of sanctions]] against Russia by Canada, the United States, and the European Union.

The term "Cold War II" gained currency and relevance as tensions between Russia and the West escalated throughout the [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine]] followed by the [[2014–16 Russian military intervention in Ukraine|Russian military intervention]] and especially the downing of [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 17]] in July 2014. By August 2014, both sides had implemented economic, financial, and diplomatic sanctions upon each other: virtually all Western countries, led by the US and EU, imposed [[International sanctions during the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|restrictive measures]] on Russia; the latter reciprocally introduced retaliatory [[International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis#Sanctions by Russia|measures]]. Besides, Russia was barred from a slimmed-down June 2014 [[40th G7 summit|G7 summit]] in Brussels that had been planned as a [[G8]] summit to be held in Russia.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/03/24/politics/obama-europe-trip/|title=U.S. and other powers kick Russia out of G8|date=25 March 2014 |accessdate=7 August 2014 |publisher=CNN.com}}</ref><ref>Johanna Granville, [https://www.academia.edu/7011881/Playing_Poker_with_Putin "The Folly of Playing High-Stakes Poker with Putin: More to Lose than Gain over Ukraine"], May 8, 2014.</ref> Also, the Australian government explored the [[2014 G20 Brisbane summit#Issues involving Russia|option of disinviting]] Putin to the November 2014  [[2014 G20 Brisbane summit|G20 summit]] in [[Brisbane]], to which Putin was eventually invited and did go but was reported to be frozen out or outright rebuked by some other leaders.<ref name=shirtfront>{{cite web |url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/nov/15/g20-canadian-prime-minister-shirtfronts-vladimir-putin-instead|title=G20: Canadian prime minister shirtfronts Vladimir Putin instead|date=15 November 2014 |accessdate=8 January 2015 |publisher=The Guardian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/insidestory/2014/11/g20-summit-putin-being-frozen-out-20141115172716683941.html|title= G20 summit: Is Putin being frozen out? Russian president given a frosty reception in Brisbane over his Cold War-style stand-off with the West|date=15 November 2014 |accessdate=8 January 2015 |publisher=Aljazeera}}</ref> On the eve of the summit, the host, [[Tony Abbott]], accused Putin of "bullying" Ukraine and trying to "recreate the lost glories of [[Tsarist autocracy|Tsarism]] and the Soviet Union";<ref name=apec>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-11-14/tony-abbott-details-apec-conversation-with-vladimir-putin/5891748|title=Tony Abbott told Vladimir Putin to stop trying to 'recreate lost glories' during APEC 'shirtfront' meeting |date=14 November 2014 |accessdate=8 January 2015 |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]}}</ref><ref name=FTharsh>{{cite web |url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/9afafee8-6bae-11e4-9337-00144feabdc0.html#axzz3OF6GDXm0|title=Embattled Putin arrives at G20 with navy in tow|date=14 November 2014 |accessdate=8 January 2015 |publisher=The Financial Times}}</ref> meanwhile, Putin was reported to have "ordered a Russian military flotilla of four ships to sail to the Queensland coast, adding to the surreal Cold War atmosphere".<ref name="FTharsh" />

[[File:Sanctions 2014 Russia2.png|right|thumb|upright=1.1|right|Several countries (green), many of which are [[NATO members]], introduced [[International sanctions during the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|sanctions]] on Russia (blue) following the [[2014–16 Russian military intervention in Ukraine]]]]
In August 2014, the [[Russian News Agency "TASS"|ITAR-TASS]] news agency cited the senior Russian law-maker [[Aleksey Pushkov]] as saying that Russia’s relations with the United States had become worse than in the 1970s and had no prospects for improvement.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.itar-tass.com/russia/743789|title=No prospects for Russia-US relations in near future — lawmaker|date=6 August 2014 |accessdate=7 August 2014 |publisher=ITAR-TASS News Agency}}</ref> Ukrainian President Poroshenko raised the possibility of holding a referendum on joining NATO.<ref name=MMac>{{cite news|last1=Mackinnon|first1=Mark|title=The new Cold War: Pro-Russian influence extends beyond Ukraine|url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/the-new-cold-war-pro-russian-influence-extends-beyond-ukraine/article21840836/|accessdate=21 December 2014|publisher=The Globe and Mail|date=1 December 2014|location=Toronto}}</ref>

In December 2014, Ukraine renounced its policy of [[Country neutrality (international relations)|non-alignment]], provoking harsh reactions from Russian leaders, who strongly oppose Ukraine's potential membership in [[NATO]].<ref name=Dzaks>{{cite news|last1=Zaks|first1=Dmitry|title=Outraging Russia, Ukraine takes big step toward NATO|url=http://news.yahoo.com/ukraine-parliament-takes-historic-step-toward-nato-102848451.html|accessdate=26 December 2014|publisher=Yahoo|date=23 December 2014}}</ref>

{{fake heading|sub=2|Efforts to undermine EU unity}}
The Russian leadership under Putin sees the fracturing of the political unity within the EU and especially the political unity between the EU and the U.S. as among its main strategic goals,<ref name=economistwar>{{cite news|title=Putin’s war on the West|url=http://www.economist.com/news/leaders/21643189-ukraine-suffers-it-time-recognise-gravity-russian-threatand-counter?fsrc=nlw |accessdate=30 April 2015|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|date=14 February 2015}}</ref><ref name=economisthot>{{cite news|title=From cold war to hot war|url=http://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21643220-russias-aggression-ukraine-part-broader-and-more-dangerous-confrontation |accessdate=30 April 2015|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|date=14 February 2015}}</ref> one of the means in achieving this goal being rendering support to Europe's far-right and hard [[Eurosceptic]] political parties.<ref name=economistpocket>{{cite news|title=In the Kremlin’s pocket|url=http://www.economist.com/news/briefing/21643222-who-backs-putin-and-why-kremlins-pocket |accessdate=30 April 2015|newspaper=[[The Economist]]|date=14 February 2015}}</ref><ref name=mostimes>{{cite news|last1=|first1=|last2=|first2=|title=Far-Right Europe Has a Crush on Moscow|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/far-right-europe-has-a-crush-on-moscow/511827.html|accessdate=6 January 2015|newspaper=[[The Moscow Times]]|date=25 November 2014}}</ref> Russia seeks to gain dominant influence in former Eastern Bloc states that are culturally and historically close to it, corrode and undermine Western institutions and values, manipulate public opinion and policy-making throughout Europe.<ref name=economistwar/>

In January 2016, senior UK government officials were reported to have registered their growing fears that "a new cold war" was now unfolding in Europe, with Russian meddling taking on a breadth, range and depth greater than previously thought: "It really is a new Cold War out there. Right across the EU we are seeing alarming evidence of Russian efforts to unpick the fabric of European unity on a whole range of vital strategic issues.”<ref name=clandestfunding>{{cite news|title=Russia accused of clandestine funding of European parties as US conducts major review of Vladimir Putin's strategy / Exclusive: UK warns of "new Cold War" as Kremlin seeks to divide and rule in Europe |url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/russia/12103602/America-to-investigate-Russian-meddling-in-EU.html|accessdate=17 January 2016|newspaper=The Daily Telegraph|date=16 January 2016}}</ref> The situation prompted the US Congress to instruct [[James R. Clapper|James Clapper]], the U.S. [[Director of National Intelligence]], to conduct a major review of Russian clandestine funding of European parties over the last decade.<ref name="clandestfunding" />

{{fake heading|sub=2|Tensions and proxy conflicts in other regions}}
{{See also|Russia's role in the Syrian Civil War|Russian military intervention in the Syrian Civil War}}
Apart from tensions in Europe, Russia and the West have also competed for influence in other regions, including the [[Greater Middle East]] and [[Central Asia]]. In opposition to the United States, the Russian Federation is a [[Foreign involvement in the Syrian Civil War|major supporter]] of [[Bashar al-Assad]] in the [[Syrian Civil War]].<ref name="STisdall">{{cite news |last1=Tisdall |first1=Simon |title=The new cold war: are we going back to the bad old days? |url= http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/nov/19/new-cold-war-back-to-bad-old-days-russia-west-putin-ukraine |accessdate=22 December 2014 |publisher=The Guardian |date=19 November 2014}}</ref> Russia strongly opposed Western actions in both [[Libya]] and [[Iraq]].<ref name="RLevgold">{{cite news |last=Levgold |first=Robert |title=Managing the New Cold War |publisher=Foreign Affairs |date=July–August 2014 |url=http://www.foreignaffairs.com/articles/141537/robert-legvold/managing-the-new-cold-war |accessdate=21 December 2014}}</ref> The West and Russia (as well as [[China]]) have competed for influence in the five [[post-Soviet states|post-Soviet]] [[Central Asia]]n states in what has been called "[[The Great Game#Between the end of the Cold War and 2001|the New Great Game]]."<ref name="ARash">{{cite web |last1=Rashid |first1=Ahmed |title=Why, and What, You Should Know About Central Asia |publisher=The New York Review of Books |date=15 August 2013 |url= http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/2013/aug/15/why-and-what-you-should-know-about-central-asia/ |accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="Going">{{cite news |title=Going, going… |url= http://www.economist.com/news/asia/21591242-america-winding-down-its-presence-claims-it-wont-fade-away-going-going |accessdate=21 December 2014 |publisher=The Economist |date=7 December 2013}}</ref><ref name="Nwac">{{cite news |title=Nations without a cause |url=http://www.economist.com/node/14492398 |accessdate=23 December 2014 |publisher=The Economist |date=24 September 2009}}</ref> However, both Russia and the West have publicly supported efforts to fight [[Islamic terrorism|Islamic militants]] in [[Central Asia]].<ref name="DDyomkin">{{cite news |last1=Dyomkin |first1=Dennis |title=Uzbek president asks Putin to help fight radical Islam in Central Asia |publisher=Reuters |date=10 December 2014 |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/10/us-uzbekistan-russia-islamists-idUSKBN0JO1TW20141210 |accessdate=23 December 2014}}</ref> Russia has also attempted to project its military and economic influence into [[Latin America]], an area with which the US has close economic and [[Organization of American States|political ties]].<ref name="KWong">{{cite news |last=Wong |first=Kristina |title=Putin’s quiet Latin America play |publisher=The Hill |date=21 March 2014 |url=http://thehill.com/policy/defense/201305-putins-quiet-play-for-latin-america |accessdate=25 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="DTren">{{cite news |last=Trenin |first=Dmitri |title=Putin's Latin America trip aims to show Russia is more than just regional power |publisher=The Guardian |date=15 July 2014 |url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/15/putin-latin-america-russia-power |accessdate=25 December 2014}}</ref> Russia and NATO countries have also [[Territorial claims in the Arctic|laid claim]] to territory in the [[Arctic]].<ref name="MK">{{cite news |last=Koren |first=Marina |title=Is Vladimir Putin Coming for the North Pole Next? |publisher=National Journal |date=27 March 2014 |url= http://www.nationaljournal.com/politics/is-vladimir-putin-coming-for-the-north-pole-next-20140327 |accessdate=21 January 2015}}</ref> Norway has urged NATO to be prepared for potential tensions in the region.<ref name="ARosen">{{cite news |last=Rosen |first=Armin |title=Norway Wants NATO To Prepare For An Arctic Showdown |publisher=Business Insider |date=25 June 2014 |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/norway-wants-nato-to-prepare-for-an-arctic-showdown-2014-6 |accessdate=21 January 2015}}</ref> [[North American Aerospace Defense Command|NORAD]] fighters have been scrambled to respond to Russian aircraft near Canadian airspace in the Arctic.<ref name="norad">{{cite news |title=Canadian jets intercepted Russian planes over Arctic |url= http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2014/09/19/canadian_jets_intercepted_russian_planes_over_arctic.html |accessdate=21 January 2015 |publisher=The Star |date=19 September 2014 |location=Toronto}}</ref>

While widely seen by experts both in Russia and in the West as a bid to end Russia′s political isolation imposed by the West in connection with the [[2014–16 Russian military intervention in Ukraine|situation in Ukraine]],<ref>{{cite news |title=View from Moscow: Syria Move Aimed at Ending International Isolation |work=Voice Of America |date=29 September 2015 |url= http://www.voanews.com/content/view-from-moscow-syria-move-aimed-at-ending-international-isolation/2984629.html |accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=An odd way to make friends |work=[[The Economist]] |date=10 October 2015 |url= http://www.economist.com/news/europe/21672295-intervention-syria-was-supposed-rebuild-relations-west-unsurprisingly-it-not |accessdate=13 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Putin Sees Path to Diplomacy Through Syria |newspaper=The New York Times |date=16 September 2015 |url= http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/17/world/putin-sees-syria-as-russias-path-back-into-good-graces-of-west.html?_r=0 |accessdate=17 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Putin Bids to End Russian Isolation With Syria Message to UN |publisher=Bloomberg |date=28 September 2015 |url= http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-09-27/putin-bids-to-end-diplomatic-isolation-with-syria-message-to-un |accessdate=17 October 2015}}</ref> Russia′s [[Russian military intervention in the Syrian Civil War|escalation of its efforts]] in September 2015 to prop up the Assad regime in Syria in the course of the ongoing civil war, on the one hand, and plentiful supply of arms to the rebels by the U.S. on the other hand, resulted in a situation that was judged by ''[[The New York Times]]'' in mid-October 2015 as turning into an all-out [[proxy war]] between the U.S. and Russia.<ref name="larger">{{cite news |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/13/world/middleeast/syria-russia-airstrikes.html?_r=0 |title=U.S. Weaponry Is Turning Syria Into Proxy War With Russia |author= |work=The New York Times |accessdate=14 October 2015 |date=12 October 2015}}</ref> Yet, others, including U.S. senator [[John McCain]], believed it was a proxy war already.<ref name="prox">{{cite news |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/10/13/middleeast/syria-civil-war/index.html |title=U.S., Russia escalate involvement in Syria |author= |work=CNN |accessdate=17 October 2015 |date=13 October 2015}}</ref><ref name="cain">{{cite news |author= |url= http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/oct/04/john-mccain-russia-us-proxy-war-syria-obama-putin |title=John McCain says US is engaged in proxy war with Russia in Syria |work=The Guardian |accessdate=17 October 2015 |date=4 October 2015}}</ref> [[Jeremy Shapiro]], a senior fellow in the [[Brookings Institution]], believed the unfolding situation in and around Syria was "a very, very familiar proxy war cycle from the bad old days of the Cold War".<ref name="stupid">{{cite news |last= |first= |title="The Russians have made a serious mistake": how Putin's Syria gambit will backfire |publisher=The VOA |date=1 October 2015 |url=http://www.vox.com/2015/10/1/9434365/putin-syria-russia-mistake |access-date=17 October 2015}}</ref>

{{fake heading|sub=2|Buildup of espionage efforts}}
{{see also|United States Intelligence Community|Russian Intelligence Community|Mike Hancock (British politician)#Russian aide's arrest, espionage allegation and extra-marital affair|Illegals Program}}
Russian espionage activities in the West under Putin had been reported to have reached the height of the Cold War levels years before the Ukraine crisis, according to official sources.<ref name=heightColdW>{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Russian spies 'at Cold War level'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk/6452519.stm|accessdate=3 January 2014|publisher=BBC|date=15 March 2007}}</ref><ref name=USlevels>{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Spying at Cold War Levels, U.S. Says|url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/sitemap/free/2007/3/article/spying-at-cold-war-levels-us-says/198054.html|accessdate=3 January 2014|publisher=The Moscow Times|date=30 March 2007}}</ref><ref name=UKlevel>{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Russian spies in UK 'at cold war levels', says MI5|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/29/russian-spies-cold-war-levels|accessdate=3 January 2014|publisher=The Guardian|date=29 June 2010}}</ref> The US and its major allies had been building up their intelligence-gathering capabilities since the [[September 11 attacks|attacks on 11 September 2001]], with the [[United States intelligence budget|US intelligence budget]] having since doubled by 2013.<ref name=guardbudg>{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=US intelligence spending has doubled since 9/11, top secret budget reveals|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/29/us-intelligence-spending-double-9-11-secret-budget|accessdate=5 January 2014|publisher=The Guardian|date=29 August 2014}}</ref>

[[Security Information Service|Czech Republic's secret service]] reported that an unusually high number of Russian spies, registered officially as tourists, experts, businessmen or academics, visited the Russian embassy in Prague from 2013 onward.<ref>http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/10/27/us-czech-russia-espionage-idUSKBN0IG17B20141027</ref>

The investigation report published by ''[[Newsweek]]'' in December 2014 found that Russian spying activity in Europe had returned to levels not seen since the Cold War; moreover, the investigation claimed that Russia had reintroduced the Soviet intelligence practice of so-called ‘influence operations’, whereby both Westerners and Russians resident outside Russia would be doing Moscow’s bidding.<ref name=Newsweekinv>{{cite news|last1=Braw|first1=Elisabeth|title=Russian Spies Return to Europe in 'New Cold War'|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2014/12/19/spies-are-back-espionage-booming-new-cold-war-290686.html|accessdate=3 January 2014|publisher=Newsweek|date=10 December 2014}}</ref>

In January 2015, the former [[Director of Central Intelligence|CIA Director]] [[R. James Woolsey, Jr.|James Woolsey]] said that employing the so-called "illegals", [[Non-official cover|non-official spies]] posing as US citizens while being [[Citizenship of Russia|Russian nationals]], remained a favorite tactic of the Russian [[Foreign Intelligence Service (Russia)|Foreign Intelligence Service]] to obtain trade and financial secrets in the US, especially about the energy sector.<ref name=americans>{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=Former CIA Spies Call 'The Americans' More Exciting Than Reality|url=http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/01/29/former-cia-spies-call-the-americans-more-exciting-than-reality|accessdate=20 February 2015|publisher=[[U.S. News & World Report]]|date=29 January 2015}}</ref>

In April 2015, the allegedly Russian government-sponsored cyber-hacking and espionage aimed against the US government computer systems, was reported to have increased significantly.<ref name=hacking>{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=How the U.S. thinks Russians hacked the White House|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/04/07/politics/how-russians-hacked-the-wh/index.html|accessdate=12 April 2015|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=8 April 2015}}</ref>

{{fake heading|sub=2|Trade and economy}}
{{see also|Russia–European Union relations|Energy policy of Russia}}
[[File:BRICS heads of state and government hold hands ahead of the 2014 G-20 summit in Brisbane, Australia (Agencia Brasil).jpg|thumb|upright=1.15|Tension was laid bare between the leaders of the [[BRICS]] (pictured above) and Western states at the [[2014 G20 Brisbane summit|G20 Brisbane summit]] (15–16 November 2014), as the former made it public they considered Western sanctions against Russia over [[2014–16 Russian military intervention in Ukraine|Ukraine]] a violation of [[international law]].<ref name=shirtfront/><ref name=apec/><ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sponsored/rbth/politics/11263625/g20-summit-brics-challenge-g7.html G20 summit: Brics build momentum to challenge G7] ′′The Telegraph′′, 30 Nov 2014.</ref>]]

Like many other countries, Russia's [[Great Recession in Russia|economy suffered]] during the [[Great Recession]]. Following the [[2014 Crimean crisis|Crimean Crisis]], several countries (including most of NATO) imposed [[International sanctions during the 2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|sanctions]] on Russia, hurting the Russian economy by cutting off access to capital.<ref name=JStewart/> <ref name=clamor>{{cite news|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/russian-companies-clamor-for-dollars-to-repay-debt-1412860551|title=Russian Companies Clamor for Dollars to Repay Debt|author=Chiara Albanese and Ben Edwards|date=9 October 2014|accessdate=16 December 2014|work=Wall Street Journal}}</ref> At the same time, the global [[price of oil]] declined.<ref name=FChang>{{cite news|last1=Chung|first1=Frank|title=The Cold War is back, and colder|url=http://www.news.com.au/finance/economy/the-cold-war-is-back-and-colder/story-e6frflo9-1227159436375|accessdate=17 December 2014|publisher=News.au|date=18 December 2014}}</ref> The combination of Western sanctions and the falling crude price in 2014 and thereafter, which was viewed by the western outlet ''[[Russia Insider]]'' as a US–Saudi plot against it,<ref>[http://russia-insider.com/en/business_opinion/2014/11/21/01-58-31am/oil_price_drop_us_saudi_plot_against_iran_and_russia Oil Plunge Part of US Campaign to Destabilize Russia]</ref> resulted in the ongoing [[2014–15 Russian financial crisis]].<ref name=FChang/> As a way to get around Western sanctions, Russia and China  signed a 150 billion yuan [[central bank liquidity swap]] line agreement to get around American sanctions.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://sg.news.yahoo.com/china-russia-seek-international-justice-agree-currency-swap-185306361.html |title=China, Russia seek 'international justice', agree currency swap line |last1=Smolchenko |first1=Anna |date=13 October 2014 |website=news.yahoo.com |publisher=AFP News |accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref> and agreed to a [[US$]]400 billion deal which would supply natural gas to China over the next 30 years.

One particular editor has put an enormous amount of work into this article and it is both informative and highly referenced. He/she has accepted it is not neutral POV and is doing further work on this. However, I do have concerns that the way the source material has been assembled appears to be taking a moral/ethical stance on the inequality/unfairness of the current state of the UK housing situation and is presenting a case for change. === [[Wikipedia talk:Prices#rfc_E28C1B5|Wikipedia talk:Prices]] expired 2016-02-29 14:01 ===
* Id: E28C1B5
* User: CtrlXctrlV
* Date: 2016-01-30 12:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|702422175|ECON 702422175}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|702422176|SCI 702422176}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|702422180|POLICY 702422180}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|707547792|ECON 707547792}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|707547795|SCI 707547795}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|707547797|POLICY 707547797}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hello, it is as a consequence of a derailed discussion on a talk page [[Talk:Mitsubishi Magna|this one]], that I commence this one here. In a nutshell (I hope):
* WP:NOPRICES or WP:PRICES is clearly neither definitive nor compulsory, in omitting price information from articles
* the present case arises because, in an Australian car article ([[Mitsubishi Magna]]), for some 1.5 years, [[recommended retail price]]s have been included without any opposition by any of the regular editors 
* opposition has been (improperly?) raised of late by a regular editor (OSX) only in retaliation for a separate discussion not going his way (which involved both me and him)
* in 2014, a discussion went against the inclusion of prices, with reasons including: (i) a lack of reference; (ii) price flactuations over time; (iii) the potential for car dealers to spam; (iv) the potential misuse of the article as a sales catalogue (note: the originating RfC has also been compromised by an offensive participant to the 2014 discussion, Mr.choppers, claiming that it was all done and dusted 2 years ago)
* to address, or in answer to, the above valid points: (i) full reliable external references have been found and included, from Australian car magazines; (ii) the prices included, for each series of the car over a period of 10 years, have strictly been only those listed at the time of launch of each car thus eliminating the issue of price flactuations; (iii) the car has out of production for over 10 years; (iv) by being only prices at launch, it ensures that "special" or "discounted" prices are not included... and a car is not an insignificant household good, which renders its price a key factor for consumers
* the launch prices have been included in such a manner that they do not render the article illegible (prices are included in brackets, against each model variant, where these are listed)
* other car articles (and I am aware this is not a basis for inclusion) also contain prices, without reason or context, let alone full references unlike the above case
* in the above case, prices were a determinative factor of the car's success (in terms of competition and winning Car of the Year awards) and failure against other Australian-made cars
* in the manner in which prices have been included, it is possible (for those who may choose to do so), to carry out trend analysis of new car prices in Australia, which, in the case of this car, spans a period of 20 years (such analysis may seem trivial and I do not profess the following being a determinative crucial point, however, come 2017, no more Australian cars will be manufactured, so prices have the potential of being an important historical fact in future relative to imports)
** ''AN ALTERNATIVE'': could the fully referenced prices perhaps instead exist in a table, which lists all series, models and variants of this car, if it is a case of readibility?
All in all, is opposition to the inclusion of prices in the above case, proper? Does the non-descriptive and non-compulsory WP:PRICES really give basis to delete this carefully searched and referenced information? As mentioned, I am forcedly resorting to starting this discussion here, because of the derailed RfC on the relevant Talk Page (and other retaliatory actions against me, including being subject of a sockpuppet investigation, which I have no qualms highlighting, unlike the opposing editor's practice of oppressing and/or contorting facts—as I have complained about in the sockpuppet report—and deleting warnings from his Talk Page).<br>
'''Above all''', I raise this discussion here with a view to encourage/seek more more definitive and/or prescriptive guidance on this WP... it isn't helpful that it is so inconclusive, causing the above type of arguments to arise.<br>
I am '''not''' requesting or suggesting that this Policy be varied to allow prices for ''all'' consumer goods, but a car is typically a major purchase for most people, with price being a key factor in consumer choice. I argue for price inclusion, only if fully referenced and as it applied at a specific point in time (the most practical, if not logical, being the time of launch of the car or last listed price). [[User:CtrlXctrlV|CtrlXctrlV]] ([[User talk:CtrlXctrlV|talk]]) 12:17, 30 January 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Development of Grand Theft Auto V#rfc_046FDD1|Talk:Development of Grand Theft Auto V]] expired 2016-03-01 01:01 ===
* Id: 046FDD1
* Date: 2016-01-30 23:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|702503931|UNSORTED 702503931}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|707648933|UNSORTED 707648933}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 How should the second paragraph of the overview section begin [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:Mainline421/sandbox#Overview in this draft] begin? Disagreement has arisen over how this paragraph should begin, this mainly stems from whether or not Grand Theft Auto V was developed in parallel for [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 3]] and [[Xbox 360]] as it is argued is confirmed by these articles: [http://www.pcgamer.com/gta-5-bug-log-lists-pc-version-and-directx-11-effects/ GTA 5 bug log lists PC version and DirectX 11 effects], [http://www.pcgamer.com/rockstar-talk-4k-pc-performance-and-more/ Rockstar talk 4K, PC performance and more], and [http://www.gamesradar.com/gta-5-pc-why-evidence-too-strong-ignore/ GTA 5 on PC - why the evidence is too strong to ignore] however, it is also argued that this quote from the second article contradicts this:
{{Talkquote|"While we started development of the PC version quite early, we decided to focus the bulk of our attention on the PS3 and XB360 versions first in order to push that as far as we possibly could before turning our attention to the PS4 and Xbox One versions, and then using the shared architecture underpinning the new consoles to help ourselves ramp up into the PC version and push the game as far as we possibly could knowing we would have the opportunity to make the game look and feel better than it ever has."}}
while it has also been said that this merely a matter of interpretation and that this does not contradict the other sources. The reliance of a leaked bug log for the claims that development was in parallel have been criticized as well, this been contended with the fact that the bug log is present on the PlayStation 3 disk, and it has therefore been argued it is part of the product and not leaked or rumour. All the above articles meet [[WP:VG/RS]] and two are from the same publication. [[WP:Synthesis]] and [[WP:Inaccuracy]] are both relevant here. 23:33, 30 January 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Planet Nine#rfc_18375E4|Talk:Planet Nine]] expired 2016-03-01 05:01 ===
* Id: 18375E4
* User: nagualdesign
* Date: 2016-02-04 03:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|703209595|SCI 703209595}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|708365586|SCI 708365586}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
''(Notifying previously involved editors: [[User:Jehochman|Jehochman]], [[User:Prokaryotes|prokaryotes]], [[User:Serendipodous|Serendipodous]], [[User:Future Perfect at Sunrise|Fut.Perf. ☼]], [[User:Ephraim33|Ephraim33]], [[User:Nergaal|Nergaal]], [[User:Neutron|Neutron]], [[User:Leitmotiv|Leitmotiv]], [[User:Kheider|Kheider]], [[User:Wnt|Wnt]], [[User:Nowa|Nowa]], [[User:Itu|Itu]], [[User:Smkolins|Smkolins]], [[User:Tomruen|Tom Ruen]] and [[User:Jonathunder|Jonathunder]].)''

I really think we need more input regarding the images used on this article. There have been a few previous discussions<sup>[[Talk:Planet Nine/Archive 1#Artistic image of PN|[1]]][[Talk:Planet Nine/Archive 1#Remove artists conception|[2]]][[Talk:Planet Nine/Archive 2#perspective|[3]]][[Talk:Planet Nine/Archive 2#Diagrams|[4]]][[Talk:Planet Nine/Archive 2#Picture|[5]]]</sup> but no clear consensus was demonstrated. I propose that we pool our collective opinions here and put things to a vote. Since there are 2 questionable images I'll split this into 2 subsections.

'''Artist's impression in the infobox'''

[[File:Planet-Nine-in-Outer-Space-artistic-depiction.jpg|thumb|right|An artist's impression of Planet Nine]]
The infobox currently shows an artist's impression of Planet Nine (right), which appears to be closely based on [http://www.caltech.edu/news/caltech-researchers-find-evidence-real-ninth-planet-49523 an image released by Caltech credited to R. Hurt (IPAC)]. While artist's impressions may help to grab the reader's attention I do not think that it's becoming of an encyclopedia to reproduce them here and I propose that it be removed, or at the very least removed from the infobox. The only information it conveys are ''basic assumptions'', which could easily mislead the reader. [https://www.google.co.uk/maps/@21.854703,-45.6376436,22971116m/data=!3m1!1e3?hl=en A view of the Earth can be found here] in which the planet's size and distance from the Sun is similarly ''not'' conveyed. Please bear in mind that even if you don't find the picture misleading, others undoubtedly will.

'''Propose''' the complete removal of artist's impression. Sorry. '''<span style="font-family:Trebuchet MS; font-size:1.3em; letter-spacing:-0.07em; line-height:1em;">[[User:Nagualdesign|<font color="#000000">nagual</font>]][[User talk:nagualdesign|<font color="#ABAB9D">design</font>]]</span>''' 03:43, 4 February 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Capital letters#rfc_05BA6F2|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Capital letters]] expired 2016-03-01 16:02 ===
* Id: 05BA6F2
* User: SNUGGUMS
* Date: 2016-02-10 03:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|704266215|LANG 704266215}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|704266227|SOC 704266227}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|704266231|STYLE 704266231}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|704266234|POLICY 704266234}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|709474281|LANG 709474281}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|709474284|SOC 709474284}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|709474286|STYLE 709474286}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|709474287|POLICY 709474287}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the word "like" be capitalized within titles (excluding situations where it is the first word of the title)? I came across [[Template:Did you know nominations/Love Me like You]] where an editor cited MOS:CT for the capitalization of "like", though this page currently doesn't say whether it should generally be capitalized or not. [[User:SNUGGUMS|<b style="color:#454545">Snuggums</b>]] ([[User talk:SNUGGUMS|<b style="color:#454545">talk</b>]] / [[Special:Contributions/SNUGGUMS|<b style="color:#454545">edits</b>]]) 03:37, 10 February 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Capital letters#rfc_19E8093|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Capital letters]] expired 2016-03-01 16:02 ===
* Id: 19E8093
* User: Tom29739
* Date: 2016-01-31 15:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|702600115|STYLE 702600115}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|702600119|POLICY 702600119}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|707751017|STYLE 707751017}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|707751019|POLICY 707751019}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The Wikipedia Manual of Style does not currently have any solid guidelines on how to capitalise trademarks with multiple capital letters, such as 'tvOS', 'watchOS', 'webOS', etc. The only guidelines I can find currently are: 
* [[Wikipedia:Article titles#Use commonly recognizable names]],
* [[Wikipedia:Manual of Style#Article titles]],
* [[Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Capital letters#Trademarks]] and
* [[Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Trademarks#Trademarks that begin with a lowercase letter]].
Editors are divided over which forms to use, e.g. whether to use 'exampleOS', 'ExampleOS' or 'EXAMPLEOS' and whether to use different forms at the start of sentences, etc. The Manual of Style needs some guideline to use because the current ones do not give a rule to follow for this situation. Thanks, [[User:Tom29739|Tom29739]] ([[User talk:Tom29739|talk]]) 15:18, 31 January 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Israeli lira#rfc_6D34DF0|Talk:Israeli lira]] expired 2016-03-01 23:02 ===
* Id: 6D34DF0
* User: LlywelynII
* Date: 2016-02-09 06:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|704061407|ECON 704061407}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|704061409|HIST 704061409}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|704061412|POL 704061412}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|704061413|SOC 704061413}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|704061417|STYLE 704061417}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|704061419|POLICY 704061419}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|707813599|ECON 707813599}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|707813602|HIST 707813602}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|707813606|POL 707813606}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|707813611|SOC 707813611}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|707813615|STYLE 707813615}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|707813617|POLICY 707813617}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[:Israeli lira]] → {{no redirect|Israeli pound|rfcid=2D71369}} – Per {{sc|[[wp:useenglish]]}} {{sc|[[wp:commonname]]}}s.<br>There was a previous vote that was rather one-sided:
:''pound:'' [[User:Epson291]], [[User:AjaxSmack]]
:''lira:'' [[User:Dove1950]], [[User:Chochopk]], [[User:Number 57]], [[User:Nightstallion]], [[User:Valley2city]], [[User:Jayjg]]<br>
but may have been the result of [[wp:canvas|an unrepresentative sample]] since the ''lira'' contingent ignored Epson's solid arguments and data, referred to each other as colleagues, and relied on anecdotal evidence and a [[WP:LOCALCONSENSUS|misconception]] that [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Numismatics|{{sc|wpcoin}}]]'s guidelines trumped {{sc|[[wp:useenglish]]}} {{sc|[[wp:commonname]]}}s.<br><br>This is the English wiki and the common English name of this currency is the ''Israel'' or ''Israeli pound''; ''lira'' was the Hebrew name but that was always aside the point. Pound is over twice as common as lira even [https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&q=%22Israeli+pound%22&btnG=&as_sdt=1%2C33&as_sdtp= at] [https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&q=%22Israel+pound%22&btnG=&as_sdt=1%2C33&as_sdtp= Google] [https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&q=%22Israeli+lira%22&btnG=&as_sdt=1%2C33&as_sdtp= Scholar]; [https://books.google.com/ngrams/graph?content=Israeli+lira%2C+Israeli+pound%2CIsrael+lira%2CIsrael+pound&year_start=1800&year_end=2020&corpus=15&smoothing=3&share=&direct_url=t1%3B%2CIsraeli%20lira%3B%2Cc0%3B.t1%3B%2CIsraeli%20pound%3B%2Cc0%3B.t1%3B%2CIsrael%20pound%3B%2Cc0 much more common in historical sources] (and this is a historical article); and, more importantly, [http://www.bankisrael.gov.il/en/Currency/PastNotesAndCoinsSeries/Pages/Default.aspx#Top continues to be the ''formal'' translation of the currency used by the Bank of Israel], who presumably know the Hebrew name and when and where to use it.<br><br>Even at the time, the editors above should have [[WP:IAR|ignored the policy they were citing]] ("use the local name even where there is an English alternative") since it's a lousy one. The editor just above them even pointed that out, along with its lack of authority, which they ignored. Since then, <u>the policy itself has been corrected</u>. It now reads
:''Use the term for the currency that is most commonly used by standard English language sources. Such sources include encyclopedias, media of record, academic literature, government publications, and numismatic catalogues. English language descriptions of the currency by the issuing authority, as well as usage of English names on the currency itself, should also be considered.''<br>
which means ''it's'' now in favor of a move as well. Let's fix this.&nbsp;—&nbsp;[[User talk:LlywelynII|<span style="text-shadow:#BBBBBB 0.1em 0.1em 0.1em; class=texhtml">Llywelyn<font color="Gold">II</font></span>]] 06:58, 9 February 2016 (UTC)}}
There is some disagreement over what this article should be about just the phrase 'Comedy of the Commons', or if it should generally be about the concept 'successful commons' - which is referred to by some as 'Comedy of the Commons'. Also, see [[Tragedy of the commons]] a phrase that refers to the concept of a 'unsuccessful commons'. [[User:Jonpatterns|Jonpatterns]] ([[User talk:Jonpatterns|talk]]) 16:00, 6 February 2016 (UTC)|rfcid=E925957}}
Previous discussion can be found on this talk page ([[#Arbitration clause]]).  Thanks for your feedback, <span style="color: #D00000">'''RJaguar3 &#124; [[User: RJaguar3|u]] &#124; [[User Talk:RJaguar3|t]]'''</span> 20:36, 2 February 2016 (UTC)|rfcid=E775BA6}}
{{rfc|rfcid=80BA7DB}}

} }}
