=== [[Talk:World Open (snooker)#rfc_41FA4C8|Talk:World Open (snooker)]] expired 2016-06-02 14:01 ===
* Id: 41FA4C8
* User: Betty Logan
* Date: 2016-05-03 13:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|718434490|SOC 718434490}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|723343837|SOC 723343837}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This article up until March used to include the World Grand Prix results (the 2015 and 2016 entries in the table) until this was contested by Armbrust. Armbrust [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=World_Open_(snooker)&diff=708032340&oldid=704346010 contested the view that the World Grand Prix was not a rebranded continuation of the World Open, but a new tournament and removed the WGP results]. He provided sources that referred to it as the "inaugural" tournament. This was contested by several editors who pointed out that World Grand Prix held the same spot on the calendar, had the same broadcaster and also used the historic Grand prix/World Open trophy which had the previous winners engraved on the trophy alongside those of the World Grand Prix. An IP editor [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=World_Open_(snooker)&diff=708830190&oldid=708828806 initiated a cut and paste move] which was subsequently reverted. This led to me proposing a rename at [[#Requested move 11 March 2016]] for the article (to move the article to the World Grand Prix page) but the proposed move resulted in a "no consensus".

The question remains over what to do with the World Grand prix results. An IP is persisting in [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=World_Open_%28snooker%29&type=revision&diff=718335962&oldid=718070726 removing the results], effectively splitting the World Grand Prix content to its own article. The problem with this is that it has implications for performance table in the player articles. Case in point: if you look at [[Judd_Trump#Performance_and_rankings_timeline]], you will see there is an entry for the World Grand Prix twelve tournaments down the list. This entry combines the World Open and World Grand Prix results as this article did: the problem though is that if a completely new article is created to house the World Grand Prix results the World Open/World Grand Prix entries in the performance tables need to be also split into separate entries too, otherwise the performance tables link to the wrong tournament. Up to [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:WhatLinksHere/World_Open_(snooker)&limit=250 250 articles are affected in all].

So there are two options:
* '''No split''' - We retain the status quo in accoridance with the "no consensus" result from the move discussion and house the World Grand Prix results at the World Open article, and thus retaining the internal link integrity.
* '''Split''' - We split out the World Grand Prix results to its own article, but this will necessitate the fixing of the entries in the performance tables at the player articles that are effected by the split. 
[[User:Betty Logan|Betty Logan]] ([[User talk:Betty Logan|talk]]) 13:42, 3 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:European Graduate School#rfc_8FE92BF|Talk:European Graduate School]] expired 2016-06-02 17:01 ===
* Id: 8FE92BF
* User: Jytdog
* Date: 2016-05-03 15:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|718451475|UNSORTED 718451475}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|718767045|SOC 718767045}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|723368523|ECON 723368523}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|723368530|SOC 723368530}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|723368532|UNSORTED 723368532}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Shall we update the accreditation section (including the header) with the following?   If we fail to reach consensus, the outcome should be removal of the section since we cannot agree on anything to say; if you disagree with that please say so. 

;Licenses and recognition

EGS is licensed as a university in Malta<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ncfhe.gov.mt/en/register/Pages/list_universities.aspx |title= List of Licensed Institutions and Accredited Courses > Universities |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref> and is recognized in the Swiss canton where it operates,<ref>Canton du Valais [https://www.vs.ch/web/she/formation-et-recherche-universitaires Formation et recherche universitaires] Page accessed April 7, 2016</ref> but is not recognized by the [[Swiss University Conference]], the main regulatory body for universities in [[Switzerland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.swissuniversities.ch/en/higher-education-area/recognised-swiss-higher-education-institutions/ |title=swissuniversities |accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref>  In the US, the State of Texas includes the European Graduate School on its published list of institutions that issue "fraudulent or substandard degrees" and notes that it is illegal to use an EGS degree to obtain employment within the state.<ref name="texas">{{cite web | url=http://www.thecb.state.tx.us/?objectid=EF4C3C3B-EB44-4381-6673F760B3946FBB | title=Institutions Whose Degrees are Illegal to Use in Texas | publisher=Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board | accessdate=18 February 2016}}</ref> 

{{reflist-talk}}

- [[User:Jytdog|Jytdog]] ([[User talk:Jytdog|talk]]) 15:13, 3 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Revision deletion#rfc_FB9DA15|Wikipedia talk:Revision deletion]] expired 2016-06-03 00:01 ===
* Id: FB9DA15
* User: BU Rob13
* Date: 2016-05-03 23:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|718515875|POLICY 718515875}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|722092045|POLICY 722092045}}
* RFC Text:

Currently, the policy states the following about appealing RevDel.
"Actions performed using this tool remain visible in the public logs. They are subject to review by other administrators (who can see redacted material), and to reversal upon clear, wider consensus. As with other administrative tools, good judgment and appropriate use are expected; improper use can lead to sanctions or desysopping."

Additionally, the [[WP:REVDEL#Misuse|section]] on misuse reads:

"Material must be grossly offensive, with little likelihood of significant dissent about its removal. Otherwise it should not be removed."

There was disagreement surrounding a [[Wikipedia:Administrators%27_noticeboard/IncidentArchive922#BLP_revdel_on_the_Gamergate_Talk_page|recent discussion]] at ANI about how RevDel appeals should take place, and this RfC seeks to make the process more clear. ~ <b>[[User:BU Rob13|Rob]]</b><sup>[[User talk:BU Rob13|Talk]]</sup> 23:26, 3 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Hilton Worldwide#rfc_B85AD12|Talk:Hilton Worldwide]] expired 2016-06-04 21:01 ===
* Id: B85AD12
* User: Inkian Jason
* Date: 2016-05-05 19:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|718815125|ECON 718815125}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|723726562|ECON 723726562}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should this article's infobox include Blackstone Group in the "owner" parameter?

I submitted a request to remove Blackstone Group from the infobox (see the [[Talk:Hilton_Worldwide#Request_for_updates_to_infobox|Request for updates to infobox]] section above, or more specifically, the [[Talk:Hilton_Worldwide#Re:_Blackstone_Group|Re: Blackstone Group]] subsection). Hilton Worldwide is a publicly traded company. According to infobox template documentation (bold emphasis mine), we should "Use [the owner] parameter to list ownership percentages for private companies owned by a few key individuals or to list ownership percentages for joint ventures, if applicable. '''Do not use this field for publicly traded companies.''' When listing a company as an owner, use the full legal name of the entity that holds the ownership stake in the article's subject company."

[[User:Toohool]] disagrees with the infobox documentation. [[User:Altamel]] does not feel strongly either way, but offered the following compromise: "perhaps Blackstone Group could be removed from the infobox while writing a sentence in the introduction about Blackstone's plurality ownership stake". I agreed to this compromise. User:Toohool did not accept the compromise, and User:Altamel closed the edit request saying there is no consensus for update the article accordingly.

I think template documentation supports my argument, but Blackstone Group remains in the infobox and I am not willing to edit the article myself given my conflict of interest (see multiple sections above). I would like for more editors to weigh in on this discussion. Thank you in advance. [[User:Inkian Jason|Inkian Jason]] ([[User talk:Inkian Jason|talk]]) 19:55, 5 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Iran#rfc_343572B|Talk:Iran]] expired 2016-06-04 22:01 ===

=== [[Talk:Potato chip#rfc_33B6167|Talk:Potato chip]] expired 2016-06-05 00:01 ===
* Id: 33B6167
* User: Andy Dingley
* Date: 2016-05-13 12:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|720057199|HIST 720057199}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|724926244|HIST 724926244}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the caption (not the article title) be "Potato chips" or "Potato chips / crisps"? See [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Potato_chip&diff=719943480&oldid=719916658]

There has been considerable edit-warring here lately by an IP removing the UK term. It has been restored by multiple editors.  I see this as a purely behavioural and POV issue, but before going to ANEW would like to confirm consensus from others.

IMHO, both terms are needed and should be used. This is our usual behaviour.

The IP has made similar edits at [[Mars (chocolate bar)]]. They have raised an RfC here to try and discredit a source showing the prior British invention, but that gained no support. They have claimed, incorrectly, that ENGVAR requires the UK alternative name to be removed (obviously it doesn't). They have used a variety of IPs (a large British ISP), but this is just technical and should not be construed as deliberate socking. They have even raised a protected edit request, when the article was protected against their own edit warring.

Thoughts? [[User:Andy Dingley|Andy Dingley]] ([[User talk:Andy Dingley|talk]]) 12:09, 13 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_2CEBFC0|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2016-06-06 07:01 ===
* Id: 2CEBFC0
* User: Music1201
* Date: 2016-05-31 03:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|722957071|POLICY 722957071}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|722957072|TECH 722957072}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|722957076|PROP 722957076}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|723949364|POLICY 723949364}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|723949367|TECH 723949367}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|723949368|PROP 723949368}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A common problem I come across while new page patrolling is tagging pages with CSD tags. It's a problem because they can take hours to be deleted. There are so many users who have very lengthy CSD logs with mostly red-links, and the encyclopedia would benefit greatly by allowing editors other than administrators to delete pages. The deletion log is likely the lengthiest log, because hundreds of pages are deleted daily. It's strange that such a common process can only be done by sysops. I'm proposing that these rights be added to the proposed 'deleter' user-group: <code>delete</code>, <s><code>undelete</code> and <code>deleterevision</code></s>. The deletion of articles would also be restricted to pages created in the last 24 hours and with less than a certain number of edits (I propose 15). <span style="font-family:sans-serif; color:red">&mdash; <span style="font-weight:bold">[[User:Music1201|<span style="color:green"> Music1201</span>]] <sup>[[User talk:Music1201|<span style="color:red">talk</span>]]</sup></span></span> 03:53, 31 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_9140B65|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2016-06-06 23:01 ===
* Id: 9140B65
* User: Music1201
* Date: 2016-05-27 03:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|722290310|POLICY 722290310}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|722290313|PROP 722290313}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|722607437|POLICY 722607437}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|724066524|PROP 724066524}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Templates and interface pages are somewhat similar. They both encompass variables and other similar things. Since there is a lack of pages protected with template protection (most protected templates are full-protection,) I think it would be useful to give <code>editinterface</code> rights to the template editors' user group. <span style="font-family:sans-serif; color:red">&mdash; <span style="font-weight:bold">[[User:Music1201|<span style="color:green"> Music1201</span>]] <sup>[[User talk:Music1201|<span style="color:red">talk</span>]]</sup></span></span> 03:57, 27 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Rfd2#rfc_92986D0|Template talk:Rfd2]] expired 2016-06-07 00:01 ===
* Id: 92986D0
* User: Fred Gandt
* Date: 2016-05-11 10:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|719819067|TECH 719819067}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|719819069|PROP 719819069}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|724614075|TECH 724614075}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|724614076|PROP 724614076}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per {{U|Oiyarbepsy}}'s [[Template talk:Rfd2#Template produces hopeless technobabble|request to simplify the raw wikitext result of substituting rfd2]], I worked to build {{tl|rfd2 links}} and have implemented its use in {{tl|rfd2/sandbox}}.

When substituted, this sandboxed version of {{tl|rfd2}} leaves {{tlc|rfd2 links}} unsubstituted in place of what is usually a large and complex mess of wikitext markup for various links.

* It is proposed to make this the default configuration for {{tlc|rfd2}}.

There is a concern that whilst {{tlc|rfd2 links}} is transcluded in use, any changes to the template would be reflected in the transclusions, which at any time may be many. It is thus proposed that if this method is employed, {{tlc|rfd2 links}} should be template-protected from the start, and possibly automatically substituted by bot once it's ''archived''. {{u|Anomie}} who operates {{u|AnomieBOT}} (which is currently utilised for auto substitutions) may like to advise? <code class="nowrap" style="background:#DFF"> [[User:Fred Gandt|Fred Gandt]] <small>([[User talk:Fred Gandt|talk]]&#124;[[Special:Contributions/Fred Gandt|contribs]])</small></code> 10:02, 11 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_2B4AACD|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2016-06-07 02:01 ===
* Id: 2B4AACD
* User: Ricky81682
* Date: 2016-05-20 21:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|721515182|POLICY 721515182}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|721515187|PROP 721515187}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|724086115|POLICY 724086115}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|724086120|PROP 724086120}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Non-[[WP:AFC|AFC]] drafts in draftspace have no G13 method for automatic deletion or for any review at all. As such, [[User:MusikBot/StaleDrafts/Report|there are hundreds of stale drafts that haven't been edited in a long time]]. Attempts to add G13 or other criteria have been repeatedly and expressly rejected so instead these pages take up a lot of time at [[WP:MFD]] where deletion is somewhat routine. I'd like to propose that we allow for a new draft proposed deletion system with the following rules:
# Draftspace drafts that are not tagged with AFC that haven't been edited in six months can be considered.
# If the deletion is proposed, it would go into a dated category similar to [[:Category:Proposed deletion]] for at least ''one month'' at which time any one can remove the proposal for ''any reason whatsoever''. This is similar to the 5 month notification of [[:Category:AfC G13 eligible soon submissions]] with a month before G13.
# After a month with no deletion, an admin can then decide if it's worth deleting.
I've added header for support as is and a separate support in case people support the general concept but disagree on the six month/one prod timeline. -- [[User:Ricky81682|Ricky81682]] ([[User talk:Ricky81682|talk]]) 21:34, 20 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_043F5FC|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2016-06-07 04:01 ===
* Id: 043F5FC
* User: Display name 99
* Date: 2016-06-06 22:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|724099779|POLICY 724099779}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Proposal: Should the removal of the {{para|religion}} parameter as done [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Village_pump_(policy)/Archive_126#RfC:_Religion_in_biographical_infoboxes here] apply only to BLPs?'''<br>
*Religion would remain as a category in the biographies of deceased persons and be included in the infobox based on consensus at each particular article. 
* It will stay off the infoboxes of BLPs in accordance with the previous RfC. [[User:Display name 99|Display name 99]] ([[User talk:Display name 99|talk]]) 22:24, 6 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_6D1D6E1|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2016-06-07 12:01 ===
* Id: 6D1D6E1
* User: Music1201
* Date: 2016-05-27 03:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|724066525|UNSORTED 724066525}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|724145200|UNSORTED 724145200}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Templates and interface pages are somewhat similar. They both encompass variables and other similar things. Since there is a lack of pages protected with template protection (most protected templates are full-protection,) I think it would be useful to give <code>editinterface</code> rights to the template editors' user group. <span style="font-family:sans-serif; color:red">&mdash; <span style="font-weight:bold">[[User:Music1201|<span style="color:green"> Music1201</span>]] <sup>[[User talk:Music1201|<span style="color:red">talk</span>]]</sup></span></span> 03:57, 27 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[User:Shhhnotsoloud/sandbox#rfc_DB06591|User:Shhhnotsoloud/sandbox]] expired 2016-06-07 15:01 ===
* Id: DB06591
* User: Shhhnotsoloud
* Date: 2016-06-07 08:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|724121123|HIST 724121123}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|724121126|STYLE 724121126}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|724121128|POLICY 724121128}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|724167310|HIST 724167310}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|724167319|STYLE 724167319}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|724167322|POLICY 724167322}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The name "Persian Gulf" is disputed (see [[Persian Gulf naming dispute]]) and although it is ''widely accepted'' in accordance with WP guidelines [[WP:WIAN]], it is not used by Arab states. A recognised (by BGN, Google maps and various atlases) ''alternative name'' is "Arabian Gulf". As a compromise:
:Should the name be determined by the article content? For example, an article about an Arab entity would use the term "Arabian Gulf", while an article on a Persian/Iranian entity would use "Persian Gulf"?

'''Discussion at [[ Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#RfC: Persian Gulf and Arabian Gulf ]]'''

[[File:Farm-Fresh eye.png|15px|link=|alt=]]You are invited to join the discussion at [[ Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#RfC: Persian Gulf and Arabian Gulf ]].  [[User:Shhhnotsoloud|Shhhnotsoloud]] ([[User talk:Shhhnotsoloud|talk]]) 08:07, 7 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Requests for comment/Genetically modified organisms#rfc_24965F8|Wikipedia:Requests for comment/Genetically modified organisms]] expired 2016-06-07 15:01 ===
* Id: 24965F8
* User: Coffee
* Date: 2016-06-03 20:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|724025414|UNSORTED 724025414}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|724034127|SCI 724034127}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|724167325|UNSORTED 724167325}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{ARBGMO talk notice|style=long}}

This is a '''Request for Comment''', conducted under [[Wikipedia:Arbitration Committee/Discretionary sanctions|discretionary sanctions issued by the Arbitration Committee]], concerning how to indicate the scientific views on the safety of genetically modified crops for human consumption.

'''Introduction'''

[[#Comments|''Jump to comments section.'']]

'''Purpose of this RfC'''

The following pages are affected by this RfC:
{{cot|List of pages|bg=#F2E0CE}}
*[[Genetically modified food controversies]] (lead and health section)
*[[Genetically modified crops]] (lead and controversy section)
*[[Genetically modified food]] (lead and health and safety section)
*[[Genetically modified organism]] (controversy section)
*[[Genetically modified canola]] (controversy section)
*[[Genetically modified maize]] (controversy section)
*[[Genetically modified soybean]] (controversy section)
*[[March Against Monsanto]] (background section)
*[[Regulation of the release of genetically modified organisms]] (lead)
*[[Biotechnology]] (agriculture section)
*[[Denialism]] (genetically modified foods section)
{{cob}}

Each of these pages has language similar to: {{tq|There is general scientific agreement that food on the market derived from GM crops poses no greater risk to human health than conventional food, but should be tested on a case-by-case basis.}} Editors are generally dissatisfied with this wording, but disagree about how to revise it. '''This RfC presents options for content to replace that wording, and is intended to determine community consensus about that.'''

Specifically, '''you are asked to address two questions''':

1. Based upon the policies, guidelines, and concepts related to [[scientific consensus]], listed [[#Policies, guidelines and essays to keep in mind|below]], do the preponderance of reliable sources (see citations in the [[#Proposals|listed proposals]]) indicate that there is a scientific consensus about the safety of genetically modified food with respect to human health?

2. Should the existing language be changed, and which content [[#Proposals|proposal(s)]], if any, best represent the answer to question 1 for inclusion in the articles listed above?

'''Rules'''

Under the authority granted to Uninvolved Administrators and by the terms of the [[Wikipedia:Arbitration/Requests/Case/Genetically modified organisms|Arbitration Committee GMO case]], and [[WP:ACDS|Standard Discretionary Sanctions]] as [[Wikipedia:Arbitration/Requests/Case/Genetically modified organisms#Discretionary Sanctions|authorized by that case]], the following limits are imposed on debate:

*'''All editors are required to maintain a proper level of decorum'''. Unnecessary rudeness, hostility, casting aspersions, and battleground mentality '''will not be tolerated''' here, in the interest of arriving at a clear, fair-minded consensus. Inappropriate conduct may be met with warnings, blocks, or bans from further participation in this RfC as the administrator deems necessary. To foster a collaborative atmosphere, editors are encouraged not to bring statements made here to Arbitration Enforcement, but rather to leave it to the patrolling admins.
*The '''sole purpose''' of this RfC is to determine consensus about a specific question concerning article content. It is not a venue for personal opinions about GMOs in general, nor a place to relitigate past disputes.
*All comments '''must''' be about article ''content'' or the ''content'' of users' proposals. Comments on any contributor, ''ad hominem'', attacks, aspersions, or that are found in any other way to not conform to the standards prescribed herein, '''are prohibited'''. 
**Any violations of these restrictions '''will be reverted, removed, or redacted'''. 
**Violating editors '''will face blocks or discretionary sanctions''', with or without warning and at the discretion of an administrator.
*If you came here because someone asked you to, or you read a message on another website, please note that this is [[Wikipedia:Polling is not a substitute for discussion|'''not a majority vote''']], but instead a ''discussion'' among Wikipedia contributors. Wikipedia has [[Wikipedia:Policies and guidelines|policies and guidelines]] regarding the encyclopedia's content, and [[Wikipedia:Consensus|'''consensus''']] (agreement) is gauged based on the merits of the arguments, not by counting votes.
*If you believe that a user is violating policy or the rules set forth by Arbcom or by this page, and you cannot work it out between yourselves, please speak to an Enforcement admin at their talk page or at ANI, '''not here or on this RFC's talk page'''. If you believe an admin is behaving inappropriately, their decisions may be appealed to [[WP:ANI]], [[WP:AE]] or Arbcom directly.
*Please '''do not make changes''' in proposals that have already been posted. '''Anyone is permitted to post additional proposals''', below the existing proposals.
*'''Threaded discussion is prohibited on the RfC page'''. To comment in the RfC, you '''must''' create '''your own section''' within the [[#Comments|Comments]] section, placing your username in the section header. Within your own section, you may present your opinions on the proposals, and briefly pose questions to other editors or respond to questions from other editors. Do not make "support" or "oppose" comments under each proposal; indicate these opinions instead within your own section. '''Do not make any edits in any other editor's section'''. A section may be edited '''only''' by the editor to whom it corresponds, and by enforcing administrators. Editors are encouraged to discuss and collaborate with one another on the RfC Talk page, where threaded discussion is permitted and there are no word limits.
*In each comment section, each editor is '''strictly limited to 800 words''', including replies to other editors. ([http://wordcounttools.com Word Count Tool]) There will be no exceptions. Excessively long statements will be hatted until shortened.
*{{user|KrakatoaKatie}}, {{user|Nakon}}, and {{user|Deor}}, have agreed to serve as a panel of three experienced, uninvolved editors who will close the RfC after 30 days and determine the consensus (if any). Because this is such a contentious area, the RfC will run for '''the full 30 days''', unless additional time is needed to judge consensus, and closing early as per [[WP:SNOW]] is unlikely.
*The consensus reached (if any) '''will be imposed as a Discretionary Sanction''' on the topic area, broadly construed. It may be overturned only by another widely published full 30-day RfC, a consensus of administrators at [[WP:AE]], or by decree of the Arbitration Committee.

*Nobody is required to participate in this RfC, and anybody may cease participation at any time for any reason. However, it is in everyone's best interest that we solicit a wide range of opinions so that we may achieve a strong consensus.
*Finally, if you have issue with my own conduct or with these rules, we request that you please discuss with us on our own user talk pages before escalating. We am always willing to listen to a reasonable argument.

'''Administrators Moderating this Request for Comment'''

:*<small style="color:#999;white-space:nowrap;text-shadow:lightgrey 0.3em 0.3em 0.15em;">&mdash; [[User:Coffee|<big style="color:#ffa439">Coffee</big>]] // [[user talk:Coffee|<font color="#009900">have a cup</font>]] // [[Special:Contributions/Coffee|<font color="#4682b4">beans</font>]] // </small> 20:30, 3 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion#rfc_222419F|Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion]] expired 2016-06-09 10:01 ===
* Id: 222419F
* User: Adam9007
* Date: 2016-06-01 23:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|723276122|POLICY 723276122}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|724452077|POLICY 724452077}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I don't see the point of A9 any more. Per [[Wikipedia_talk:Credible_claim_of_significance#RfC:_Can_SIGNIFICANCE_be_inherited.3F|this RfC]] having a notable recording artist would likely constitute a [[Wikipedia:Credible claim of significance|credible claim of significance]] anyway (those that have articles tend to be notable), making the no-recording-artist-having-an-article requirement totally redundant. I've seen articles about musical recordings whose artist does have an article tagged A9 when it's clear the artist's article will be deleted (they technically don't meet A9 until it has been deleted). I'm proposing that we scrap that requirement and merge what's left of A9 into A7; it's senseless to have them as separate criteria. [[User:Adam9007|Adam9007]] ([[User talk:Adam9007|talk]]) 23:47, 1 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:The Matrix#rfc_F7A932B|Talk:The Matrix]] expired 2016-06-09 20:01 ===
* Id: F7A932B
* Date: 2016-05-10 19:27:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|719630201|BIO 719630201}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|719630208|MEDIA 719630208}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|724520458|BIO 724520458}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|724520463|MEDIA 724520463}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How should the directors of this film be presented in the lead of the article?

"''The Matrix'' is a [...] film written and directed by..."
*'''A''' - "the Wachowski Brothers"
*'''B''' - "the Wachowski Brothers (now known as the Wachowskis)"
*'''C''' - "the Wachowskis"
*'''D''' - "the Wachowskis (credited as the Wachowski Brothers)"

For context, the Wachowski Brothers have both come out as transgender women in the time since ''The Matrix'' was released. They are now credited as [[the Wachowskis]], not the Wachowski Brothers.

This is a matter that has been argued over extensively. A 2012 discussion at WikiProject Film ended with the determination that the infobox should reflect names as they appear in the credits, but I have not been able to find any such consensus for anything outside of the infobox. After many threads and many edits back and forth, a more formal RfC seems useful. &mdash; <tt>[[User:Rhododendrites|<span style="font-size:90%;letter-spacing:1px;text-shadow:0px -1px 0px Indigo;">Rhododendrites</span>]] <sup style="font-size:80%;">[[User_talk:Rhododendrites|talk]]</sup></tt> \\ 19:27, 10 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Marriage#rfc_F450B2B|Template talk:Marriage]] expired 2016-06-09 21:01 ===
* Id: F450B2B
* User: DrKay
* Date: 2016-05-10 20:50:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|719630201|BIO 719630201}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|724528872|BIO 724528872}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{Infobox person
|name=John Smith
|birth_date=1892
|death_date=1942
|spouse={{marriage|Joan Smith|1916|1942|end=widowed}}
}}
This template uses a parameter, "end", to display a reason for the termination of a marriage. The template documentation advises that the end date should be the date a marriage was dissolved or the date that the spouse of the article subject died. However, in the event of a marriage ending by the death of the article subject, it is possible to signal that by using "end=widowed", for example <nowiki>{{marriage|Joan Smith|1916|1942|end=widowed}}</nowiki> produces the output "Joan Smith ({{abbr|m.|married}} 1916; {{abbr|wid.|widowed}} 1942)", attempting to indicate that Joan Smith was widowed in 1942. Should this functionality be kept or removed? [[User:DrKay|DrKay]] ([[User talk:DrKay|talk]]) 20:50, 10 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Ipswich#rfc_046C17E|Talk:Ipswich]] expired 2016-06-10 11:01 ===
* Id: 046C17E
* User: Keri
* Date: 2016-05-11 10:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|719732392|SOC 719732392}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|724614073|SOC 724614073}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per the essay [[Wikipedia:Famous Residents]] I propose that we use these 3 criteria for inclusion on the [[Ipswich]] article:
# Notability: The person must be notable enough to have an article in Wikipedia.
# Residence: The person must be or must have been a true resident of Ipswich itself; not a seasonal or short-term resident; not a resident of a nearby locale or community. Such residence must be verifiable through cited, reliable sources.
# Significance to Ipswich: The person's notability must derive from the location OR the person must have derived the basis for their notability in that location OR the person must hold some significance to the location in general. Examples: an artist who was notable for painting scenes of the town; an author who wrote a book about the town; a singer who developed his/her talent and/or was "discovered" in Ipswich while they were living there; a professional athlete who developed his/her talent in a local athletic team; a mass-murderer who lived in the town when he/she murdered his/her victims; an actor who establishes his/her notability prior to living in the town, but is now a resident who uses his/her notability to benefit local charities or becomes a public servant.
Inclusions must meet all 3 criteria. [[User:Keri|Keri]] ([[User talk:Keri|talk]]) 10:13, 11 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Comics#rfc_A144557|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Comics]] expired 2016-06-10 16:01 ===
* Id: A144557
* User: Tenebrae
* Date: 2016-05-11 14:34:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|719748190|MEDIA 719748190}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|723425291|STYLE 723425291}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|724649289|MEDIA 724649289}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|724649297|STYLE 724649297}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|724649300|POLICY 724649300}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Currently, [[Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Comics#Titles]] specifies that "comic book series, comic strips and comics publications should be italicized. For the titles of comic book storylines, chapters, comic strip episodes, an individual editorial cartoon or gag panel, editors should use quotation marks." It give as examples:
{{quote|* {{xt|''Identity Crisis''}}, the title of a [[DC Comics]] [[limited series]], should be italicized. {{xt|"Identity Crisis"}}, the title of a Spider-Man storyline that leads to the creation of the [[Slingers]], should be in quotation marks. [...]
* In 2006, Marvel published the {{xt|"[[Civil War (comics)|Civil War]]"}} cross-over event. The flagship title of the event is the limited series {{xt|''Civil War''}}.}}

The MOS does not specify comic-book features. These currently appear generally in quote marks, i.e., the feature "Nick Fury, Agent of SHIELD" in ''Strange Tales'' as opposed to the series ''Nick Fury, Agent of SHIELD''. (See ''[[Strange Tales]]''.) But this is not formal MOS. How should the MOS address features? --[[User:Tenebrae|Tenebrae]] ([[User talk:Tenebrae|talk]]) 14:34, 11 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:United States Senate elections, 2016#rfc_8B8D60A|Talk:United States Senate elections, 2016]] expired 2016-06-10 19:01 ===
* Id: 8B8D60A
* User: Orser67
* Date: 2016-05-11 18:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|719789255|POL 719789255}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|724672906|POL 724672906}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should primary dates be included in the table 2016 Senate elections summary table? [[User:Orser67|Orser67]] ([[User talk:Orser67|talk]]) 18:06, 11 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_45E18DD|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2016-06-10 20:01 ===
* Id: 45E18DD
* User: Fred Gandt
* Date: 2016-06-05 22:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|723896582|STYLE 723896582}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|723896586|TECH 723896586}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|723896595|PROP 723896595}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|728520486|STYLE 728520486}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|728520489|TECH 728520489}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|728520491|PROP 728520491}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
With two working demonstrations available, it is requested that the community comment on the possibility of implementing site wide, JavaScript enabled, interactive chess boards for visual demonstration of described ''plays''.

[[User:קיפודנחש|קיפודנחש]] (aka kipod) and [[User:Fred Gandt|Fred Gandt]] (me) have provided example demonstration code:
* [[User:קיפודנחש/pgn viewer demo|kipod's]] takes [[Portable Game Notation]] (PGN) and optional [[Forsyth–Edwards Notation]] (FEN) for non-standard set-up.
** It will output the PGN in a raw format for users with JavaScript disabled.
* [[User:Fred Gandt/sandbox/chessDemo|Fred's]] takes [[Algebraic notation (chess)|algebraic chess notation]] and optional partially plain English instructions for non-standard set-up.
** It will fallback to an animated .gif (if provided) for users with JavaScript disabled.
Both these demonstration examples require the addition of JavaScript to [[Special:MyPage/common.js|your common JS]] to see them. This RfC is to determine if and how such a feature might be woven into the fabric of Wikipedia such that ALL users will see the proposed functionality by default. Please view the demonstration examples in their scripted and unscripted conditions before commenting. Be aware that some [[CSS]] styling is also required, which is imported by the JavaScripts; thus the unscripted display may not be ''exactly'' as intended in any eventual site wide implementation.
; Related discussions:
: [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#Interactive chess boards]] - the parent section of this RfC.
: [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Chess/Interactive chess boards]]
&#32; <code style="background:#DFF;white-space:pre">[[User:Fred Gandt|Fred Gandt]] · [[User talk:Fred Gandt|talk]] · [[Special:Contributions/Fred Gandt|contribs]]</code> 22:59, 5 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_C50DD52|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2016-06-10 20:01 ===
* Id: C50DD52
* Date: 2016-05-11 19:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|721515185|TECH 721515185}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|721515187|PROP 721515187}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|724680595|TECH 724680595}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|724680597|PROP 724680597}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As [[WP:INTDAB|INTDAB]] indicates, links in mainspace to disambiguation pages are usually (but not always) wrong. [[User:DPL bot|DPL bot]] does a great job of catching these links when they are added, and letting the editor know on their talk page, but, as [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links]] makes clear, there is significant non-response to these bot messages. It seems to me that we would have greater compliance if we could intercede ''before'' changes are saved.

I propose a high-attention message and two buttons that appear when "Save" is clicked (with the exception of disambiguation pages, which often intentionally link to other disambiguation pages), modeled on DPL bot, e.g.: "You have added [a link{{!}}links] pointing to the disambiguation page[s] [X, Y, and Z]. Such links are almost always unintended, since a disambiguation page is merely a list of "Did you mean..." article titles." Buttons: [Return to edit][Save anyway]. So:

# Is there support for the idea?
# What are the technical limitations?

—[[user:swpb|<u>swpb</u>]]<sup>[[user talk:swpb|''T'']]</sup> 19:59, 11 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Eidetic memory#rfc_63A9941|Talk:Eidetic memory]] expired 2016-06-11 05:01 ===
* Id: 63A9941
* User: Flyer22 Reborn
* Date: 2016-05-12 04:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|719851362|SCI 719851362}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|719851366|MEDIA 719851366}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|719851369|SOC 719851369}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|724739218|SCI 724739218}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|724739221|MEDIA 724739221}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|724739226|SOC 724739226}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
If viewing this from the RfC page or an alert on your talk page, the full discussion starts at [[Talk:Eidetic memory#Eidetic vs. photographic]]. One concern is that "It should be very clear to readers that 'eidetic images' (in psychology) and 'photographic memory' are not the same things. Photographic memory does '''not''' exist, and eidetic images are generally not found in adults and they don't allow people to perform spectacular memory feats. [...] 'Eidetic imagery' in psychology is not 'photographic memory' -- it refers to the brief impression of an image that children sometimes see, and it has '''nothing to do with adults who memorize things'''. There is no science to support that." The other concern is that "'''most of the sources [...] are clear that the terms are used interchangeably''' or that photographic memory and eidetic memory '''are''' the same topic, but that the term ''eidetic memory'' is more accurate; if they distinguish photographic memory and eidetic memory at all, it's only slightly. In other words, sources usually treat these topics side by side and as the same thing while other sources distinguish them or slightly distinguish them."

So the issue is this: Should we be strict in stating that eidetic memory and photographic memory are not the same thing? Or should we should initially treat the terms as the same thing, with "photographic memory" as the [[WP:Alternative title]], and then relay that the terms are sometimes distinguished? Sources for examining the terminological matter are below. I will alert [[WP:WikiProject Psychology]] and [[WP:Biology]] to this discussion.

{{collapse top|title=Click on this to see the sources.}}

'''1.''' {{cite book|author=D. Draaisma|title=Metaphors of Memory: A History of Ideas about the Mind|publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]|isbn=0521650240|year=2000|page=129|accessdate=May 11, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q0LlL1A9p9cC&pg=PA129|quote=The type of visual memory which is commonly called 'a photographic memory' was connected with photography at an early period. In 1868 Maudsley described the case of a man who was capable of repeating a text he had just read, backwards. This is the kind of visual memory, writes Maudsley, 'in which the person seems to read a photographic copy of former impressions with his mind's eye'. The metaphor of the 'photographic memory' is considerably older than the specialist term 'eidetic memory', which was only introduced in 1922.}}

'''2.''' {{cite book|author=David Moxon|title=Memory|publisher=[[Heinemann (publisher)|Heinemann]]|isbn=0435806521|year=2000|page=15|accessdate=May 11, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xy90vrTuZNQC&pg=PA15|quote=Photographic (eidetic) memory  is a term given to describe an almost perfect replication of some observed material (usually observed for only a short period of time). It is more correctly referred to as 'eidetic memory'.}}

'''3.''' {{cite book|author=Dennis Coon|title=Psychology: A Modular Approach to Mind and Behavior|publisher=[[Cengage Learning]]|isbn=0534605931|year=2005|page=310|accessdate=May 10, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=evrfDR09mDsC&pg=PA310|quote=The term ''photographic memory'' is more often used to describe eidetic imagery.}}

'''4.''' {{cite web|last=Foer|first=Joshua|title=The accused Harvard plagiarist doesn't have a photographic memory. No one does.|date=April 27, 2006|accessdate=May 11, 2016|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/health_and_science/science/2006/04/kaavya_syndrome.single.html|quote=Lots of people claim to have a photographic memory, but nobody actually does. Nobody. [...] That's  not to say there aren't people with extraordinarily good memories—there are. They just can't take mental snapshots and recall them with perfect fidelity. [...] Photographic memory is often confused with another bizarre—but real—perceptual phenomenon called eidetic memory, which occurs in between 2 and 15 percent of children and very rarely in adults. An eidetic image is essentially a vivid afterimage that lingers in the mind's eye for up to a few minutes before fading away. Children with eidetic memory never have anything close to perfect recall, and they typically aren't able to visualize anything as detailed as a body of text.}}

'''5.''' {{cite book|authors=Robert McEntarffer, Allyson Weseley|title=AP Psychology|publisher=[[Barron's Educational Series]]|isbn=0764136658|year=2007|page=106|accessdate=May 11, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=duaDqRwKZhcC&pg=PA106|quote=Memory researchers are particularly interested in individuals who demonstrate eidetic, or photographic, memory. [...] Some people say they have a photographic memory when what they mean is a very good memory. True eidetic memory occurs very rarely.}}

'''6.''' {{cite book|authors=Dennis Coon, John O. Mitterer|title=Introduction to Psychology: Gateways to Mind and Behavior|publisher=[[Cengage Learning]]|isbn=0495599115|year=2008|page=273|accessdate=May 11, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vw20LEaJe10C&pg=PA273|quote=The term 'photographic memory' is more often used to describe a memory ability called eidetic imagery. Eidetic imagery occurs when a person has visual images clear enough to be 'scanned' or retained for at least 30 seconds.}}

'''7.''' {{cite book|authors=Carol Turkington, Joseph Harris|title=The Encyclopedia of the Brain and Brain Disorders|publisher=[[Infobase Publishing]]|isbn=1438127030|year=2010|page=128|accessdate=May 11, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6hbKkynRxPYC&pg=PA128|quote=Most experts suspect that eidetic imagery is not a different kind of visual memory, but just a greater skill in the ability to form visual images that everyone possesses to some degree. While eidetic imagery is most likely the source of the concept of a photographic memory, there are differences in the two concepts. An eidetic image fades soon after one sees the original image and does not stay with a person over time. The image is subjective, and the details of greatest interest to the person are the ones most easily reproduced. Moreover, a person cannot form an eidetic image in one second, as a camera can snap a photo; several seconds are required to scan the picture. Once the picture has faded away, eidetic images cannot be retrieved. Those who can form eidetic images do not seem to be able to use their special ability to improve long-term memory.}}

'''8.''' {{cite web|last=Gordon|first=Barry|title=Does Photographic Memory Exist?|date=January 1, 2013|accessdate=May 11, 2016|work=[[Scientific American]]|url=http://www.scientificamerican.com/article/i-developed-what-appears-to-be-a-ph/|quote=The intuitive notion of a 'photographic' memory is that it is just like a photograph: you can retrieve it from your memory at will and examine it in detail, zooming in on different parts. But a true photographic memory in this sense has never been proved to exist. Most of us do have a kind of photographic memory, in that most people's memory for visual material is much better and more detailed than our recall of most other kinds of material. For instance, most of us remember a face much more easily than the name associated with that face. But this isn't really a photographic memory; it just shows us the normal difference between types of memory.}}

'''9.''' {{cite book|author=Annette Kujawski Taylor|title=Encyclopedia of Human Memory [3 volumes]|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|isbn=144080026X|year=2013|page=951|accessdate=May 10, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VevXAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA951|quote=Eidetic memory is sometimes called photographic memory because individuals who possess eidetic memory can reproduce information from memory in exactly the format in which it was provided during encoding.}}

'''10.''' {{cite book|author=Bennett L. Schwartz|title=Memory: Foundations and Applications|publisher=[[Sage Publications]]|isbn=1483323269|year=2013|page=172|accessdate=May 11, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wb4gAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA172|quote=It is likely that those who claim to possess 'photographic memory' (or eidetic imagery, in technical terms) do have extraodinarily good visual imagery systems that allow them to form strong visual images of the material that they learn.}}

'''11.''' {{cite book|authors=Minna Lyons, Neil Harrison, Gayle Brewer, Sarita Robinson, Rob Sanders|title=
Biological Psychology|publisher=[[Learning Matters]]|isbn=0857256947|year=2014|page=140|accessdate=May 11, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2LS9AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT140|quote=Eidetic memory [...] This type of memory refers to occasions when people claim to be able to recall a very detailed visual image for a long period of time. This type of memory is commonly known as photographic memory and is very rare (with some researchers claiming that eidetic memories do not exist at all).}}

'''12.''' {{cite book|authors=Scott Lilienfeld, Steven Jay Lynn, Laura Namy, Nancy Woolf, Graham Jamieson, Anthony Marks, Virginia Slaughter|title=Psychology: From Inquiry to Understanding|publisher=[[Pearson Higher Education]]|isbn=1486016405|year=2014|page=353|accessdate=May 10, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7dSaBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA267|quote=
Iconic memory may help to explain the remarkable phenomenon of eidetic imagery, popularly called 'photographic memory'.}}

'''13.''' {{cite book|author=Anthony Simola|title=The Roving Mind: A Modern Approach to Cognitive Enhancement|publisher=ST Press|isbn=069240905X|year=2015|page=117|accessdate=May 10, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p4ZMBwAAQBAJ&pg=PT117|quote=[...] Photographic memory or eidetic memory, as it is more accurately called. It refers to the ability to recall memories in vivid visual detail without the use of mnemonic techniques. Importantly though, eidetic memory differs from what is commonly thought to be photographic memory in the respect that eidetic memory literally refers to one's ability to view memories like photographs. In popular culture, photographic memory simply refers to the ability to recall items like pages of text or numbers in great detail without the visualization associated with eidetic memory. Sometimes found in children but rarely in adults, photographic memory has an aura of mystery to it, and to most people it sounds almost like a supernatural ability. The incredible claims surrounding eidetic memory arouse high emotions in the public, which remains predominantly skeptical of its existence.}}

'''14.''' {{cite book|author=S. Marc Breedlove|title=Principles of Psychology|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=0199329362|year=2015|page=353|accessdate=May 10, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oKzfCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA353|quote=If a person had iconic memory that did not fade with time, he or she would have what is sometimes called photographic memory (also called eidetic memory), the ability to recall entire images with extreme detail.}}

{{collapse bottom}} 
[[User:Flyer22 Reborn|Flyer22 Reborn]] ([[User talk:Flyer22 Reborn|talk]]) 04:09, 12 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Arab–Israeli conflict#rfc_26C26BE|Talk:Arab–Israeli conflict]] expired 2016-06-11 22:01 ===
* Id: 26C26BE
* User: Oncenawhile
* Date: 2016-05-12 20:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|719959203|HIST 719959203}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|724845048|HIST 724845048}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per [[Wikipedia:Summary_style#Rationale]], for major topics Wikipedia should ''"distribute information across related articles in a way that can serve readers who want varying amounts of details, thus giving readers the ability to zoom to the level of details they need and not exhausting those who need a primer on a whole topic"''. It goes on to discuss the parent-child article structure. I have tried in different ways to get the community focused on this question for the huge and complex Israel-Palestine topic, but I have continually failed to get a proper discussion going, probably because I have been asking the wrong question. Here is another attempt, with a hopefully better question.

Please could editors comment as to whether you believe that this article should be the overall parent article of the whole conflict, which began in 1917 or 1920 depending which scholar you look at. Proposed options below:
* '''Yes, this article should be the parent article of the whole conflict'''
* '''No, the parent is at another article''' 
* '''No, we don't need a parent article; the split of three top articles is fine'''

[[User:Oncenawhile|Oncenawhile]] ([[User talk:Oncenawhile|talk]]) 20:10, 12 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Battle of Ia Drang#rfc_08EB42E|Talk:Battle of Ia Drang]] expired 2016-06-12 08:01 ===
* Id: 08EB42E

* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|724433552|HIST 724433552}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I was under the impression that the following sentence was [[WP:SYNTH]] (and another editor thought it was [[WP:OR]]) because it implies that the air action of the Pleiku Campaign was more significant than the ground action of the Battle of Ia Drang without the sources making that claim, or that it violates [[WP:N]] by challenging the significance of this battle; I also feel that the comparison being made is between two things that aren't easily compared, so I don't think the comparison needs to be made in this article at all:
<blockquote>"The air action spent more times,[68] operated in a wider areas,[69] committed more units[70] and attacked more enemy forces,[71] than the ground action."</blockquote>
The editor that wrote this sentence claims that it is a statement of facts that're reliably sourced, and that the comparison is [[WP:BLUE]]. Does this sentence violate any policy or guideline, need rewording, or need removal? '''[[User:Sturmgewehr88|<span style="background:black"><span style="color:red">ミーラー強斗武</span></span>]]''' ([[User_talk:Sturmgewehr88|StG88ぬ会話]]) 05:29, 9 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Proposed deletion#rfc_8E117E4|Wikipedia talk:Proposed deletion]] expired 2016-06-13 07:01 ===
* Id: 8E117E4
* User: Jytdog
* Date: 2016-06-13 00:28:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|725037759|POLICY 725037759}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|725049280|POLICY 725049280}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The lead already says: "A nominated article is marked for at least seven days; if nobody objects, it is considered by an uninvolved admin, who reviews the article and may delete it or may remove the PROD tag. "

To make the rest of the policy consistent with that, the following changes are proposed:

* In the lead:

<blockquote>;There are three steps to the PROD process:
# To nominate an article, place the {{tlxs|Proposed deletion|2=concern=''reason for proposed deletion''}} tag on the page. This is automatically converted to a {{tlx|proposed deletion/dated}} which lists the article in [[:Category:Proposed deletion]]. You should notify the article's creator or other significant contributors by adding the {{Tlsp|Proposed deletion notify|''Name of Article‎''}} tag or other appropriate text to contributor talk pages.
# If anybody objects to the deletion (usually by removing the {{tlx|proposed deletion/dated}} tag—see full instructions below) <u>within seven days of the PROD tag being placed</u>, the proposal is aborted and may not be re-proposed.
# The article is first checked and then deleted by an administrator seven days after nomination (or any time after seven days that an administrator reviews the article). It may be [[Wikipedia:Requests for undeletion|undeleted upon request]]. If the reviewing administrator does not agree with the deletion they may remove the PROD tag instead of deleting the article.</blockquote>

* In the "Objecting" section (with notes removed only to reduce clutter)<br>

<blockquote>'''To object to and therefore permanently prevent a proposed deletion <u>during the seven days after the PROD tag has been placed</u>''',remove the {{tlx|proposed deletion/dated}} tag from the article. You are encouraged, but not required, to also:
# Explain why you disagree with the proposed deletion, either in the edit summary or on the talk page.
# Consider notifying the editors involved in the PROD by placing a {{tl|Deprod}} tag on their user talk page.
# Add or modify an {{tl|Old prod full}} tag on the article's talk page, to prevent renomination under Proposed deletion. It will then be listed at [[:Category:Past proposed deletion candidates]] for easy tracking.
# Consider improving the article to address the concerns raised.</blockquote>

<blockquote>'''If anyone, including the article creator, removes a {{tlx|proposed deletion/dated}} tag from an article <u>during the seven days after the PROD tag was placed</u>, do not replace it,''' even if the tag was apparently removed in [[WP:ABF|bad faith]]. This excludes removals that are clearly not an objection to deletion, such as page blanking or obvious vandalism, and tags removed by [[WP:Banning policy|banned users]] may be restored. If you still believe that the article needs to be deleted, or that the article should be deleted but with discussion, list it on [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion]].</blockquote>

-- [[User:Jytdog|Jytdog]] ([[User talk:Jytdog|talk]]) 00:28, 13 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_D0D4C97|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2016-06-14 03:01 ===
* Id: D0D4C97
* User: Hungryce
* Date: 2016-06-02 02:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|723276118|SCI 723276118}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|723276121|STYLE 723276121}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|723276122|POLICY 723276122}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|723276125|TECH 723276125}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|723276126|PROP 723276126}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|725184750|SCI 725184750}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|725184753|STYLE 725184753}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|725184754|POLICY 725184754}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|725184755|TECH 725184755}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|725184756|PROP 725184756}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In MathML with SVG and PNG fallback we got the problem in [[phab:T136688]] and [[phab:T136685]]. This mode is entabled by default because of [[phab:T131177]]. Currently this causes [[phab:T136688]], [[phab:T136685]], [[phab:T136672]] and [[phab:T136709]]. While other workarounds are yet to be found the solution to [[phab:T136688]] and [[phab:T136685]] it will probably be solved by repacing all instances of <nowiki>[h] in TeX/LaTeX (and in MathJax) with [tcb] as [h] is not a valid tag and was seen by the PNG rendering mode as [tcb] but now causes an error in the new mode</nowiki>. I propose that some sort of bot or AWB script is written to automaticaly or semi-automaticaly replace <nowiki>[h] in TeX/LaTeX (and in MathJax) with [tcb]</nowiki> to fix this problem as this was already accepted as the correct solution (pending actual code workarounds) at [[phab:T136685#2345546]].

For those of you who don't understand what I said above it was decided ([[phab:T136685#2345546]]) that a small edit-a-thon is necessary to replace <nowiki>[h] with [tcb]</nowiki> in some cases. This RFC is to decide whether or not to do that. [[User:Hungryce|Hungryce]] ([[User talk:Hungryce|talk]]) 02:59, 2 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:In the news/2016 RD proposal#rfc_B48B21C|Wikipedia talk:In the news/2016 RD proposal]] expired 2016-06-14 15:01 ===
* Id: B48B21C
* User: Fuebaey
* Date: 2016-05-25 15:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|725258425|PROP 725258425}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is currently a trial at [[WP:In the news|in the news]], affecting the criteria for recent deaths (RD). This has been in place since 9th May and runs until 9th June. During this period, RD nominations made to [[Wikipedia:In the news/Candidates]] no longer take into account significance and are judged solely on article quality. Any comments or suggestions are welcome. [[Special:Contributions/Fuebaey|Fuebaey]] ([[User talk:Fuebaey|talk]]) 15:18, 25 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_59CC560|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2016-06-14 21:01 ===
* Id: 59CC560
* User: Mandruss
* Date: 2016-06-02 19:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|723393924|BIO 723393924}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|723393929|HIST 723393929}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|723393942|POLICY 723393942}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|728046538|BIO 728046538}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|728046541|HIST 728046541}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|728046547|POLICY 728046547}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In the second paragraph at [[WP:BIO1E]], the assassination that led to the start of World War I is given as an example (and the only example) of a "highly significant" event. To me, this suggests that the appropriate bar is whether the event is covered in, or can reasonably expected to be covered in,  history books. Others prefer a lower bar, especially for more recent events, that requires only extensive RS coverage and a subjective assessment of the event's impact—an assessment which often takes a short-term view. They would include events that very likely <u>will not</u> be covered in history books. Should the guideline be modified to clarify this point? If so, how? &#8213;[[User:Mandruss|<span style="color:#775C57;">'''''Mandruss'''''</span>]]&nbsp;[[User talk:Mandruss|<span style="color:#AAA;">&#9742;</span>]] 19:07, 2 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_9DF6092|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2016-06-14 21:01 ===
* Id: 9DF6092
* User: Curly Turkey
* Date: 2016-05-15 20:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|721515182|POLICY 721515182}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|721515183|PROJ 721515183}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|721515185|TECH 721515185}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|725304489|POLICY 725304489}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|725304492|PROJ 725304492}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|725304495|TECH 725304495}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In 2013 [[Wikipedia:Requests for comment/Wikidata Phase 2]] determined "to permit Wikidata inclusion when there is no existing English Wikipedia data for a specific field in the infobox".  This has been interpreted so that
* such data will be included in Infoboxes by default if such data exists, and it will be included silently, without any notice on people's watchlists.
* such data can be excluded only by including an empty parameter: e.g. {{para|isbn}}.  If the parameter is ''absent'' (rather than ''empty''), inclusion of WikiData will still happen automatically.

Some editors have brought up issues with [[WP:WD|Wikidata]] in infoboxes being included in this way. Should such inclusions continue to be "opt-out"?

'''Note''': This discussion is not about whether we should use WikiData, but about how such data should be imported.  If you issues with WikiData itself, that should be a separate discussion. [[User:Curly Turkey|Curly&nbsp;Turkey]]&nbsp;<span style="color:red">🍁</span>&nbsp;[[User talk:Curly Turkey|''¡gobble!'']] 20:59, 15 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Medicine#rfc_73102A7|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Medicine]] expired 2016-06-15 00:01 ===
* Id: 73102A7
* User: Doc James
* Date: 2016-05-15 22:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|721515170|SCI 721515170}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|725323959|SCI 725323959}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have been including pricing information in medication articles. We have a good source [http://erc.msh.org/dmpguide/resultsdetail.cfm?language=english&code=SAL01D&s_year=2014&year=2014&str=100%20mcg%2Fdose&desc=Salbutamol&pack=new&frm=INHALER&rte=INH&class_code2=&supplement=&class_name=%28%29%3Cbr%3E here] that gives the price range found internationally and in a number of countries in the developing world. Often the variation between prices is less than 5 fold. I have also been providing the US price as presented in [https://www.amazon.ca/Tarascon-Pharmacopoeia-2015-Professional-Reference/dp/1284075087/ref=sr_1_7?ie=UTF8&qid=1463352135&sr=8-7&keywords=tarascon+pharmacopoeia this book] but there are other good options. The US is not only a large portion of the EN speaking population but a large percentage of our readership. Also most other countries are somewhere between the global price and the US price. [[User:Doc James|<span style="color:#0000f1">'''Doc James'''</span>]] ([[User talk:Doc James|talk]] · [[Special:Contributions/Doc James|contribs]] · [[Special:EmailUser/Doc James|email]]) 22:44, 15 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Comics#rfc_BC56B6D|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Comics]] expired 2016-06-15 16:01 ===
* Id: BC56B6D
* User: Argento Surfer#Adam Warlock
* Date: 2016-05-17 23:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|721522935|MEDIA 721522935}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|725427482|MEDIA 725427482}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This has [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Adam_Warlock&type=revision&diff=537975092&oldid=537949399 come up before], but [[User:Arionapollo]] has brought this up on [[User talk:Argento Surfer#Adam Warlock|my talk page]] and I thought I'd invite more voices to the table since this could apply to other characters as well.

Basically, the [[Adam Warlock]] publication history currently says "The character debuted in Fantastic Four #66-67 ... [and had] a second appearance as "Him" in Thor #165-166" Arionapollo, citing CGC and Overstreet, [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Adam_Warlock&type=revision&diff=719894035&oldid=719888695 wants to note] the ''Fantastic Four'' issues are a cameo, and specify the character's "first full appearance" as the ''Thor'' issues. However, 
* The FF issues present his origin in full. 
* Old ''Wizard'' magazines note that FF 66 is a cameo, and FF67 is the first appearance. 
* Marvel says his first appearance was [http://marvel.com/universe/Warlock,_Adam FF 66]. 
* There was a 2 year gap between the FF and Thor stories. 

I think the current wording is sufficiently generic, and avoids making a judgment on what's a cameo and what's a true first appearance. Google [https://www.google.com/?gws_rd=ssl#q=adam+warlock+first+appearance+thor+165 provides some additional support] for the Thor books, but all the top hits are from sites promoting the book for its sale value. 

[[Venom (comics)]] gives his first appearance as ASM #300, and specifies in the publication history he appeared in cameo on the last page of #299. 
[[Apocalypse (comics)]] gives his first appearance as X-Factor #5 in the lead, and the infobox specifies #5 was "in shadow" and #6 was "first full appearance". 
The lead and PH of [[Wolverine (character)]] mentions Hulk 180 as his "first appearance" and Hulk 181 as his "first full appearance". The infobox has Hulk 180 listed as a cameo.

# Should the publication history section or infobox distinguish between cameos and first appearances?
# Is this disagreement significant enough to discuss within the article?
[[User:Argento Surfer|Argento Surfer]] ([[User talk:Argento Surfer|talk]]) 23:33, 17 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_2B391AE|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2016-06-17 00:01 ===
* Id: 2B391AE
* User: Music1201
* Date: 2016-06-16 22:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|725637934|POLICY 725637934}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|725637939|PROP 725637939}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|725644909|POLICY 725644909}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|725644911|PROP 725644911}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It's ridiculous that most experienced editors avoid requesting adminship because they don't want to go through the RfA process. After [[Wikipedia:RFA reform|5 reforms]], no ''major'' changes have been made. I think with a final RfA reform, the process should be completely recreated. Something i'm proposing is the creation of "RfA guidelines", where certain topics cannot be discussed in the RfA (edit count, incidents that occurred 8 years ago, etc.) I think with a new RfA reform, the number of sysops will increase significantly. Additionally, i'm proposing that [[WP:RECALL]] be promoted to policy and be required for all sysops, making it easier for administrators to be desysopped. <span style="font-family:sans-serif; color:red">&mdash; <span style="font-weight:bold">[[User:Music1201|<span style="color:green"> Music1201</span>]] <sup>[[User talk:Music1201|<span style="color:red">talk</span>]]</sup></span></span> 22:40, 16 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:United States presidential election, 2016#rfc_C3F2941|Talk:United States presidential election, 2016]] expired 2016-06-17 04:01 ===
* Id: C3F2941
* User: Proud User
* Date: 2016-05-29 23:21:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|722755711|POL 722755711}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|725668276|POL 725668276}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There seems to be dispute among editors wether or not a given candidate is a "presumptive nominee." For example, a lot of editors think that [[Gary Johnson]] or [[Jill Stein]] should be considered the presumptive nominee of their party, others disagree. I think it would be helpful to reach a consensus on what makes someone a presumptive nominee. 

First, I would like to point out what [[presumptive nominee|our article on presumptive nominees]] says: "a candidate becomes the presumptive nominee of his or her party when his or her last serious challenger drops out or when he or she mathematically clinches—whichever comes first." My interpretation of what this is saying would imply that, for someone to be the presumptive nominee, one of these two things must be:
#He or she has no challenger from his/her same party that is featured in a major poll.
#He/she has obtained 50% or more of his or her party's delegates.
The above seems pretty reasonable to me. However, some editors seem to think differently; they think that a major news agency has to announce him/her the presumptive nominee of their party before Wikipedia does. This disagreement could affect at what point in time should we call [[Hillary Clinton]] the presumptive Democratic nominee, or wether [[Jill Stein]] ''is'' currently the presumptive nominee for the Green Party.

I think it would be helpful for this election and future elections for Wikipedia to have a consensus on what makes a candidate the "presumptive nominee" of their party. --[[User:Proud User|Proud User]] ([[User talk:Proud User|talk]]) 23:21, 29 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:IP block exemption#rfc_BB87800|Wikipedia talk:IP block exemption]] expired 2016-06-22 17:01 ===
* Id: BB87800
* User: Saizai
* Date: 2016-05-24 18:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|721900558|POLICY 721900558}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|726509719|POLICY 726509719}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 

Proposal: [[WP:IPBE]] shall be granted, <s>for any given language wiki</s> ''on WP/EN'':
# with sufficient scope to permit Tor and VPN use (e.g. local IPBE),
# automatically (to the extent wikimedia admin software allows — preferably requiring zero user action, or on a bot-automated "click here to get your IPBE" type basis if not), and
# to any user who demonstrates '''any one''' of the following proofs of work:
## an edit history of sufficient length to show that the user is most likely acting in good faith, i.e. not a [[WP:ILLEGIT]] violator (e.g. ≥10 substantive edits over the course of ≥1 month)
## human effort sufficient to dissuade sockpuppetry (e.g. emailing stewards such that they would notice if multiple requests are from the same human or from a bot)
## computational effort sufficient to dissuade sockpuppetry (e.g. Javascript cryptographic task demonstrating ≥4 hours of computational time on an average home computer).

Any IPBE expiration shall be renewed on the same basis.

In particular, as a change to current policy, IPBE shall '''not''' require '''any''' justification, showing of special need, unusual circumstances, etc. To the extent possible, curtailed '''only''' by actual needs to prevent sockpuppetry or automation, IPBE shall be given '''presumptively''', just like HTTPS. [[User:saizai|Sai]]&nbsp;<span style="font-size:x-small;vertical-align:super;">[[User_talk:saizai|¿?]]</span><span style="margin-left:-2ex;font-size:x-small;vertical-align:sub;">[[Special:Contributions/Saizai|✍]]</span> 18:30, 24 May 2016 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:IP block exemption#rfc_BB1487A|Wikipedia talk:IP block exemption]] expired 2016-06-22 17:01 ===
* Id: BB1487A
* User: ゼーロ
* Date: 2016-05-23 15:50:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|721716532|POLICY 721716532}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|726509719|POLICY 726509719}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Users with good standing (judged by the admin, based on having made a positive contribution over a considerable period of time) may requset an exemption on privacy/security grounds, without the need for further justification. [[User:ゼーロ|ゼーロ]] ([[User talk:ゼーロ|talk]]) 15:50, 23 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Politics of the United Kingdom#rfc_3DE4462|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Politics of the United Kingdom]] expired 2016-06-22 18:01 ===

I am starting a RfC to gather consensus on how the newly-renamed [[Executive Office (Northern Ireland)]] should be referred to.
