=== [[Talk:Jerusalem#rfc_E15D8FA|Talk:Jerusalem]] expired 2016-06-23 11:01 ===
* Id: E15D8FA
* User: Debresser
* Date: 2016-05-24 10:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|721839533|POL 721839533}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|726633929|POL 726633929}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Following the discussions at [[Talk:Birthright_Israel#Jerusalem.2C_Israel]] and [[User_talk:Debresser#1RR]] I want to open an Rfc about the question "Is Jerusalem in Israel or Palestine?"

After I reverted the removal of "Israel" from "Jerusalem, Israel" in a certain article, I was referred to [[Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Jerusalem]]. I noticed there that "There was no consensus for any phrasing of Jerusalem’s location in either Israel or Palestine." It does not say what to do. I also noticed that that Rfc was about the [[Jerusalem]] article only, and that it is binding for 3 years only, till July 9, 2016.

My first reaction was that in the absence of any clear consensus on this potentially controversial subject, the only acceptable course of action per Wikipedia policies and guidelines would be to refrain from changing any status quo. Then I cam to the realization that I could also initiate a process to try and establish a project wide consensus on this issue, some guideline on the issue, much like [[WP:WESTBANK]] regarding another related hot potato.

I then did some research. A simple search of Wikipedia teaches that there are 438 instances of "Jerusalem, Palestine" on Wikipedia and 9,268 of "Jerusalem, Israel". I came to the conclusion that that fact proves that both alternatives are considered completely acceptable on Wikipedia, and with a ratio of roughly 1:21 even makes a point for "Jerusalem, Israel" over "Jerusalem, Palestine". Also compare the Google search results, which are 331,000 to 5,950,000, roughly 1:18. I remember from my elementary school in Holland, that there never was any issue that Jerusalem is in Israel. Mind you, I am not talking about [[East Jerusalem]], the status of which is widely acknowledged as ambiguous, just simply "Jerusalem".

Then that same respected editor who pointed me to the Jerusalem Rfc, made another interesting point, namely that there is a difference between <nowiki>[[Jerusalem, Israel]] (or [[Jerusalem, Palestine]], for that matter) and [[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]] (or [[Jerusalem]], [[Palestine]])</nowiki>, with the latter being more problematic in his eyes.

I see four general options:
# Replace all instances of "Palestine" by "Israel" (unless specific reference was made to [[[East Jerusalem]]);
# Remove all instances of "Israel" and "Palestine" from after "Jerusalem";
# Keep all instances as they are. This means that no changes will be allowed to whatever is the present version. In the case of a new article, local consensus should decide;
# Refrain from making a guideline and leave it up to local consensus. This option might be rephrased, and I mean this non-judgemental, as keep the present anarchy.

In addition there is an idea that can be implemented independently of whichever of the above options will be chosen:
# Replace all <nowiki>[[Jerusalem]], [[Israel]] and [[Jerusalem]], [[Palestine]] by [[Jerusalem, Israel]] (or [[Jerusalem, Palestine]]</nowiki>, to address at least the most problematic form of this issue.

Please take part in the discussion below, and at the end also express your vote. Please note that I made no discussion section regarding the independent replacement option, because I expect the general discussion to cover this as well. [[User:Debresser|Debresser]] ([[User talk:Debresser|talk]]) 10:29, 24 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Falklands War#rfc_E7609AD|Talk:Falklands War]] expired 2016-06-23 21:01 ===
* Id: E7609AD
* User: Wee Curry Monster
* Date: 2016-05-24 20:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|721917902|HIST 721917902}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|726703874|HIST 726703874}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Falklands_War&type=revision&diff=721868899&oldid=721863210] Material claiming that a source of intelligence information was Russian satellite data intercepted by a Norwegian listening station has been included in the article.  I suggest there a number of problems with this:

1. It is only covered in media outlets, with reference to a single TV report and a report on the TV show itself; effectively the same source.  I cannot find reference to it in any other [[WP:SECONDARY]] source.  Whilst we can look to a media report as a source, this isn't encouraged where it is the only source of data.  We also look to other sources that are considered more reliable.  I would suggest the current reference is inadequate.

2. Coverage in this article is disproportionate, it certainly doesn't merit two paragraphs.

3. The sensationalist terms used in the edit are completely inappropriate, with the suggestion is was somehow "vital" and let the British know where the Argentine navy was at all times.  This contradicts just about every source known on the conflict, which details the problems the British had in locating the Argentine carrier.  In any case the Argentine fleet withdrew to port after the sinking of the Belgrano and played no role in the conflict.

It has been removed on this basis several times, on each occasion removal was reverted with the comment "it is cited" "disagree with removal" but as far as I can see these discrepancies have not been addressed.  I suggest that on the basis laid out above, this is very much [[WP:FRINGE]] material, the coverage here is disproportionate and it should be removed.  <span style="border:1px solid black;padding:1px;">[[User:Wee Curry Monster|W]][[Special:contributions/Wee Curry Monster|C]][[User talk:Wee Curry Monster|M]]</span><sub>[[Special:EmailUser/Wee Curry Monster|email]]</sub> 20:11, 24 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Trivia sections#rfc_740E326|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Trivia sections]] expired 2016-06-24 03:01 ===
* Id: 740E326
* User: BrightRoundCircle
* Date: 2016-06-13 15:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|725103501|POLICY 725103501}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|726744799|POLICY 726744799}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is [[User:BrightRoundCircle/sandbox/self-sourcing|established consensus]] that examples from popular culture are "not self-sourcing", that is, "'''The source(s) cited should not only establish the verifiability of the pop culture reference, but also its significance.'''" [[MOS:POPCULT]] "in popular culture" section currently suggests the cleanup of "unencyclopedically trivial" entries, but does not elaborate what they are. The article [[Wikipedia:"In_popular_culture"_content#Good_and_bad_popular_culture_references|"In popular culture"]] does elaborate on this, and makes it clear: "'''Although some references may be plainly verified by primary sources, this does not demonstrate the significance of the reference'''" and "'''[examples] should be reserved for major, in-depth treatments of the subject that have had lasting significance'''". Should the quoted text from the consensus of the RfC discussion and the "in popular culture" article be added to [[MOS:POPCULT]] for clarification of what is "unencyclopedically trivial"? [[User:BrightRoundCircle|BrightRoundCircle]] ([[User talk:BrightRoundCircle|talk]]) 15:25, 13 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Constitution of Medina#rfc_1E3F730|Talk:Constitution of Medina]] expired 2016-06-26 15:01 ===
* Id: 1E3F730
* User: Davidbena
* Date: 2016-05-27 14:08:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|722352551|HIST 722352551}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|727082750|HIST 727082750}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Although this article deals specifically with the "Constitution of Medina," it is my opinion that there is a place to mention, in passing, a similar pact or covenant made by Muhammad to the Jews living in Arabia, since it applies to the right of non-Muslims. 
The most appropriate place to add this small note is in the sub-section, "Rights of Non-Muslims," directly after the bullet which reads:
#Non-Muslims will not be obliged to take part in religious wars of the Muslims.
The edit which we are suggesting would read as follows:

:"In Yemenite Jewish sources, subsequent to the Constitution of Medina, another treaty was drafted between Muhammad and his Jewish subjects, known as ''kitāb ḏimmat al-nabi'', written in the 17th year of the [[Hijri year|Hijra]] (638 CE), and which gave express liberty unto Jews living in Arabia to observe the Sabbath and to grow-out their side-locks, but were required to pay the [[jizya]] (poll-tax) annually for their protection by their patrons." 
This edit will be backed-up by a footnote which reads:
:"[[Shelomo Dov Goitein]], ''The Yemenites – History, Communal Organization, Spiritual Life'' (Selected Studies), editor: Menahem Ben-Sasson, Jerusalem 1983, pp. 288–299. ISBN 965-235-011-7."
If such an edit should be viewed by our fellow co-editors as informative in the general history of relations between non-Muslims, we will add the edit. Thanks in advance. [[User:Davidbena|Davidbena]] ([[User talk:Davidbena|talk]]) 14:08, 27 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Draft talk:Austin Petersen presidential campaign, 2016#rfc_0A2A3D7|Draft talk:Austin Petersen presidential campaign, 2016]] expired 2016-06-27 23:01 ===
* Id: 0A2A3D7
* User: Acidskater
* Date: 2016-05-28 22:48:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|722559030|POL 722559030}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|727282191|POL 727282191}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am requesting a comment on the notability of the following sources. I have been trying to establish notability for the Austin Petersen presidential campaign, 2016 and I believe the sources I have provided are reliable independent sources, most especially independent on the topic of Petersen or the Libertarian Party in general. I believe the sources show more than enough notability to qualify for [[WP:GNG]] but some users are claiming the sources are not enough as they claim the sources are not reliable. This is only a small list but I believe they are also disqualifying [[WP:NEXIST]] as there is a lot of other coverage including local coverage. While not all coverage is solely on the topic of Petersen's bid for presidency it does state in [[WP:GNG]] "Significant coverage is more than a trivial mention, but it does not need to be the main topic of the source material."

* [http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/mar/31/inside-the-beltway-gary-johnson-john-mcafee-austin/ Washington Times]
* [http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/may/24/inside-the-beltway-the-charm-of-a-pro-life-liberta/?page=all Washington Times]
* [http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/matalin-endorses-libertarian-for-president/article/2592239 Washington Examiner]
* [http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/the-surreal-presidential-debate-you-didnt-see-libertarians-in-las-vegas The New Yorker]
* [http://www.glennbeck.com/2016/05/20/libertarian-austin-petersen-makes-glenns-heart-skip-a-beat/ Glenn Beck]
* [http://www.glennbeck.com/2016/05/24/libertarian-austin-petersen-joins-glenn-and-makes-big-announcement/ Glenn Beck]
* [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Td4xlcFxeI Glenn Beck Show]
* [http://reason.com/blog/2016/05/25/austin-petersen-catches-more-endorsement Reason.com]
* [http://www.newsmax.com/Politics/Mary-Matalin-Endorses-Austin-Peterson-Libertarian/2016/05/24/id/730423/ Newsmax.com]
* [http://freebeacon.com/culture/want-vote-libertarian/ freebeacon.com]
* [http://uptownmessenger.com/2016/05/libertarian-presidential-candidate-to-make-campaign-stop-at-nola-brewing/ Uptown Messenger]
* [http://liveactionnews.org/pro-life-libertarian-candidate-austin-petersen-thinks-pro-lifers-want-tracking-bracelets-on-every-pregnant-woman/ Live Action News]
* [https://pjmedia.com/trending/2016/05/25/libertarian-presidential-candidate-austin-petersen-redeems-himself-on-the-glenn-beck-show/ PJ Media]
* [http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/27/politics/libertarianism-libertarian-party/index.html CNN]
* [https://www.facebook.com/plugins/video.php?href=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fcnnpolitics%2Fvideos%2F1159134954128336%2F&show_text=0&width=560 CNN]
* [https://www.facebook.com/NowThisElection/videos/1184371264927695/ NowThis Media]

I believe we are being asked to show an unreasonable amount of sources to show notability. As well [[User:MelanieN]] is indicating that all the sources I listed should never be considered reliable, something that [[WP:IRS]] says is an incorrect statement. Even more so I believe the users denying notability are relying on [[WP:BIO]] when in fact the topic of this page is his campaign, an organization separate to a page on Ausin Petersen himself, and thus requires the use of [[WP:ORG]] and [[WP:GNG]] to establish notability as a campaign is an organization. I believe this page was unreasonably speedily deleted as the page deserves a discussion of it's own on notability. Relevent discussion on the topic can be found above and [[User_talk:Ricky81682#Deletion_of_Austin_Petersen_presidential_campaign.2C_2016|here]]. [[User:Acidskater|Acidskater]] ([[User talk:Acidskater|talk]]) 22:48, 28 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Images#rfc_F775CD7|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Images]] expired 2016-06-28 06:01 ===
* Id: F775CD7
* User: DavidLeighEllis
* Date: 2016-05-29 04:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|722607437|POLICY 722607437}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|727321085|POLICY 727321085}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I would like to propose the repeal of the language in this guideline which forbids the inclusion of image galleries in articles about human ethnic groups. This would bring such articles into conformity with Wikipedia's general practice of attempting to include informative image(s) in articles wherever reasonably possible. Even articles about sub-species groupings directly analogous to human ethnic groups, such as [[Maine Coon]], include images of their subjects.

Possible counter-arguments:
#Classification of people on the basis of ethnic group is offensive. -> Please see [[WP:NOTCENSORED]].
#Where no reliable sources for classification of specific people on the basis of ethnic group can be found, such classifications constitute original research. -> The original research policy [[WP:OI|specifically allows]] the use of original images in articles, even when visual analysis of photo content forms the sole basis for concluding that photos depict their purported subject matter.
#Human ethnic groups have no biological, genetic, or other scientific basis. Therefore, there is no reasonable basis for classifying photos of people as depictions of such groups. -> This argument is flat out wrong, according to "Genetic structure, self-identified race/ethnicity, and confounding in case-control association studies" {{PMID|15625622}}. This particular paper qualifies as a secondary [[WP:RS]] since the authors aren't analyzing data they collected themselves. Note also the approval of [[isosorbide dinitrate/hydralazine]] by the FDA, which would have hardly occurred if human ethnicity were not a scientifically definable concept.
#The inherent uncertainty and changes over time in definitions of human ethnic groups creates a class of photos which may or may not depict a particular ethnic group. -> When depicting an ethnic group, we aim for the center, and not the edge.

Full disclosure:
I am opening a discussion about this issue in response to a dispute about whether [[Special:Permalink/680609377|a photo gallery for the White people article with the images I selected]] is appropriate for Wikipedia. [[User:DavidLeighEllis|DavidLeighEllis]] ([[User talk:DavidLeighEllis|talk]]) 04:06, 29 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Corina Abraham#rfc_5293647|Talk:Corina Abraham]] expired 2016-06-28 07:01 ===
* Id: 5293647
* User: Mitch Ames
* Date: 2016-05-29 06:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|722615600|BIO 722615600}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|722615605|POL 722615605}}

Should the "Opposition to Roe 8" section be shortened to the proposed new version? [[User:Mitch Ames|Mitch Ames]] ([[User talk:Mitch Ames|talk]]) 06:58, 29 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Hilton Worldwide#rfc_C26FE8C|Talk:Hilton Worldwide]] expired 2016-06-28 18:01 ===
* Id: C26FE8C
* User: Inkian Jason
* Date: 2016-06-16 20:08:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|727386151|UNSORTED 727386151}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|727393133|UNSORTED 727393133}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
== Proposed changes to the article's lead '''

{{Edit request|a}}

I am submitting another request on behalf of Hilton Worldwide as part of my work for Beutler Ink. This request proposes 2 changes to the article's lead.

<hr>
{{Resolved}}

:1. I propose a slight wording change to improve flow, eliminate unnecessary detail (re: Chad), and update the number of rooms.

: Before: {{fontcolor|red|As of January 2016, Hilton Worldwide's portfolio includes 4,610 hotels with over 758,502 rooms. In January 2016, the opening of the Hilton in Chad marked the 100th country Hilton resides in, thus making the corporation the largest hotel chain in the world by rooms and international presence.}}

: After: {{fontcolor|green|As of March 2016, Hilton Worldwide's portfolio includes more than 4,660 properties with over 765,000 rooms in more than 100 countries, making the corporation the largest hotel chain in the world by rooms and international presence.}}

: Source: [http://news.hiltonworldwide.com/index.cfm/news/responding-to-popular-demand-hilton-taps-google-maps-to-help-hhonors-members-see-more-when-choosing-their-room Hilton Worldwide]
: Formatted reference: <nowiki><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.hiltonworldwide.com/index.cfm/news/responding-to-popular-demand-hilton-taps-google-maps-to-help-hhonors-members-see-more-when-choosing-their-room|title=Responding to Popular Demand, Hilton Taps Google Maps to Help HHonors Members See More When Choosing Their Room|date=May 11, 2016|accessdate=June 15, 2016|publisher=Hilton Worldwide}}</ref></nowiki>

<hr>
{{Resolved}}
:2. Currently, the article's lead says, "The company has been a sponsor of the United States Olympic Team since 2005." This is no longer true. I propose changing the tense, since the company is no longer a sponsor, and moving the sentence from the lead to the article's [[Hilton Worldwide#History|History]] section. This past sponsorship does not seem like something worth mentioning in the lead.

<hr>
Thanks again for your consideration. I am happy to address any questions or concerns reviewers may have about these proposed changes. [[User:Inkian Jason|Inkian Jason]] ([[User talk:Inkian Jason|talk]]) 20:08, 16 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Courtesy vanishing#rfc_395998D|Wikipedia talk:Courtesy vanishing]] expired 2016-06-29 02:01 ===
* Id: 395998D
* User: Izkala
* Date: 2016-05-30 01:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|722774374|POLICY 722774374}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|727448061|POLICY 727448061}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the last paragraph of the lead be shortened to "'''it is not possible to ''delete'' an account'''."?

''' Reasoning '''

Currently, the last paragraph of the lead reads:

: Due to all contributions being licensed under the [[Wikipedia:Text of Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License|CC BY-SA 3.0 License]] and the [[Wikipedia:Text of the GNU Free Documentation License|GFDL]], '''it is not possible to ''delete'' an account'''.

This is disingenuous.  These licenses set out no such requirements.  If we're to put aside community norms for a minute, the reason for not being able to delete accounts is technical; as anybody who's had their username changed would know, the software allows for accounts to be created under a previously-held username.  The theory is, if we were to delete somebody's account, somebody else could register under the same name and assume authorship of the departed user's edits.  There's ways to get around this, but none have been pursued for different reasons; foremost is the community's obsession with requiring editors to identify with only one handle - an obsession that is borne of misguided notions of professionalism.  In any case, I suggest condensing the paragraph down to...

: '''it is not possible to ''delete'' an account'''.

... which is strictly factual.  Izkala ([[User talk:Izkala|talk]]) 01:13, 30 May 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers#rfc_FCB933E|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers]] expired 2016-06-29 14:01 ===
* Id: FCB933E
* User: Crumpled Fire
* Date: 2016-06-29 08:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|727487318|POLICY 727487318}}
* RFC Text:

A short discussion was [[Wikipedia_talk:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#WP:DATERANGE_again|initially had above]] (the latest of many which went nowhere) regarding the re-introduction of the four-digit endrange year in [[WP:DATERANGE]]. When some support was garnered but discussion again stalled, it was then [[Wikipedia:Village_pump_(policy)#WP:DATERANGE_ambiguity_and_stylistic_concerns|expanded to a discussion and !vote at the Village Pump]], garnering a high level of agree !votes to return to the original style of allowing—or even preferring—four-digit end years (''i.e. 2000–2016'') instead of the current two-digit end years (''i.e. 2000–16'') for ranges that occur post-11th century and within the same century. 
In addition to the support garnered at the Village Pump, it's becoming clear to me that the general editing public (and likely the general public itself) finds the 2000–16 format disagreeable, as I've already had to revert '''three instances''' ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Anton_Yelchin&diff=prev&oldid=727482362],[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Anton_Yelchin&diff=prev&oldid=726247993],[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Anton_Yelchin&diff=prev&oldid=726090890]) within the last few days of someone changing "2000–16" to "2000–2016" in the infobox for [[Anton Yelchin]] (a high-traffic article due to the subject's recent death). As suggested by a user at the Village Pump discussion, I am opening an RfC to hopefully determine once and for all whether the community at large agrees it's time to re-introduce four-digit end years in ranges. — '''[[User talk:Crumpled Fire|<font face="Lucida Fax"><font color="#2695A9">Crumpled Fire</font></font>]]'''<small> • ''[[Special:Contributions/Crumpled Fire|contribs]]'' •</small> 08:26, 29 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Harassment#rfc_17B5EE6|Wikipedia talk:Harassment]] expired 2016-07-01 21:01 ===
* Id: 17B5EE6
* User: Doc James
* Date: 2016-06-30 18:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|727713998|POLICY 727713998}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|732264107|POLICY 732264107}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This article has contained the follow text for a fair amount of time "Posting links to other accounts on other websites may be allowable on a case-by-case basis."

With respect to providing links, one reason to do this would be: 

a) someone posts a job offer money for article X on Elance

b) an editor notifies [[WT:COIN]] of that fact and provides the Elance link as proof, people than watch the article that does not yet exist 

c) someone on Elance wins the job, creates a new Wikipedia account, and than creates the article. 

This is something which is done on a regular basis such as in this example [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Conflict_of_interest/Noticeboard&oldid=679657047#Checking_Elance here]. [[User:Doc James|<span style="color:#0000f1">'''Doc James'''</span>]] ([[User talk:Doc James|talk]] · [[Special:Contributions/Doc James|contribs]] · [[Special:EmailUser/Doc James|email]]) 18:54, 30 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Aviation/Style guide/Lists#rfc_05E6547|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Aviation/Style guide/Lists]] expired 2016-07-02 08:01 ===
* Id: 05E6547
* Date: 2016-06-02 07:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|723306075|SCI 723306075}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|727968748|SCI 727968748}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Consensus has been for some time that in general, lists of many aircraft types do not include the numbers built for each type. Two editors in particular have now challenged that in the case of lists for aircraft types in a given role. There appear to be three possible ways forward:
#Maintain the broad consensus that production numbers should not be listed.
#Change the broad consensus, to add production numbers to all lists of aircraft in table form.
#Make an exception for role-based lists of aircraft.
(An exception has been agreed for the numbers ''in service'' in lists for a given operator, but that is a different number with a particular rationale).

&mdash; Cheers, [[User:Steelpillow|Steelpillow]] ([[User Talk:Steelpillow|Talk]]) 07:54, 2 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Cary Grant#rfc_1973DA5|Talk:Cary Grant]] expired 2016-07-02 14:01 ===

Should the section on Grant's "Sexuality" contain:

{{quotebox|William McBrien, in his biography ''Cole Porter'', claim that [[Cole Porter|Porter]] and Grant frequented the same upscale house of male prostitution in Harlem, run by Clint Moore and popular with celebrities,{{sfn|McBrien|2000|p=129}} Grant lived with actor [[Randolph Scott]] off and on for 12 years,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.advocate.com/news/2009/01/05/paper-trail-great-american-couple?page=0,0|title=Paper Trail: Great American Couple|work=[[The Advocate]]|date=January 5, 2009|accessdate=June 8, 2012}}</ref> which led to rumors. -- [[User:Collect|Collect]] ([[User talk:Collect|talk]]) 12:37, 2 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_FB10353|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2016-07-02 20:01 ===
* Id: FB10353
* User: Crumpled Fire
* Date: 2016-06-18 00:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|727617410|POLICY 727617410}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|730289998|POLICY 730289998}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I recently initiated [[Wikipedia_talk:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#WP:DATERANGE_again|a discussion]] regarding [[WP:DATERANGE]], the MoS guideline that specifies use of two-digit abbreviated years in end-ranges (i.e. 1995–99 instead of 1995–1999) for years from the 11th century onward only. Objections have been raised regarding this guideline before, and now again, with many agreeing with my reasoning for reverting to the old format, but it never proceeds any further. Here are several reasons why the current guideline should be abandoned and reverted:

* Date ranges under the current format can easily be confused for something else entirely, especially for ranges ending in years '01–'12. For example, "2010–12" can easily be interpreted as December 2010 instead of a date range of 2010–2012.
* It looks very unprofessional IMHO. Saving a measly two digits is not worth giving the appearance of using unnecessary shortcuts/slang in a respectable encyclopedia.
* It doesn't read naturally for years in the 21st century spanning the 2000s decade to 2010 or later. This is mainly because years from 2000–2009 are usually pronounced "two thousand and", while years from 2010—present are usually said as "twenty". So a range such as 2000–16 being read as "two thousand to sixteen" sounds ridiculous. This is especially problematic for anyone having Wikipedia read aloud by a text-to-speech program.
* Implementation is inconsistent, since it is only applicable to years 1000 AD+ and to none of the years in the BC era (why not?), leading to more confusion and unnecessary stylistic asymmetry.

I am looking to canvass the wider community to see if there is support to revert to the older style, which <s>preferred</s> permitted the entire 4-digit year for end-ranges. Please indicate whether you support the current MoS guideline or the previous one. — '''[[User talk:Crumpled Fire|<font face="Lucida Fax"><font color="#2695A9">Crumpled Fire</font></font>]]'''<small> • ''[[Special:Contributions/Crumpled Fire|contribs]]'' •</small> 00:43, 18 June 2016 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_AD61A60|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2016-07-02 23:01 ===
* Id: AD61A60
* User: 67.14.236.50
* Date: 2016-06-02 22:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|723418270|STYLE 723418270}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|723418274|POLICY 723418274}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|728065802|STYLE 728065802}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|728065803|POLICY 728065803}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{hatnote|1=There is some previous discussion at [[WP:Help desk#Style questions go where?]] ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Help_desk&oldid=723271969#Style_questions_go_where.3F permalink]).}}

If a video game has a “Game of the Year Edition,” or an album has a “Collector’s Edition,” or a movie has a “Director’s Cut” release, should the edition name be italicized as well (per [[MOS:T#Major works]])? Is “Game of the Year Edition” considered a partial title, part of the name of the major work, for instance ''Uncharted 3: Drake’s Deception: Game of the Year Edition''? (If so, should we also say “they released a ''Game of the Year Edition''”?) A brief internal search shows italics (and even capitalization) inconsistently applied to such labels, at least in video game articles:
*[[Call of Duty 2]] does not italicize “Special Edition” or “Game of the Year Edition,” and doesn’t even capitalize “a collector’s edition” or “the mobile version”.
*[[The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind]] italicizes “''Game of the Year Edition''” both with the game title (with and without a preceding colon) and on its own, but not “Special Edition Soundtrack.”
*[[Batman: Arkham Asylum]] has “Game of the Year edition” roman with a small E, but italicizes “a ''Collector’s Edition''.”

One of the goals of the Manual of Style is to encourage consistency across WIkipedia. To that end, should [[MOS:T#Major works]] be edited to address this? What should it say? —[[Special:Contributions/67.14.236.50|67.14.236.50]] ([[User talk:67.14.236.50|talk]]) 22:29, 2 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Elizabeth Warren#rfc_AA617D6|Talk:Elizabeth Warren]] expired 2016-07-03 02:01 ===
* Id: AA617D6
* User: Marteau
* Date: 2016-06-27 22:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|727287534|BIO 727287534}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|727287537|POL 727287537}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|727321085|POLICY 727321085}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|728084244|BIO 728084244}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|728084253|POL 728084253}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|728084258|POLICY 728084258}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How should Wikipedia cover the issue of Elizabeth Warren's native American heritage?  Currently, information pertaining to Warren's native American heritage is placed under the "2012 Election" heading in this article. Options which have been put forth before in this talk page include:

1. Leave the issue under the "2012 election"<br/>
2. Move the majority of coverage to the "2012 election" article, and leave a summary here<br/>
3. Create a new heading for the issue<br/>
4. Remove all coverage of the issue from Wikipedia

[[User:Marteau|Marteau]] ([[User talk:Marteau|talk]]) 22:36, 27 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Requests for page protection#rfc_4440FB9|Wikipedia talk:Requests for page protection]] expired 2016-07-03 04:01 ===
* Id: 4440FB9
* User: Xender Lourdes
* Date: 2016-06-03 03:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|723451773|POLICY 723451773}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|728093294|POLICY 728093294}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In the current page protection format, sometimes, urgent requests for BLPs' protection languish behind many normal protection requests. BLPs constitute some of the most critical issues faced by our project. Can we create a separate BLP section above the '''Current requests for increase in protection level'''? We could possibly title it '''Urgent requests for increase in protection level of BLPs'''. Opposes, supports, comments are all welcome. This is just a suggestion for ease of handling BLPs. Thanks for giving your time. [[User:Xender Lourdes|Xender Lourdes]] ([[User talk:Xender Lourdes|talk]]) 03:36, 3 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Isaac Barrow#rfc_BFF3B42|Talk:Isaac Barrow]] expired 2016-07-05 19:01 ===
* Id: BFF3B42
* User: 174.3.155.181
* Date: 2016-06-05 17:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|723852232|BIO 723852232}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|723852236|SCI 723852236}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|723852241|RELI 723852241}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|728483251|BIO 728483251}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|728483254|SCI 728483254}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|728483256|RELI 728483256}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hi,

[[User:Fountains of Bryn Mawr]] disagrees that [[James Gregory (mathematician)| James Gregory]] had influenced [[Isaac Barrow]], however I provided a very robust document that was a 1916 translation of his work, which clearly showed high praise for Gregory's work.
It seems this user is just against establishing this relationship for some reason. It shouldn't be a surprise that Barrow had respect for gregory, and was influenced by his work, yet Bryn Mawr just can't let it go. I provided sources, and they try to claim a translated document from over 100 years ago, showing mutual respect, is somehow original research. It is not original research at all. Calling "the most learned man" is one of the highest compliments a scholar could pay another when using their work. I'm seeking moderation because the user may risk violating the [[Wikipedia:Edit warring#The three-revert rule|3RR]], and I feel what I've provided is quite compelling. I would have to dig a little more, but I find a translated primary source document containing such a phrase as the most compelling piece of evidence. Secondary accounts often are less convincing. <br>Here is some secondary analysis showing the impact of Gregory's work. Secondary analysis such as [http://physics.ucsc.edu/~michael/barrowleibniz15.pdf] (page 4, footnote 11) also refers to the quote I've used, but builds on it slightly more by also mentioning [[Gottfried Leibniz]]' praise of Gregory's work. So we can see that the work of Gregory impressed both Leibniz and Barrow. To suggest such esteemed scholars (of almost 400 years ago) use phrases like "the most learned man" or "elegant theorem by Gregory" (quite the compliments) without being influenced by them (where such influence is in the form of using their work, at the very least) is unreasonable. I just do not know what the editor wants, and it feels like the evidence provided was sufficient. I will try to find more sources but I do not know how what is already provided isn't sufficient to constitute as evidence for influence.<br>
Here is a letter by a prominent publishing intermediary (between Gregory, Barrow, and Newton) John Collins addressed to Gregory [http://www-groups.dcs.st-and.ac.uk/history/Extras/Collins_Newton.html] While the letter itself is somewhat mundane (he met Sir Isaac, had dinner, Sir Isaac said [[Opticks]] was going to continue where Reverend Barrow left off, and that Collins needn't ask about Sir Isaac's publishing commitments because Reverend Barrow said the Lucasian chair had such requirements already), it establishes that, while communication was slow at the time, Collins was clearly acting as a facilitator. Thus, the work of Gregory clearly had an influence on Barrow given that the publisher was writing about their progress to the former. Trying to find more.<br>
Here is another secondary source, [http://gec.ncut.edu.tw/teacher/math/homepage/liu_pohong/teach_class2_download.php?sn=14 The Historical Development of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus And Its Implication in Teaching]: <blockquote>Apparently, Fermat reduced a problem of rectification by connecting tangents and
the question of quadratures. Surprisingly, for all his deft use of infinitesimals in a variety of areas, he still failed to recognize this critical relation, denying himself the honored title of “true inventor of the calculus” (Boyer, 1959). The man first overtly aware of generality of the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus was James Gregory in 1668, exerting a significant influence on Isaac Barrow’s work.</blockquote>
So I have to ask, why is [[Fountains of Bryn Mawr]] picking a fight over something that seems to be the consensus? Note: I am not talking about assigning priority/credit for the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus (which is clearly a bit more involved), but the '''influence''' of their investigations on eachother's work. Clearly assigning priority of the fundamental theorem is difficult because their collaboration (facilitated by Collins where appropriate) muddled the "who did what" part.<br>
Found probably the most definitive scholarly literature on this issue, however, again, I must emphasise that the focus of these scholars is much more than that:
<blockquote>
Barrow's heavy "borrowings" include his restatement of "Gregory's generalization of Wren's proof of a construction for the tangent at a general point on a cyclid arc," as well as his appropriation of Gregory's "rectifying transformation," the basis of the Scot's ''involutio'' and ''evolutio'' method. Even barrow's most famous achievement--the proof for the inverse nature of differentiation and integration--was now reinterpreted as a "neat amendment of Gregory's generalization of Neil's rectification method." - Mordechai Feingold<ref>{{cite journal| last=Feingold|first=Mordechai| url=https://keats.kcl.ac.uk/pluginfile.php/1346678/mod_resource/content/4/Feingold.pdf| title= Newton, Leibniz, and Barrow Too: An Attempt at a Reinterpretation | year=1993| volume=84|page=310-338|journal=[[Isis (journal)]]|publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]] on behalf of [[History of Science Society]]}}(page 332)</ref></blockquote>

If you dig further into that cited passage, you will find references to [[Tom Whiteside| DT Whiteside]]<ref>{{cite journal| last=Whiteside|first=Derek Thomas| title=Patterns of Mathematical Thought in the later Seventeenth Century| url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/pdf/41133216.pdf| doi=10.1007/BF00327940| journal= Archive for History of Exact Sciences | volume=1|issue=3|publisher=[[Springer]]|pages=179-388|year=1961}}</ref> who argues this line of thinking. However, again, we are not discussing ''priority'' of the fundamental theorem, nor are we discussing ''originality''. What we are discussing is whether it is reasonable to infer that Gregory's work influenced Barrow, and given the in-depth analyses of these scholars (admittedly focusing on originality and priority for the fundamental theorem of calculus), it is hard to argue against, at the very least, the idea that Gregory's work did influence Isaac Barrow. 
[[Special:Contributions/174.3.155.181|174.3.155.181]] ([[User talk:174.3.155.181|talk]]) 17:05, 5 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_B50F649|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2016-07-05 23:01 ===
* Id: B50F649
* User: Holleday
* Date: 2016-06-24 12:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|726796916|STYLE 726796916}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|726796919|TECH 726796919}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Galleries currently use <code>mode=traditional</code> by default, producing a gallery like this:
<gallery>
File:Meripilus giganteus (Karst 1882).jpg|'''''[[Meripilus giganteus]]''''', by [[user:Michael Gäbler|Michael Gäbler]]
File:Zierliche Koralle Ramaria gracilis.JPG|'''''[[Ramaria gracilis]]''''', by [[User talk:Holleday|Dr. Holger Krisp]]
File:Hydnellum ferrugineum Glieres.jpg|'''''[[Hydnellum ferrugineum]]''''', by [[user:Myrabella|Myrabella]]
File:Panaeolus semiovatus LC0334.jpg|'''[[Panaeolus semiovatus var. semiovatus|''Panaeolus semiovatus'' var. ''semiovatus'']]''', by [[User talk:LC-de|Jörg Hempel]]

File:False turkey-tail - Stereum hirsutum - 02.jpg|'''''[[Stereum hirsutum]]''''', by [[User:NorbertNagel|NorbertNagel]]
</gallery>
Should they be change to use <code>mode=packed</code> by default, as below?
<gallery mode=packed>
File:Meripilus giganteus (Karst 1882).jpg|'''''[[Meripilus giganteus]]''''', by [[user:Michael Gäbler|Michael Gäbler]]
File:Zierliche Koralle Ramaria gracilis.JPG|'''''[[Ramaria gracilis]]''''', by [[User talk:Holleday|Dr. Holger Krisp]]
File:Hydnellum ferrugineum Glieres.jpg|'''''[[Hydnellum ferrugineum]]''''', by [[user:Myrabella|Myrabella]]
File:Panaeolus semiovatus LC0334.jpg|'''[[Panaeolus semiovatus var. semiovatus|''Panaeolus semiovatus'' var. ''semiovatus'']]''', by [[User talk:LC-de|Jörg Hempel]]
File:Grüngelbes Gallertkäppchen Leotia lubrica.JPG|'''''[[Leotia lubrica]]''''', by [[User talk:Holleday|Dr. Holger Krisp]]
File:False turkey-tail - Stereum hirsutum - 02.jpg|'''''[[Stereum hirsutum]]''''', by [[User:NorbertNagel|NorbertNagel]]
</gallery>
(pictures from [[:Wikipedia:Featured pictures/Fungi]]) —&nbsp;[[User:Crh23|<span style="font-size: 110%;background-color:#E90800; color:#000005;font-family:Garamond;">&nbsp;'''crh'''&nbsp;<span style="color:White;"><sub>23</sub>&nbsp;</span></span>]]<small>&thinsp;([[User Talk:Crh23|Talk]])</small> 12:29, 24 June 2016 (UTC)}}

* Id: B6132F9
* User: FuriousFreddy

* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|724073083|MEDIA 724073083}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|728688030|MEDIA 728688030}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
With DC Comics' reintroduction of "Captain Marvel" as part of their "New 52" revamp in 2012, he was officially renamed "Shazam", a name that is used not only in the comics but in the character's subsequent appearances in other media. As a result, for the last four years, the lead and infobox for this article have been in a constant state of flux; I have seen each of the following as the lead sentence - back and forth - over the years:
:'''''Captain Marvel''', is a fictional superhero who appears in American comic books published by [[DC Comics]].''
:'''''Captain Marvel''', also known as '''Shazam''', is a fictional superhero who appears in American comic books published by [[DC Comics]].''
:'''''Shazam''', also known as '''Captain Marvel''', is a fictional superhero who appears in American comic books published by [[DC Comics]].''

The infobox has been in more of a state of flux than the lead - attempts have been made to acknowledge both names - i.e. "Shazam (Captain Marvel)" - in the header, but this again has been constantly edited back and forth, often without attribution. My proposal is that the infobox match whatever the choice for the lead will be, either ''"Captain Marvel"'', ''"Captain Marvel (Shazam)"'', or ''"Shazam (Captain Marvel)"''.

This is mostly the result of longtime fans being upset with the renaming of the character; a situation which doesn't appear to be all that reversible given [[Marvel Comics]]' increasing promotion and use of ''their'' [[Captain Marvel (Marvel Comics)|Captain Marvel]] ([[Carol Danvers]]) in their comics and in an upcoming [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]] film. This was the key impetus for the name change in the first place.

This issue may also affect the naming of the article itself - that is, whether or not it needs to be renamed "[[Shazam (DC Comics)]]" or "[[Shazam! (DC Comics)]]". There also may need to be discussion about to do with [[Shazam (character)]], which redirects to [[Shazam (wizard)]], the article about the hero's wizard benefactor, as well as (eventually) the articles for [[Marvel Family]], [[Mary Marvel]] and [[Captain Marvel, Jr.]]. --[[User:FuriousFreddy|FuriousFreddy]] ([[User talk:FuriousFreddy|talk]]) 23:39, 6 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2016 Orlando nightclub shooting#rfc_A79F10C|Talk:2016 Orlando nightclub shooting]] expired 2016-07-07 13:01 ===
* Id: A79F10C
* User: MrX
* Date: 2016-06-25 13:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|726944755|POL 726944755}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|726944757|SOC 726944757}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|728758553|POL 728758553}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|728758555|SOC 728758555}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is a two part question resulting from two previous deadlocked discussions [[Talk:2016 Orlando nightclub shooting/Archive 5#Latin Night per WP:LEAD|here]] and [[Talk:2016 Orlando nightclub shooting#Latin Night in the lead again|here]].

#Should the lead mention that the majority of victims were Hispanic?
#Should the lead mention that Pulse was hosting a Latin night?

Please selection from one of the following options, or write in your own:
:'''A: Include both in the lead.''' Example: "Pulse was hosting a Latin Night and most of the victims were of Hispanic descent."
:'''B: Only include that most of the victims were Hispanic in the lead.''' Example: "Most of the victims were of Hispanic descent."
:'''C: Omit any mention of Latin night and Hispanic victims in the lead'''
:'''D: Mention that it was Latin Night. Omit the race of the victims from the lead. Mention details in the body of the article.'''
[[User:MrX|MrX]] ([[User talk:MrX|talk]]) 13:49, 25 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Credible claim of significance#rfc_385C2F5|Wikipedia talk:Credible claim of significance]] expired 2016-07-09 03:01 ===
* Id: 385C2F5
* User: Adam9007
* Date: 2016-06-09 02:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|724412285|POLICY 724412285}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|728995116|POLICY 728995116}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This essay is linked to from policy, and many people (myself included) refer to it to determine whether something is a credible claim of significance. An official guideline of what constitutes one is badly needed (the above RfC is, to my knowledge, the only official consensus about what does constitute one). In addition to this, we need one that's more broad. This essay has been cited umpteen times recently in discussions about A7, and it seems to represent a very widespread viewpoint. [[User:Adam9007|Adam9007]] ([[User talk:Adam9007|talk]]) 02:26, 9 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Alfred North Whitehead#rfc_DBF0089|Talk:Alfred North Whitehead]] expired 2016-07-10 18:01 ===
* Id: DBF0089
* User: 174.3.155.181
* Date: 2016-06-10 17:56:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|724672900|ECON 724672900}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|724672905|SCI 724672905}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|724672911|RELI 724672911}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|729211867|ECON 729211867}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|729211870|SCI 729211870}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|729211874|RELI 729211874}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
this is getting ridiculous and embarrassing. is wikipedia being used as a way to help nobodies get opportunities they otherwise wouldn't? look at how long the list of "influenced" is! this is longer than [[John Stuart Mill]] who is also a giant. this list needs to be reduced, and to suggest that it doesn't is incorrect. i didnt make a fuss about someone changing the infobox back to "philosophy" because his supervisor [[Edward John Routh]] (a MATHEMATICIAN) was still acknowledged. what is with you "arts kids" on wikipedia? did Whitehead have some exceptional philosophical discourse? of course! however, he was a MATHEMATICIAN. look at some of these references for the "influenced" is hilarious (see reference "CPS Co-Directors", Center for Process Studies, accessed December 12, 2013, http://www.ctr4process.org/about/CoDirectors/. for [[Marjorie Hewitt Suchocki]]). 
:the number of people in this "influenced" box only insult the legacy that was supposed to be left for OUR GUY, the great whitehead. if this was that loser [[bertrand russell]]'s (caveat: i must admit his work was crucial to me "blossoming" though, as it ensured i was "nurtured" throughout my public K-12 education<ref>see [[Genius#Philosophy]]. "Russell's philosophy further maintains, however, that it is possible for such geniuses to be crushed in their youth and lost forever when the environment around them is unsympathetic to their potential maladaptive traits."</ref>), i wouldn't be making as much of a fuss. so can we get some cooperation in lopping off this list? it's way too long and unfair. as was mentioned by another individual in the [[Talk:John Stuart Mill]], many people were influenced by people like Whitehead or Mill. However, that doesn't mean they should all get equal mention. this list is outrageously long and only dilutes his impact. [[Special:Contributions/174.3.155.181|174.3.155.181]] ([[User talk:174.3.155.181|talk]]) 17:56, 10 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016#rfc_32C43CD|Talk:Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016]] expired 2016-07-10 22:01 ===
* Id: 32C43CD
* Date: 2016-07-09 09:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|729226107|UNSORTED 729226107}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|729240826|UNSORTED 729240826}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is general consensus that the text should not necessarily have its own section header on its own merits. While there is consensus for adding some information regarding this news item, the current text did not have consensus. To (grossly) generalise: While the references (such as The Washington Post) may have noted this information, the text in question does not show what the references state as to '''why''' they noted this information, so ''as written'' this appears to the reader as "trivia". So, while keeping policy ([[WP:BLP]], [[WP:V]], [[WP:OR]], etc.) in mind, there is no prejudice against starting a new RfC to determine what that text should be, and which section it should be grouped under (including the possibility of a whole new section, if deemed appropriate). Note: The arbcom restriction noted at the top of this page still applies, so initially [[WP:BOLD|boldly]] adding such text would likely be seen as disruptive and likely trigger sanction. - <b>[[User:Jc37|jc37]]</b> 09:19, 9 July 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:In the news/2016 RD proposal#rfc_577F531|Wikipedia talk:In the news/2016 RD proposal]] expired 2016-07-11 13:01 ===
* Id: 577F531
* User: Thryduulf
* Date: 2016-06-11 12:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|724782119|POLICY 724782119}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|724830658|PROP 724830658}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|725088707|POLICY 725088707}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|729325806|PROP 729325806}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Following a month long trial (9 May - 9 June inclusive) that was regarded as successful by most commenters based on objective and subjective measures (read this page for the full background), this RfC seeks to establish whether the criteria for the "Recent deaths" section of the "In the news" section of the main page, listed at [[Wikipedia:In the news#Recent deaths]] ([[WP:ITN/DC]]), should be changed to match those used during the trial.

'''Question:''' Should the proposal detailed below be implemented?
{{divbox|plain|Proposal|
'''The existing criteria for a recent deaths listing:'''
*The deceased was in a high-ranking office of power at the time of death and/or had a significant contribution/impact on the country/region.
*The deceased was widely regarded as a very important figure in his or her field.
'''are replaced by:'''<br />
The deceased has a Wikipedia article that is:
#Not currently nominated for deletion or speedy deletion.
#Of sufficient quality to be posted on the main page, as determined by a consensus of commenters.
}}
No other changes to the section at [[Wikipedia:In the news#Recent deaths section]] are proposed. These changes do not alter the criteria, standards or conventions for blurbs, including blurbs for people who have recently died.
 
If this proposal is successful it will apply to all nominations made from the UTC day after the RfC is closed (e.g. if this is closed on the 18 June it will apply from 19 June). [[User:Thryduulf|Thryduulf]] ([[User talk:Thryduulf|talk]]) 12:32, 11 June 2016 (UTC)}}

A fair number of the people in this list fail GNG and have an article with their name as a title, which serves as a redirect to this article.  Should these redirect articles be deleted?

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Articles for deletion#rfc_62A12B8|Wikipedia talk:Articles for deletion]] expired 2016-07-13 09:01 ===
* Id: 62A12B8
* User: SSTflyer
* Date: 2016-06-13 08:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|725059881|POLICY 725059881}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|725059883|PROP 725059883}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|729598025|POLICY 729598025}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|729598027|PROP 729598027}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
When an article is [[WP:PROD|proposed for deletion]], the PROD tag sits on the article and the article gets deleted after 1 week of no opposition. However, any editor who later disagrees with the deletion may [[WP:UND|request for undeletion]]. When an AfD discussion receives no comments after a week of being open, it is generally relisted to gain higher participation. Usually AfD discussions are relisted a maximum of two times, after which the discussion is usually closed as [[WP:SOFTDELETE]], meaning that any user may request for its undeletion without going through a [[WP:DRV|deletion review]]. Discussion venues such as [[WP:RFD]] and [[WP:RM]] follow [[WP:NOQUORUM]], in that nominations which have received no opposition after a week are deleted (in the case of RFD) or moved (in the case of RM). I cannot see why AfD should be treated differently from PROD. Generally speaking, AfD is monitored by more editors than PROD, meaning that an AfD uncontested after being opened for more than one week should have gotten more attention than an article which has been PRODed for a week. I propose that AfD discussions which have been open for more than a week (168 hours) without any "keep" votes (policy-based or not) be closed as soft delete, provided that the article has never been proposed for deletion or soft deleted in the past. This means that the article is deleted but any user, for any reason, may request for its undeletion at [[WP:UND]] instead of gaining consensus at [[WP:DRV]]. [[User:SSTflyer|<span style="color:Black">SST</span>]][[User talk:SSTflyer|<span style="color:DarkSlateBlue">flyer</span>]] 08:57, 13 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:James Shortt#rfc_25606FC|Talk:James Shortt]] expired 2016-07-14 22:01 ===
* Id: 25606FC
* User: Legitimus
* Date: 2016-06-14 20:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|725304486|BIO 725304486}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|729837256|BIO 729837256}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The article cites several sources that I would like some informed opinions on in the context of [[WP:RS]] in a [[WP:BLP]] article.  These seem problematic:

* "The Lordship of Castleshort" [http://home.earthlink.net/~rggsibiba/html/castleshort/castleshort.html] - And simple Earthlink site published by Shortt himself.  This makes it a [[WP:SELFPUBLISH|self-published source]], which normally are not acceptable (especially in this case; most other sources seem to show a lot of it is untrue)
*  "Ryoi Shintô Ryû Clubs Worldwide" [https://web.archive.org/web/20131112024747/http://www.rsrjujutsu.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=13&Itemid=29] - Also seems to be a [[WP:SELFPUBLISH|self-published website]] by Shortt himself.
*  www.ibabodyguards.com - While this is an organization, it's also Shortt's business and it reads as though he either wrote it himself or at least has direct control over it's content, which would make it another [[WP:SELFPUBLISH|self-published source]].
*  "Irish Chiefswatch" [http://homepage.eircom.net/%257Eseanjmurphy/chiefs/chiefswatch.htm] and "Niadh Nask: An Alleged Irish Order of Knighthood" [http://homepage.eircom.net/%257Eseanjmurphy/chiefs/niadhnask.htm] - Both part of the [[WP:SELFPUBLISH|Self-published website]] of Sean J Murphy, an alleged genealogist (or something) who was allegedly threatened by Shortt.  He actually references Wikipedia and other wikis in the site.
*  The two [[Private Eye]] articles, "Soldiers of misfortune" and "A Shortt story" - Two problems.  1) There are no links to them and I cannot find them on Private Eye's site or anywhere else online. At present, I cannot verify what they said or if they even exist. 2) Prviate Eye is a ''satire'' magazine, somewhat like the American [[National Enquirer]], and so I am unclear if they are considered reliable sources in general.
*  The three [[The_Phoenix_(magazine)|Phoenix]] articles - same problems as Private Eye above, far as I can tell.
*  BudoExpress Interview - Can't find this anywhere.
*  The Dundalk Leader article - Can't find this anywhere either, not even a mention on a forum post.
[[User:Legitimus|Legitimus]] ([[User talk:Legitimus|talk]]) 20:46, 14 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Elizabeth Dilling#rfc_F094D6B|Talk:Elizabeth Dilling]] expired 2016-07-15 01:01 ===
* Id: F094D6B
* User: Midnightblueowl
* Date: 2016-07-12 21:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|729538642|HIST 729538642}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|729538646|POL 729538646}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|735598054|HIST 735598054}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|735598058|POL 735598058}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[User:Signedzzz]] has done some fantastic work on this page recently, pulling it up to GA status. However, I notice that there are still some significant omissions to the content; there is no section discussing Dilling's personal life or personality for instance, and no wider discussion of her political views or ideology. Moreover, the lead does not aptly summarise the rest of the article, as is required in [[WP:Lede]] (Contrast, for example, this article with that of other political figures like [[Else Christensen]] or [[Vladimir Lenin]]). Thus, this evening I have gone back to the reliable sources, and used them as part of a project to add these sections into the article and to ensure that on the whole it is more thoroughly sourced. 

Unfortunately, Signedzzz has simply undone almost all of my additions, often not giving any explanation in their edit summaries and barely responded to my Talk Page comments. In my opinion, this smacks of [[Wikipedia:Ownership of content|WP:Ownership]], which I think is completely unwarranted in this situation. I'm more than happy to work with them in improving the article, but at this stage I think it is best if I take it to RfC to see what other people have to say. Do I have a point? [[User:Midnightblueowl|Midnightblueowl]] ([[User talk:Midnightblueowl|talk]]) 21:41, 12 July 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Pulse (nightclub)#rfc_13827BD|Talk:Pulse (nightclub)]] expired 2016-07-16 15:01 ===
* Id: 13827BD
* User: Mardus
* Date: 2016-06-16 14:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|725577944|STYLE 725577944}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|730068964|STYLE 730068964}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Because people have actually confused unrelated 2013 shootings in or near other venues named ''Pulse'', I first included a disambiguation hatnote that was removed [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pulse_%28nightclub%29&type=revision&diff=725528548&oldid=725506367 here,] and then included a disambiguation para in a lede, which was also [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pulse_%28nightclub%29&type=revision&diff=725572032&oldid=725571433 removed,] and which I duly reverted. The two 2013 events in other Pulses have been topical elsewhere in this Talk, and have become reason to potentially rename this article.

Therefore, should the article contain disambiguation to shooting events in other venues named Pulse? -<span style="text-shadow:7px 5px 7px #409fff;">[[User:Mardus|Mardus]] <small>/[[User talk:Mardus|talk]]</small></span> 14:24, 16 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Featured article candidates#rfc_DE49A29|Wikipedia talk:Featured article candidates]] expired 2016-07-16 16:01 ===
* Id: DE49A29
* Date: 2016-06-16 15:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|725585437|POLICY 725585437}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|730075938|POLICY 730075938}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am making this request due to a discussion I initiated [[Talk:The_Phantom_Tollbooth#Plot_section_in-universe_problem|here]]. The discussion centered on whether the in-universe template should be applied to the article on the [[The Phantom Tollbooth]], which happens to be a featured article. My understanding of [[MOS:PLOT]] and [[MOS:INUNIVERSE]] is that the entire article, including in a plot summary section, should be written in an out-of-universe perspective, and therefore this article should be changed to fix this. To me, it seems that there are a few possibilities:
<ol> 
  <li>I am misinterpreting the plot summary in [[The Phantom Tollbooth]], and it isn't in the in-universe perspective.</li>
  <li>I am misinterpreting the guidelines at [[MOS:PLOT]] and [[MOS:INUNIVERSE]], and it is acceptable to write in an in-universe style, as long as it is within a plot summary section.</li>
  <li>There actually is a problem, and we should be taking steps to resolve it.</li>
</ol>
Thanks, <span style="background-color:yellow">[[User:Gluons12|<font face="Impact" color="red">Gluons12</font>]]</span> <sup>[[User_talk:Gluons12|<font face="Verdana" color="black">talk</font>]]</sup> 15:02, 16 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Mahindra Enforcer (PBA team)#rfc_90F1077|Talk:Mahindra Enforcer (PBA team)]] expired 2016-07-17 15:01 ===
* Id: 90F1077
* User: Babymissfortune
* Date: 2016-07-12 16:03:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|729503297|SOC 729503297}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Featured picture candidates#rfc_EFF0872|Wikipedia talk:Featured picture candidates]] expired 2016-07-17 22:01 ===
* Id: EFF0872
* User: Pine
* Date: 2016-06-24 04:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|726755745|PROP 726755745}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|730266435|PROP 730266435}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 Our current minimum for featured pictures is "a minimum of 1500 pixels in width and height" with some exceptions. Considering the continuing increases in the quality and size of digital photographs even from smartphone cameras, and the trend toward [[4K UHD]] (3840 x 2160) displays, should we make the following changes:
# increase the minimum size for still images to "3840 pixels x 2160 pixels ([[4K UHD]]), with the height and width interchangeable", and
# change the exception of "Animations and video may be somewhat smaller." to "Animations and video must be a minimum of [[full HD]] (1920 x 1080), with the height and width interchangeable. Exceptions to the minimum may be made for historical, technically difficult or otherwise unique images, if no higher resolution could realistically be acquired."?

The full set of revised size criteria would read:

"It is of sufficiently high resolution to allow quality print reproduction. 
* Still images should be a minimum of 3840 pixels x 2160 pixels ([[4K UHD]]), with the height and width interchangeable; larger sizes are generally preferred. Further information on image size can be found [[Wikipedia:Featured picture criteria/Image size|here]]. 
:* Note that vector graphics in SVG format can have a nominal size much smaller than this, as by their nature they can be infinitely scaled without loss of quality.
:* Exceptions to this rule may be made where justified on a case-by-case basis, such as for historical, technically difficult or otherwise unique images, if no higher resolution could realistically be acquired. This should be explained in the nomination so that it can be taken into consideration.
* Animations and video must be a minimum of [[full HD]] (1920 x 1080), with the height and width interchangeable. 
:* Exceptions to this rule may be made where justified on a case-by-case basis, such as for historical, technically difficult or otherwise unique images, if no higher resolution could realistically be acquired. This should be explained in the nomination so that it can be taken into consideration."
--<font style="white-space:nowrap;text-shadow:#008C3A 0.1em 0.1em 1.5em,#01796F -0.1em -0.1em 1.5em;color:#000000">[[User:Pine|<font color="#01796F"><b>Pine</b></font>]][[User talk:Pine|<font color="#01796F"><sup>✉</sup></font>]]</font> 04:29, 24 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_B0659FB|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2016-07-18 02:01 ===
* Id: B0659FB
* User: Ricky81682
* Date: 2016-07-12 01:56:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|733936879|POLICY 733936879}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Following the closure at [[Wikipedia:Village_pump_(policy)/Archive_128#RfC:_Proposed_draftspace_deletion]], and no review, I've created [[Wikipedia:Proposed draftspace deletion]] as a proposed process. Given that there is consensus that the policy should be adopted, I'd like to see if we could move it to a policy at this point. Some people express some concerns about the time limits listed so I'll add that. Please vote in the subheaders about (a) the length of inactivity; (b) the length of review; and finally (c) whether to adopt as policy. I figured I'd see where we are before starting on the templates and categories. -- [[User:Ricky81682|Ricky81682]] ([[User talk:Ricky81682|talk]]) 01:56, 12 July 2016 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Pendant Productions#rfc_C3969A8|Talk:Pendant Productions]] expired 2016-07-18 03:01 ===
* Id: C3969A8
* User: Bmanpa
* Date: 2016-06-18 02:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|725821774|MEDIA 725821774}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|730295651|MEDIA 730295651}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hi! At the suggestion of [[User:Electricburst1996]], I'm requesting comment on edit number [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pendant_Productions&oldid=725565717 725565717]. As of current, there is an ongoing dispute between myself, {{ping|Spshu}}, and {{ping|Electricburst1996}} regarding this edit and our ongoing discussions about it can be read on our User Talk pages [[User_talk:Bmanpa#Pendant_Productions_issues|here]], [[User_talk:Spshu#Pendant_Productions|here]], and [[User_talk:Electricburst1996#Pendant_Productions|here]]. I'm seeking neutral insight into this situation to help us resolve the issue with cool heads.

Paramount to the discussion is an insistence by [[User:Spshu]] that the sources noted in the current revision do not constitute notoriety. It is my opinion that between [[BBC Radio 4]] coverage, a publishing deal with [[Valiant Comics]], several [[Parsec Awards|Parsec Award]] wins, and multi-million download numbers from a the early days of podcasting (When such things were more rare. The sources for this were removed by Spshu because they were Primary Sources.), notoriety is firmly established. His criteria of notoriety includes needing an abundance of coverage by major media (as opposed to New Media sources), which is not a standard being required of any Wikipedia pages of similar material, nor is it a guideline set forth in [[WP:PSTS]]. (Please see [[Earwolf]], [[Maximum Fun]], and [[Nerdist Industries]] for examples similar to this page.) 

As you can see in my edits from 14 June, I attempted to solve this problem by following the [[WP:UNDUE]] and [[WP:PRIMARY]] guidelines, but Spshu did not deem this sufficient and deleted much of the edit against the guidelines of [[WP:DR]]

Also of issue is the Infobox formatting, which is making use of < small > tags. Small tags are currently in use on Infoboxes for major corporate Wikipedia pages, including [[Warner Bros.]] and [[Paramount Pictures]]. Unless the formatting on those pages is incorrect, it appears his insistence over not using Small tags constitutes a personal preference (see [[WP:IDLI]]).--[[User:Bmanpa|Bmanpa]] ([[User talk:Bmanpa|talk]]) 02:13, 18 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Indian massacre#rfc_DCEA918|Talk:Indian massacre]] expired 2016-07-18 22:01 ===
* Id: DCEA918
* User: Herostratus
* Date: 2016-06-18 20:24:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|725934359|HIST 725934359}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|730415303|HIST 730415303}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should following sentence (or something close to it) appear at the end of the lede paragraph?
:{{xt|The massacres of indigenous peoples of the Americas over five centuries have contributed to the severe population decline of Native Americans in the Americas, which has sometimes been referred to as genocide or the "Indian Holocaust".}}
There are currently two refs for the statement (both entire works with no page numbers given): 
*Churchill, Ward,''A Little Matter of Genocide: Holocaust and Denial in the Americas, 1492 to the Present'', City Lights, 1997, 381 pages, ISBN 978-0-87286-323-1 
*Thornton, Russell, ''American Indian Holocaust and Survival: a Population History since 1492'', University of Oklahoma Press, 1990, 312 pages, ISBN 978-0-8061-2220-5
This question has engendered significant discussion, which can be seen in the above section, [[Talk:Indian massacre#Indian Holocaust in lead]]; readers may consult that, and the person closing the RfC may also wish to. This RfC might be a good place for succinct distillation of the pro and con arguments, to the extent that that's possible for this complicated question. [[User:Herostratus|Herostratus]] ([[User talk:Herostratus|talk]]) 20:24, 18 June 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox company#rfc_33A7938|Template talk:Infobox company]] expired 2016-07-18 23:01 ===
* Id: 33A7938
* User: Timtempleton
* Date: 2016-07-06 19:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|728800584|TECH 728800584}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|733158364|TECH 733158364}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
On the page [[Disney Media Distribution]], a user just changed the type from type = [[Public company|Public]] [[subsidiary]] to type = [[subsidiary]] of [[The Walt Disney Company]]

I know that's wrong, since there's a separate field for parent, but I wanted to confirm what should be in the type field.  

The description page for [[Template:Infobox company]] describes the Type field as follows:

;Type of company, wikilinked where possible. To list percentages owned of a private company, use the ownership parameter (see below).
;Examples: 
;• [[Public company|Public]]
;• [[Privately held company|Private]]

So it's clear that the type can be public or private, but what are the other options?  It would be great to link the template to all the options.  There is a list here <nowiki>[[Category:Types of business entity]]</nowiki>, but the word Type in the [[Template:Infobox company]] infobox is wikilinked to the [[Types of business entity]] article.  That article doesn't really help users understand the type field.

Can we do two things: wikilink the description of the Type field in [[Template:Infobox company]] to <nowiki>[[Category:Types of business entity]]</nowiki>, instead of [[Types of business entity]], and change the wikilinking of the word Type in the [[Template:Infobox company]] template to go to <nowiki>[[Category:Types of business entity]]</nowiki>?  And, while we're at it, shouldn't entity be plural, since types is plural, i.e. Types of business entities?[[User:Timtempleton|Timtempleton]] ([[User talk:Timtempleton|talk]]) 19:26, 6 July 2016 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:No-hair theorem#rfc_4B1A0DC|Talk:No-hair theorem]] expired 2016-07-19 03:01 ===
* Id: 4B1A0DC
* User: Andy Dingley
* Date: 2008-04-15 11:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|728053460|SCI 728053460}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|730452259|SCI 730452259}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Is this "black holes have no hair" statement related to the "hairy ball" observation?  A "hairy ball" (e.g. the physiscist's standard spherical vacuum-racing hamster) ''cannot'' have all of the hair smoothed down perfectly flat. In at least two points ("[[boojum]]s" if you'd like more physics-related neologisms) the hair must either come to either a radial point, or a point of extreme curl. As such points aren't observable from outside the event horizon, we can infer that there's no "hair" on a black hole, where this "hair" analogy can be extended to a number of forms of possible "texture" in its surface. [[User:Andy Dingley|Andy Dingley]] ([[User talk:Andy Dingley|talk]]) 11:15, 15 April 2008 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Monosodium glutamate#rfc_5A60F98|Talk:Monosodium glutamate]] expired 2016-07-19 18:01 ===
* Id: 5A60F98
* User: Elvey
* Date: 2016-07-19 03:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|730458548|UNSORTED 730458548}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|730544864|UNSORTED 730544864}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The MSG article lede currently says: "A popular belief in the Anglosphere is that large doses of MSG can cause headaches [...] but scientists have been unable to trigger such reactions in controlled studies."  '''Are we misinforming our readers when we say that?''' '''Multiple papers''': "the Geha paper references <u>Yang 1997</u>, and includes their own experimental results; both papers clearly evidence statistically significant reactions [including headache]."  But the evidence is  The reversion of [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Monosodium_glutamate&diff=730326891&oldid=728136961 this edit] is a crude attempt to silence me that would have a conspiracy nut screaming about a cover-up.  Look, I'm skeptical about whether MSG causes headaches too.  But I'm willing to listen to the evidence and think we should be reporting the evidence, not preconceived notions of what we think the evidence should be.  That's bad science.  Who's down with reporting the evidence?  Let's see! I reiterate and clarify* the basis for my concern that Geha is not peer reviewed and has other major issues. Yet, thus far, my attempts to improve the article to address this have been met with reversion*. (*See section above the RFC on the talk page.)  I think the article ''should'' discuss the issues with Yang and Geha, but not use them as medical sources, especially if we can't establish that Geha is peer reviewed, and should include a newer review, http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/pmid/27189588/.  --[[User:Elvey|<font color="burntorange">Elvey</font>]]<sup>([[User talk:Elvey|t]]•[[Special:Contribs/Elvey|c]])</sup> 03:31, 19 July 2016 (UTC)}}

* Id: FF35F9A
