=== [[Talk:Murder of Anita Cobby#rfc_92DDB0C|Talk:Murder of Anita Cobby]] expired 2016-09-09 20:02 ===
* Id: 92DDB0C
* User: Eng.M.Bandara
* Date: 2016-08-27 16:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|736465759|POLICY 736465759}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|738575037|POLICY 738575037}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In order to maintain consistency with Homicide related articles, e.g [[Murder_of_Travis_Alexander|Homoicide 1]] and [[Shooting_of_Trayvon_Martin|Homocide 2]], I propose renaming the articles to "Homicide of...." Because the word murder has political/legal consequence attached to it, and thus may change from jurisdiction to jurisdiction, from an encyclopedic POV the word "Homicide" represents facts as it is i.e human killing human, without the politicizing and maintains an accurate general descriptions of the article.  I propose all articles of this nature be given a general Name such as "Homicide of....." and discuss a proposed subheadings. --[[User:Eng.M.Bandara|<span style="font-family:Segoe print; color:DarkBlue; text-shadow:gray 0.2em 0.2em 0.4em;">Eng. M.Bandara</span>]]<small>[[User talk:Eng.M.Bandara|'''<em style="font-family:Verdana;color:Black">-Talk</em>''']]</small> 16:13, 27 August 2016 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Stand-alone lists#rfc_1E55EEB|Wikipedia talk:Stand-alone lists]] expired 2016-09-09 20:02 ===
* Id: 1E55EEB
* User: Ilovetopaint
* Date: 2016-08-10 17:48:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|736195919|POLICY 736195919}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I'd like to propose some common sense guidelines for [[Wikipedia:Stand-alone lists#Citing sources|#Citing sources]] and/or [[MOS:MUSIC]]. There are virtually no guidelines for music genres, and because of that, I often find myself in edit wars making these same arguments over and over again, so I would like official consensus on these matters:
* WP:GENREVERIFY (clarification of [[WP:VERIFY]])
**'''Music genres are almost always [[WP:MINREF|likely to be challenged]]'''. Exceptions may be made for high-level root genres like rock, pop, electronic, folk, etc.
** Thus, '''all entries must be verifiable''' for exemplar subgenre articles like [[List of psychedelic pop artists]], [[List of blues rock musicians]], and [[List of trip hop artists]].
** "The source is in their respective articles" is not a valid rationale ([[WP:CIRCULAR]]). If it is the case, then simply copy over the relevant source(s) to establish verifiability and notability.
* WP:EXPLICITGENRE (clarification of [[WP:STICKTOSOURCE]] and [[WP:SYNTH]])
**References must be explicit in saying that the artist belongs to a genre. For instance, a source that identifies the Beatles' ''[[Rubber Soul]]'' as "a folk rock album" does not mean that the Beatles count as a folk rock band.
** Sources must ''directly support'' cited genres. When a source writes that a work "mixes experimental, rock, and jazz", it does not necessarily follow that it is a work ''of'' experimental, rock, and jazz. By the same token, if a source cites a work of pop music for using synthesizers prominently, this should not lead an editor to refer to the work as "synthpop" if not explicitly stated by the source. 
--[[User:Ilovetopaint|Ilovetopaint]] ([[User talk:Ilovetopaint|talk]]) 17:48, 10 August 2016 (UTC)}}

{{helpme}}
I don't want a Wikia or Wikimedia alternative because I don't see anything I would be interested in editing. Uncyclopedia, RationalWiki and Encyclopedia Dramatica are too strange/weird. I'd like to find a good Wikipedia knockoff that still has strict but easily understood NPOV and verification policies that have the same rules as on Wikipedia but is interpreted the same way throughout the Wiki because it reads in an easy-to-understand way so there are no conflicts over how to properly interpret the policies and reasoning can come pretty fast but despite having similar policies to Wikipedia; won't have any way to block or ban users if they make too many stupid edits or write too much or even for harassing editors and calling them names like "disruptive" and "incompetent" too much but there are no ads so no lag or accidentally clicking one or stumbling on a bad one. I think that would be a good one because stupid people would be politely dealt with instead of being kicked from the site but still has similar copyright policy and other kinds of policy like Wikipedia, but there is no 'competence is required' policy so stupid people don't get discriminated against. #DumbLivesMatter #NoobLivesMatter #AllLivesMatter --[[User:Turkeybutt JC|Turkeybutt]] ([[User talk:Turkeybutt JC#top|talk]]) 12:58, 10 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Eritrea#rfc_7C7F5F6|Talk:Eritrea]] expired 2016-09-14 17:01 ===
* Id: 7C7F5F6
* User: Soupforone
* Date: 2016-08-15 16:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Disambiguation#rfc_98D1A0B|Wikipedia talk:Disambiguation]] expired 2016-09-15 01:01 ===
* Id: 98D1A0B
* User: Bkonrad#Alphonse]]), on the basis that anthro pages should not be considered dab pages, even for this purpose. I've tried to create a workaround with {{tl
* Date: 2016-08-24 15:52:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|736023185|POLICY 736023185}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|739492140|POLICY 739492140}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''In brief: How should we treat links to anthroponymy pages?'''

For those unfamiliar, [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Anthroponymy]] pages are a somewhat unique beast: they list people who share a given name or surname <s>or complete name</s>, and they are often treated like disambiguation pages, though they are categorized as set index articles. <small>(Aside: there is no MOS guideline for these pages, just the [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Anthroponymy/Standards|WikiProject standards]] page. I have tried unsuccessfully to have this page promoted to the MOS; the absence of a MOS for anthro pages is a big problem to be tackled separately.)</small>

'''The issue at hand:''' There is no consensus on how to treat links to anthro pages. For ''dab'' pages, the correct method is to link to "Title (disambiguation)", which may be a redirect to the actual dab page—this is to make it clear to bots that the link is intentional, so it doesn't show up on lists of ambiguous links that need to be fixed (see [[Wikipedia:Disambiguation pages with links]]). IMO, the same logic applies to anthroponymy pages, and this has clearly been the practice for quite some time (see tens of thousands of examples in [[:Category:Redirects to disambiguation pages]]). However, this practice is in dispute (see [[User talk:Bkonrad#Alphonse]]), on the basis that anthro pages should not be considered dab pages, even for this purpose. I've tried to create a workaround with {{tl|R to anthroponymy page}}, in parallel with {{tl|R to disambiguation page}}, but I think a question affecting such a huge number of pages needs larger input. The options I see are (add any you think I missed):

For linking to anthroponymy pages:
# Point all links directly to the anthroponymy page (This leaves no simple way to sort intentional links from unintentional ones that should be further disambiguated.)
# Leave or create "Name (disambiguation)" redirects, using {{tl|R to disambiguation page}} (This has the drawback that anthro pages may not ''strictly'' be dab pages, though they do list ambiguous entries.)
# Create "Name (anthroponymy)" redirects, using {{tl|R to anthroponymy page}} (This would require the most work (probably by bot), but would, IMO, leave things in the most useful state.)

Thoughts? If you have a preference for one of the listed options, please indicate so. —[[user:swpb|<u>swpb</u>]]<sup>[[user talk:swpb|''T'']]</sup> 15:52, 24 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Gamergate controversy#rfc_2E228F3|Talk:Gamergate controversy]] expired 2016-09-15 05:01 ===

Concensus is noted to be needed for bold edits. I'm adding Gjoni's side of the story in a tiny manner. There is no controversy in that. Not noting his side of the story would infringe upon [[WP:BLP]]. [[User:Mr. Magoo and McBarker|Mr. Magoo]] ([[User talk:Mr. Magoo and McBarker|talk]]) 11:22, 17 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Frankfurt School#rfc_1058C32|Talk:Frankfurt School]] expired 2016-09-15 13:01 ===
* Id: 1058C32
* User: Last Contrarian
* Date: 2016-08-16 12:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|734748101|POL 734748101}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|739565982|POL 739565982}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I firmly believe that the lede of the "Cultural Marxism conspiracy theory" section is a case of [[WP:SYNTHESIS]]. [[User:Jobrot]] disagrees and has repeatedly reverted my [[WP:NPOV]] warning without cause. The lede currently states:
{{blockquote|'Cultural Marxism' in modern political parlance commonly refers to a conspiracy theory which sees the Frankfurt School as part of a contemporary movement within the political left to take over and destroy Western society.}}

If we pare the statement down to its essentials, it states that:

{{blockquote|'Cultural Marxism' in modern political parlance commonly refers to a conspiracy theory}}

The claim being advanced is:

1. It is a conspiracy theory.

2. This "fact" is commonly known and the cultural and political mainstream (all major political and cultural  divisions) believes this without a shadow of a doubt.

3. Only a small fringe continues to use the term in a "non-ironic" way.

The sources cited as evidence are:

1. An article by Jerome Jamin, a left-wing academic researching right-wing movements.

2. An article by Bill Berkowitz for the [[Southern Poverty Law Center]], a left-wing organization which maintains large lists of what it believes to be right-wing and religious movements and hate-groups. The article is entitled '''Reframing the Enemy'''.

3. American paleo-conservative [[William S. Lind]].

Now, it is no surprise that left-wingers like Jamin and Berkowitz/SPLC believe that "Cultural Marxism" is a conspiracy theory. But Lind does not believe that. Neither do the right-wingers mentioned by Berkowitz in his article.

The conclusion is that only some left-wingers consider "Cultural Marxism" to be a conspiracy theory. And instead of stating things as they are, the section currently uses [[WP:SYNTHESIS]] and weasel words like '''commonly refers to''' (without mention the subjects who do the referring) to convert an opinion held in some parts of the left to a strong, universal claim.

I formally request comments on the structure of the lede. [[User:Last Contrarian|Last Contrarian]] ([[User talk:Last Contrarian|talk]]) 12:44, 16 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox software#rfc_2F7E14A|Template talk:Infobox software]] expired 2016-09-15 17:01 ===
* Id: 2F7E14A
* User: Codename Lisa
* Date: 2016-09-04 08:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|738575019|SCI 738575019}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|738575037|POLICY 738575037}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|738575038|TECH 738575038}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|739594179|SCI 739594179}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|739594182|POLICY 739594182}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|739594184|TECH 739594184}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{Infobox
|title=Demonstration of what will happen to the infobox
| labelstyle = white-space: nowrap;
|label1 = [[Source code repository]]
|data1 = {{Plainlist|
*https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android
*https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Desktop
*https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-iOS
  }}
}}
RFC Question: '''Should we add a "source code repository" field to the infobox?'''

Caveats:
* It could go against [[WP:EL]] that says links that can be found as part of official website should not be included in the article.
* Doing so can make the infobox long and unwieldy. Sometimes, like in the case of [[Signal (software)]], there are four or five links. The External Links section is a better place.
* It is technical information that is no readily usable to every reader. Only programmers willing to participate in development need ready access to such links.

Best regards,<br/>[[User:Codename Lisa|Codename Lisa]] ([[User talk:Codename Lisa|talk]]) 08:02, 4 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Paul Singer (businessman)#rfc_E043839|Talk:Paul Singer (businessman)]] expired 2016-09-15 22:01 ===
* Id: E043839
* User: Yvarta
* Date: 2016-08-16 21:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|734815042|BIO 734815042}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|734815045|ECON 734815045}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|734815049|LANG 734815049}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|734815055|POL 734815055}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|739628845|BIO 739628845}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|739628848|ECON 739628848}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|739628852|LANG 739628852}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|739628857|POL 739628857}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Requesting input per this [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Paul_Singer_(businessman)&oldid=734669187 lead removal on August 15] with this [[Talk:Paul_Singer_(businessman)#Changes_in_lead.2C_August_15.2C_2016|rationale]], which met with [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Paul_Singer_(businessman)&oldid=734710128 reversions] from [[User:Nomoskedasticity]], and a [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Paul_Singer_(businessman)&oldid=734680124 reversion] from [[User:SegataSanshiro1]], both citing prior consensus. They are referring to a two-year discussion about the use of “[[vulture fund|vulture]]” as a descriptor in the lead of a biography. For the purpose of this discussion, I have a two-part question:

1) Is “vulture” a derogatory slur?

2) If so, does it belong in the lead of a biography (or corporate lead for that matter)?

In the hopes of keeping discussion pointed, I might strongly urge contributors from the prior RfCs to [[Talk:Paul_Singer_(businessman)#Changes_in_lead.2C_August_15.2C_2016|read the extended reasoning for my removal]] before adding their thoughts. Likewise, I'm sure scanning the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Paul_Singer_(businessman) old RfCs] for new contributors would be a boon. [[User:Yvarta|Yvarta]] ([[User talk:Yvarta|talk]]) 21:31, 16 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Miniature Australian Shepherd#rfc_C3350AE|Talk:Miniature Australian Shepherd]] expired 2016-09-15 22:01 ===
* Id: C3350AE
* User: SMcCandlish
* Date: 2016-08-16 21:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|734815052|SCI 734815052}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|734815058|SOC 734815058}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|739628854|SCI 739628854}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|739628863|SOC 739628863}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Consensus was in late 2013 to merge the articles [[Miniature American Shepherd]] and [[Miniature Australian Shepherd]] (see above). This stalled due to arguing about the name in 2014, followed by johnny-come-lately objections in 2015 on the basis that some people out there are still trying to produce a separate breed or subbreed under the "Australian" name. (Note that Australia itself is not implicated in any way; all three breeds or would-be breeds under discussion actually originated in the US).

'''Should the consensus to merge be upheld, and if so in what direction?'''

<span style="white-space:nowrap;font-family:'Trebuchet MS'"> — [[User:SMcCandlish|'''SMcCandlish''' ☺]] [[User talk:SMcCandlish|☏]] [[Special:Contributions/SMcCandlish|¢]] ≽<sup>ʌ</sup>ⱷ҅<sub>ᴥ</sub>ⱷ<sup>ʌ</sup>≼ </span> 21:39, 16 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Slut-shaming#rfc_AC101DB|Talk:Slut-shaming]] expired 2016-09-18 00:01 ===
* Id: AC101DB
* User: Flyer22 Reborn
* Date: 2016-08-18 23:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|735164460|MEDIA 735164460}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|735164464|POL 735164464}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|735164467|SOC 735164467}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|739927609|MEDIA 739927609}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|739927615|POL 739927615}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|739927616|SOC 739927616}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 
One view is that this article is about the topic, not the word, and so we can use sources to identify matters as slut-shaming even if the sources do not call the matter slut-shaming; it is for us to decide whether something is on topic or not, and whether we are introducing bias or undue [[WP:weight]]. The other view is this is not a [[WP:Not a dictionary]] matter; this is a matter concerning whether or not it is acceptable (and not a [[WP:Synthesis]] violation) to take sources that do not make it explicitly clear, in words, that the topic is about slut-shaming and then using those sources to make claims about slut-shaming. For those viewing this from the RfC page or their talk page, the full discussion is above, at [[Talk:Slut-shaming#Scope]]. [[User:Flyer22 Reborn|Flyer22 Reborn]] ([[User talk:Flyer22 Reborn|talk]]) 23:14, 18 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Mock the Week#rfc_FCDDEDF|Talk:Mock the Week]] expired 2016-09-18 21:01 ===
* Id: FCDDEDF
* User: GUtt01
* Date: 2016-08-19 19:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|735295541|MEDIA 735295541}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|740063851|MEDIA 740063851}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I would like to propose a discussion on the information in the article, [[List of Mock the Week episodes]], in regards to Wins and Scores.  My belief is that the information should not be included there; in my personal opinion, I don't think it has anything to warrant notability at all, as the show is not a serious competition and most of the rounds don't focus on news articles on the week before its broadcast/filming, because they involve stand-up on certain topics and improve games.  My proposal is simply to comment on what to do with the information and draw some consensus on this (after I let personal feelings get the better of me).  The following options should be considered in this discussion:

* Should the information be deleted, and if so, why should it be the case in your own words?
* Should the information be merged into the main article here, and if so, why?  If it is merged into this article, should it be all the information or some of it?
* Should the information remain where it is?  If so, why?

Please comment to this Talk subject below here please.  Thank you. [[User:GUtt01|GUtt01]] ([[User talk:GUtt01|talk]]) 19:10, 19 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion#rfc_8324106|Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion]] expired 2016-09-19 03:01 ===
* Id: 8324106
* User: Adam9007
* Date: 2016-08-20 01:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|735339379|POLICY 735339379}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|740107348|POLICY 740107348}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have recently encountered a confusion regarding these and A7. It was insisted that Churches are eligible for A7 as organisations. However, I look through the categories, and they are definitely classed under Buildings and Structures, and I haven't yet found any indication of them being classed under organisations (unless I missed something?). Even [[Church (building)|the article about Churches]] explicitly identify them as buildings. Hotels and hospitals appear to be classed under both; what does this mean exactly? Does it mean that both [[WP:ORG]] and [[WP:GEOFEAT]] apply? If so, how does that work? And are they eligible for A7 or not, or both (???). This is all rather confusing because, if I go to (for argument's sake) [[Wexham Park Hospital]], 2 of the 3 categories there are Hospital Buildings, and Buildings and Structures. No indication of it being classed as an organisation yet. Only after digging through the categories do I find that Hospitals are also under Medical and health organisations. Same with (again, for argument's sake) [[Imperial Hotel, Tokyo]]; categories include Hotel buildings, and of course, Buildings and Structures. No explicit indication of it being an organisation. Again, only after trawling through the categories do I find that hotels also come under companies. At face value, hospitals and hotels (or at least the two examples given here) appear to be classed under Buildings and Structures only. Does this mean they are ''primarily'' Buildings, and ''secondarily'' organisations? My query is thus: are these (for the purposes of A7) buildings, or organisations, and are they/should they be A7-eligible? And if they're under organisations, perhaps a note explaining all of this should be put somewhere (the templates perhaps?), or maybe a new (sub)category for A7 should be implemented? [[User:Adam9007|Adam9007]] ([[User talk:Adam9007|talk]]) 01:22, 20 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_CD944A1|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2016-09-19 22:01 ===
* Id: CD944A1
* User: Herostratus
* Date: 2016-08-20 20:56:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|735455609|STYLE 735455609}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|735455610|POLICY 735455610}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|735455613|TECH 735455613}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|740238423|STYLE 740238423}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|740238425|POLICY 740238425}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|740238427|TECH 740238427}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
===Statement of the issues'''

There's no "Survey" section in this RfC and no up/down vote on an action item. That can come later. There's a lot to chew on here, so let's just have a threaded discussion(s). Maybe we can generate an action item(s) to "vote" on further down the road.

It's a complicated question covering a decade of use of some half-dozen templates which are transcluded over some half a million articles, with documentation in several places. So I apologize in advance for the length of the material.

'''The basic questions of this RfC'''

The basic question is '''"How should quotes be handled in articles"''' A legitimate answer, of course, is "exactly as they have been". (We are referring in this RfC to typical quotes from a general source, not specialized situations handled by specialized templates such as {{tl|Quote hadith}} etc.)

So some more detailed questions that arise from this might be:
*Is it OK to continue to have three different templates used for general quotes, or not? Why or why not?
*The [[WP:MOS]] specifies to use {{tl|Quote}} for quotes, and doesn't mention {{tl|Quote box}} one way or the other, but {{tl|Quote box}} itself says to not use it for regular quotes -- yet {{tl|Quote box}} is used for quotes far more often than {{tl|Quote}}; ought this situation be addressed, or not, and if so how?
*{{tl|Cquote}} is used a fair amount for quotations, even though this MOS strictly forbids this; ought this situation be addressed, or not, and if so how?
*This MOS by inference supports pull quotes ("the {{tl|pull quote}}... template, which [is] reserved for pull quotes"). Should this MOS discourage or even forbid pull quotes, or is it OK like this?

And there are probably lots of other questions. Possible solutions are many, including 
*Doing nothing, leave the present situation as is.
*Functionally deleting two of {{tl|Quote}} / {{tl|Quote box}} / {{tl|Cquote}} (by just making two of them a redirect to the remaining one? or whatever would be the best way technically to achieve this function).
*Changing the documentation to overtly permit use of all three (or: some two) templates for quotes at editors' discretion.
*Designing a new template which is better than any of the existing ones and deprecating the old ones.
*Writing a new protocol which carves out separate uses for {{tl|quote}} and {{tl|quote box}} and/or {{tl|cquote}}.

And certainly there are many other good ideas to be had. That's the purpose of this RfC, to think about these and various other possibilities, and maybe we can find some that seem worthy of being presented as action items, down the road. [[User:Herostratus|Herostratus]] ([[User talk:Herostratus|talk]]) 20:56, 20 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Council/Proposals/Homelessness#rfc_AC09427|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Council/Proposals/Homelessness]] expired 2016-09-20 15:01 ===
* Id: AC09427
* User: I.am.a.qwerty
* Date: 2016-09-20 06:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|740314828|SOC 740314828}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|740314832|PROJ 740314832}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|740314834|PROP 740314834}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|740355820|SOC 740355820}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|740355821|PROJ 740355821}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|740355822|PROP 740355822}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hello,

I am wondering if interested editors would like to establish a WikiProject on [[homelessness]].

# Enough time has passed since [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Council/Proposals/Homelessness|this last proposal]].
# The topic is certainly valid and notable (it's a level 4 vital article in Society), relates to a variety of fields (social work, sociology, psychology, health).
# I have recently created [[Template:Homelessness]], linking at least 70 articles on general homelessness topics, e.g. by country, type, etc. And there are others linked on separate templates and lists (e.g. [[List of homelessness organizations]], [[List of street newspapers]]).

I'm not entirely familiar with the process of creating a project, I'm guessing we would need at least 5 other editors to join the project and help index and tag pages.

[[User:I.am.a.qwerty|I.am.a.qwerty]] ([[User talk:I.am.a.qwerty|talk]]) 06:01, 20 September 2016 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Ride the Lightning#rfc_2B66926|Talk:Ride the Lightning]] expired 2016-09-20 15:01 ===
* Id: 2B66926
* User: Maunus
* Date: 2016-08-21 14:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|735618244|SOC 735618244}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|740355820|SOC 740355820}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
One editor argues that it is important to include the year of publication when mentioning hemingway's novel "For Whom the Bell Tolls" as in this edit [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ride_the_Lightning&type=revision&diff=735459242&oldid=735422413]. To be frank I don't give a fig myself either way, but the fact that someone would edit war on an article that is undergoing FAC review about such a trivial detail grates me. Hence this RfC. You are being asked whether the article should include or exclude the year of publication. <small><span class="autosigned">—&nbsp;Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Maunus|Maunus]] ([[User talk:Maunus|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Maunus|contribs]]) 14:43, 21 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:LGBT athletes in the Olympics#rfc_3769768|Talk:LGBT athletes in the Olympics]] expired 2016-09-21 15:01 ===
* Id: 3769768
* User: Bearcat
* Date: 2016-08-22 14:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|735703091|SOC 735703091}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|740514883|SOC 740514883}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Recently, an anonymous IP started annotating the list of athletes in this article with running medal counts, marked by [[File:Gold medal icon (G initial).svg|G]], [[File:Silver medal icon (S initial).svg|S]] or [[File:Bronze medal icon (B initial).svg|B]] icons. And I don't just mean one icon per person, but an icon for ''every'' medal the person ever won — [[Ian Thorpe]], for example, had nine icons after his name. As I don't believe tallying medal counts is relevant in this context, but instead just clutters up the article unnecessarily, I removed it with an explanation in my edit summary — however, my removal has now been reverted twice (once by another anonymous IP, and once by a newly registered username who's probably that same IP), with no explanation given of why the information ''was'' warranted — the only "explanation" given was a false claim that my edits constituted ''vandalism''.

Rather than letting this turn into an ongoing revert war, however, I want to solicit opinions: is there a compelling reason that I'm missing why the list of LGBT athletes in this article ''should'' directly annotate their full medal counts, or was I right to remove that as not being useful or relevant content in this context? [[User:Bearcat|Bearcat]] ([[User talk:Bearcat|talk]]) 14:55, 22 August 2016 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|740522960|BIO 740522960}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|740522965|LANG 740522965}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|740522967|MEDIA 740522967}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|740522973|SOC 740522973}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|740522977|STYLE 740522977}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|740522981|POLICY 740522981}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|740522983|TECH 740522983}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Extensive debate over the past week regarding the selection of a consistent citation format for citations in the [[Jane Austen]] article. A group of three editors have stepped up to offer to do the complete conversion of the article into Harvard format following WP:CITEVAR ({{ping|Jonesey95|RexxS|Prairieplant}}) which has been substantially started by them already. They were rebuffed by users Victoriaearle and Lingzhi who felt that the original version of the article from 10 years ago had initially been started in MLA format by the late Wadewitz. Since Wadewitz passed away, 5-6 editors have edited the article in different cite formats, and the late Wadewitz is no longer here to state a preference. If you SUPPORT the complete conversion of the remainder of the article in agreement with the Harvard format then indicate this as your SUPPORT, and if you OPPOSE the Harvard format then indicate your preference below. The Policy and Tech editors may also indicate their preferences below. [[User:Fountains-of-Paris|Fountains-of-Paris]] ([[User talk:Fountains-of-Paris|talk]]) 15:09, 22 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Orthopedic surgery#rfc_2553E8D|Talk:Orthopedic surgery]] expired 2016-09-21 18:01 ===
* Id: 2553E8D
* User: Jerodlycett
* Date: 2016-09-18 17:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|740039280|SCI 740039280}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|740039290|STYLE 740039290}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|740538396|SCI 740538396}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|740538398|STYLE 740538398}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I just came across this article. I couldn't care less what it's named, but the fact that it uses both spellings throughout is really really odd on here. As such I see three options:
# Keep as is
# Keep name, and change all uses to Orthopedic
# Move and change all uses to Orthopaedic

I'm in favor of either 2 or 3, obviously. I've done this as an RFC to get it wide, and included it in style to have that group on here. [[User:Jerodlycett|Jerod Lycett]] ([[User talk:Jerodlycett|talk]]) 17:39, 18 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Phulkian sardars#rfc_2F0A5AF|Talk:Phulkian sardars]] expired 2016-09-23 23:01 ===
* Id: 2F0A5AF
* User: Sitush
* Date: 2016-09-23 17:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|740848961|HIST 740848961}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|740848963|POL 740848963}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|740848966|RELI 740848966}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|740881906|HIST 740881906}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|740881908|POL 740881908}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|740881912|RELI 740881912}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hello, I would like to report an issue with another user on wikipedia, who has clear bias. He claims the citations being used, which involve [[John Murray (publisher)]] and the [[Calcutta journal]] (a very good journal at the time) are "unreliable", without providing any evidence to support his claim. He made similar reversions on the [[Phulkian misl]] page with the same vacuous reasoning. His edit history suggests he has a religious bias, and I am concerned that he will continually revert valid sources to favour perception of his own culture, which at the time was considered a rival to the clan who this article is concerning. I find it hard to believe this user can make such reversions without procuring any sources to support his claim. I am urging others to please investigate this matter.  

:There is a long-standing consensus that sources from the British Raj era and earlier are not reliable for history, for caste-related matters etc. There are some notes about this at [[User:Sitush/CasteSources]], among other places, and of course there is also information of a more general type at [[WP:HISTRS]]. Please do not reinstate them. And please do not ascribe motives to people without good cause, of which you have none in this instance. - [[User:Sitush|Sitush]] ([[User talk:Sitush|talk]]) 17:30, 23 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Antisemitism in 21st-century France#rfc_EACE4A7|Talk:Antisemitism in 21st-century France]] expired 2016-09-24 06:01 ===
* Id: EACE4A7
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|736110864|RELI 736110864}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|736110865|SOC 736110865}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|736181909|HIST 736181909}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|736181911|POL 736181911}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|740925055|HIST 740925055}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|740925057|POL 740925057}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|740925059|RELI 740925059}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|740925063|SOC 740925063}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 There is disagreement about whether the article should include lists of individual recent antisemitic incidents. I have argued that these are not noteworthy according to wikipedia standards because Wikipedia is not a newspaper [[WP:NOTNP]] and this seems like a list of recent and not particularly noteworthy or historically significant anti-semitic incidents. Also see [[WP:RECENT]]. I think the content in question will not pass the ten-year test. Other editors disagree with me but we seem to be consistently talking past each other, and it would be good to have some additional eyes on this. See above discussion on [[Talk:Antisemitism in 21st-century France#Don't just list incidents]] and a previous similar RfC at

=== [[Talk:Antisemitism_in_the_United_States#RFC_-_Antisemitic_incidents]] expired 2016-09-24 06:01 ===
* Id: 
* User: Dan Eisenberg
* Date: 2016-08-25 05:32:00
* RFC Text:
. The specific text in question is:

<blockquote>

'''2015 attacks'''

During the [[January 2015 Île-de-France attacks]], one of the three gunmen killed four persons in the [[Porte de Vincennes siege]] and took hostages at a kosher supermarket. French forces killed all three attackers involved in four different shooting incidents. In the aftermath of the attacks, for which responsibility was claimed by [[Al-Qaeda]], the French government increased the presence of soldiers outside prominent Jewish buildings.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/jewish-world/jewish-world-features/.premium-1.645296|title=As Soldiers Guard Parisian Synagogues, Jews Question Their Place and Their Safety in France|work=Haaretz.com}}</ref> In February 2015 soldiers guarding a Jewish community center in [[Nice]] were attacked and wounded, none fatally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-31118020|title=French soldiers wounded in Nice Jewish centre attack|work=BBC News}}</ref> 

On 24 October in [[Marseilles]], three Jewish men outside a synagogue were stabbed by a man shouting anti-Jewish slogans.  One of the victims sustained serious abdominal wounds; he was expected to survive.  The assailant was apprehended.<ref name=TOIMarseilles>{{cite news|title=3 Jews stabbed in anti-Semitic attack in France|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/3-jews-stabbed-in-anti-semitic-attack-in-france/|accessdate=14 December 2015|publisher=[[Times of Israel]]|date=24 October 2005}}</ref>

On 18 November 2015 in Marseilles, a teacher was stabbed by three men who shouted anti-Jewish slogans; one of the men wore an [[ISIS]] T-shirt.<ref name=MarseilleStabbing>{{cite news|title=Jewish teacher stabbed in French city of Marseille|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34864509|accessdate=14 December 2015|publisher=BBC|date=18 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=MarseilleNYTimes>{{cite news|title=Jewish Teacher Stabbed in Marseille by ISIS Supporters|url=http://www.nytimes.com/live/paris-attacks-live-updates/jewish-teacher-stabbed-in-marseilles-isis-claims-responsibility|accessdate=14 December 2015|publisher=[[New York Times]]|date=18 November 2015}}</ref><ref name=GuradianStabbing18>{{cite news|title=Jewish teacher stabbed in Marseille street by trio praising Islamic State|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/nov/19/jewish-teacher-stabbed-in-marseille-street-by-trio-praising-islamic-state|accessdate=14 December 2015|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=18 November 2015}}</ref>

'''2016 attacks'''

In the third incident in Marseilles since October, on January 12, 2016 Benjamin Amsellem, a teacher, was attacked outside a Jewish school by a teenage boy wielding a machete. The attacker claimed to be acting in the name of [[ISIS]].<ref name=HallMachete>{{cite news|last1=Hall|first1=John|title=Marseille machete attack: 15-year-old suspect claims he stabbed Jewish teacher 'in the name of Isis'|url=http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/marseille-machete-attack-15-year-old-suspect-claims-he-stabbed-jewish-teacher-in-the-name-of-isis-a6807601.html|accessdate=25 January 2016|publisher=The Telegraph|date=12 January 2016}}</ref> Amsellem used a large Bible he was carrying to fend off the attack.<ref name=NossiterMachete>{{cite news|last1=Nossiter|first1=Adam|title=French Jews Fear a New Strain of ISIS-Inspired Anti-Semitism|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/25/world/europe/french-jews-fear-a-new-strain-of-isis-inspired-anti-semitism.html?module=WatchingPortal&region=c-column-middle-span-region&pgType=Homepage&action=click&mediaId=thumb_square&state=standard&contentPlacement=3&version=internal&contentCollection=www.nytimes.com&contentId=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2016%2F01%2F25%2Fworld%2Feurope%2Ffrench-jews-fear-a-new-strain-of-isis-inspired-anti-semitism.html&eventName=Watching-article-click|accessdate=25 January 2016|publisher=New York Times|date=24 January 2016}}</ref>  The attacker was a Kurdish Muslim whose family had emigrated five years before to France from Turkey. He was an excellent student from a stable, pious home. French authorities speculated that he had self-radicalized by spending long hours reading Islamist websites; no ties were found with existing terrorist organizations.<ref name=NossiterMachete/>

On August 18 in [[Strasbourg]], a "confirmed anti-semite"<ref>{{cite news|last1=AURÉLIEN POIVRET|title=Un juif agressé par un déséquilibré|url=http://www.dna.fr/edition-de-strasbourg/2016/08/19/agression-antisemite|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=Darnières Nouvelles d'Alsace|language=French|quote=Il s'agit d'un déséquilibré de 44 ans, antisémite revendiqué}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Jacques Fortier|title=Strasbourg : un juif blessé par un antisémite récidiviste|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/societe/article/2016/08/20/strasbourg-un-juif-blesse-par-un-antisemite-recidiviste_4985385_3224.html|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=Le Monde|language=French|quote=l’agresseur semble ne rien avoir perdu de sa haine antisémite}}</ref> shouted "allahou akbar"<ref>{{cite news|last1=Michaël Bloch|title=Un juif religieux attaqué au couteau à Strasbourg|url=http://www.lejdd.fr/Societe/Un-juif-religieux-attaque-au-couteau-a-Strasbourg-804091|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=Le Journal du Dimanche|language=French|quote=Un juif religieux d'une soixantaine d'années a été blessé après avoir été attaqué au couteau à Strasbourg par un homme qui a crié "Allahou Akbar".}}</ref> (allah is great, in English), as he attacked a 62 year-old Jew wearing a [[kippa]] on avenue des Vosges.  The attacker had previously knifed another jew in 2010 in Kléber square.  The French Minister of the Interior, [[Bernard Cazeneuve]], called the rabbi of Strasbourg to express his "solidarity."  The attacker was said to have a history of mental problems.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jewish man stabbed on street in French city of Strasbourg|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-37132582|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=BBC|quote=A police source said the victim was in distinctive Jewish dress}}</ref><ref>https://pjmedia.com/homeland-security/2016/08/19/known-wolf-alert-man-who-stabbed-rabbi-in-strasbourg-shouting-allahu-akhbar-involved-in-prior-stabbing/</ref>  The attacker was charged the following day with «attempted murder because of the victim's appearance belonging to a race or religion>><ref>{{cite news|title=Strasbourg : l'auteur de l'agression au couteau contre un juif a été écroué|url=http://www.parismatch.com/Actu/Faits-divers/Strasbourg-l-auteur-de-l-agression-au-couteau-contre-un-juif-a-ete-ecroue-1043008|accessdate=23 August 2016|work=Paris Match|language=French|quote=le parquet de Strasbourg a annoncé samedi soir dans un communiqué avoir ouvert une information judiciaire «pour tentative de meurtre sur une victime en raison de son appartenance réelle ou supposée à une race ou à une religion»}}</ref>».</blockquote>

{{Reflist-talk}}

Thank you. -[[User:Dan Eisenberg|Dan Eisenberg]] ([[User talk:Dan Eisenberg|talk]]) 05:32, 25 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Featured list candidates#rfc_A0F8592|Wikipedia talk:Featured list candidates]] expired 2016-09-24 20:01 ===
* Id: A0F8592
* User: PresN
* Date: 2016-09-16 18:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|739751741|PROP 739751741}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|741009650|PROP 741009650}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
At the present time, the Featured List coordinators include one director ({{u|Giants2008}}) and three delegates ({{u|PresN}}, {{u|SchroCat}}, and {{u|Crisco 1492}}) to manage the [[WP:FLC|promotion]], [[WP:FLRC|delisting]], and [[WP:TFL|appearance on the front page]] Featured List processes. As SchroCat is leaving his position at the end of October, and Crisco has been unavailable for delegate work for some time, we are looking to add new delegates. To fill one slot, the coordinators would like to nominate a specific editor for the position, in the same manner as I (PresN) was [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia_talk:Featured_list_candidates&diff=656727682&oldid=655317456 nominated] in April 2015.

Therefore, '''it is proposed that {{u|FrB.TG}} is promoted to the role of FL delegate'''. We feel that they have been a large presence around the process for some time, with 29 Featured Lists to their credit and numerous reviews, and would be a welcome addition to the project.

'''Timescale''': All comments are invited on this proposal, which will run until ''23:59, 26 September 2015'', UTC. –-'''[[User:PresN|<span style="color:green">Pres</span>]][[User talk:PresN|<span style="color:blue">N</span>]]''' 18:25, 16 September 2016 (UTC)}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|743257947|POL 743257947}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Can anyone propose any specific improvements to the following proposed text?  
Do you think it should be added to this page?  Why or why not?  

Thank you for the time invested in responding to this request for comment!  
 
<blockquote>The [[Clinton Foundation]] has been involved in Haiti both before and after the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]] with mixed results.<ref name="KQ_Haiti">{{cite web|last1=Katz|first1=Jonathan|title=The King and Queen of Haiti|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2015/05/clinton-foundation-haiti-117368|website=Politico|accessdate=September 21, 2016|date=May 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Katz|first1=Jonathan|title=The Big Truck That Went By: How the World Came to Save Haiti and Left Behind a Disaster|date=2013|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=978-0-230-34187-6|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?310297-1/big-truck-went|accessdate=September 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Katz|first1=Jonathan|title=The Clintons’ Haiti Screw-Up, As Told By Hillary’s Emails|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2015/09/hillary-clinton-email-213110|website=Politico|accessdate=September 21, 2016|date=September 2, 2015}}</ref>. The Clinton Foundation and the US State Department's role in the creation of the [[Caracol, Nord-Est#Caracol Industrial Park|Caracol Industrial Park]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Haiti Libre Staff|title=Haiti - Economy : The SONAPI proud of its Caracol Industrial Park|url=http://www.haitilibre.com/en/news-6984-haiti-economy-the-sonapi-proud-of-its-caracol-industrial-park.html|website=Haiti Libre|accessdate=22 September 2016|date=24 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Hillary Clinton|title=Remarks at the Caracol Industrial Park Opening Ceremony|url=http://www.state.gov/secretary/20092013clinton/rm/2012/10/199451.htm|website=US Department of State|accessdate=September 23, 2016|date=October 22, 2012}}</ref> has been the source of significant criticism.<ref name="KQ_Haiti" /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Johnston|first1=Jake|title=Outsourcing Haiti: How disaster relief became a disaster of its own|url=http://www.bostonreview.net/world/jake-johnston-haiti-earthquake-aid-caracol|website=Boston Review|accessdate=September 22, 2016|date=January 16, 2014}}</ref> During Clinton's tenure at the State department,  the US Embassy, US AID, and the State Department opposed raising the minimum wage in Haiti.<ref>{{cite web|author1=CEPR staff|title=Ten Things Cheryl Mills May Prefer You Not Know About Haiti Today|url=http://cepr.net/blogs/haiti-relief-and-reconstruction-watch/ten-things-cheryl-mills-may-prefer-you-not-know-about-haiti-today|website=CEPR: Center for Economic Policy and Research|accessdate=September 23, 2016|date=January 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Dan Coughlin|author2=Kim Ives|title=WikiLeaks Haiti: Let Them Live on $3 a Day|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/wikileaks-haiti-let-them-live-3-day/|website=[[The Nation]]|accessdate=September 22, 2016|date=June 1, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Dan Coughlin|author2=Kim Ives|title=Washington Backed Famous Brand-Name Contractors in Fight Against Haiti’s Minimum Wage Increase|url=http://www.haiti-liberte.com/archives/volume4-47/Washington%20Backed%20Famous.asp|website=Haiti Liberté|accessdate=September 22, 2016|date=25 May 2011|volume=4|number=45}}</ref> After the minimum wage was raised despite this opposition, garment factories across the country, including at Caracol Industrial Park, have not been applying the law.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Claire Lauterbach|author2=Elaine Zuckerman|title=Caracol Industrial Park Social and Gender Impacts of Year One of Haiti’s newest IFI - funded Industrial Park|url=http://www.genderaction.org/publications/caracol.pdf|website=GenderAction|publisher=Gender Action|accessdate=September 23, 2016|date=2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Regan|first1=Jane|title=Wage Hike in Haiti Doesn’t Address Factory Abuses|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2013/12/wage-hike-haiti-doesnt-address-factory-abuses/|website=InterPress Service|accessdate=September 23, 2016|date=December 3, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Katz|first1=Jonathan|title=A glittering industrial park in Haiti falls short|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2013/9/10/a-glittering-industrialparkfallsshortinhaiti.html|website=Al Jazeera|accessdate=September 23, 2016|date=September 10, 2013|quote=In fact, the question of minimum wage could be another drag on investors' interest. Under a recently enacted law, the minimum wage should now be roughly $6.85 a day for garment work. But factory owners have simply refused to pay the higher wages. A recent survey by the International Labor Organization found not a single factory in Haiti currently complying with the new law. Sae-A declined to comment on particulars, stating only that its employees "are compensated in accordance with local laws and regulations."}}</ref></blockquote>

[[User:SashiRolls|SashiRolls]] ([[User talk:SashiRolls|talk]]) 16:37, 24 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Category talk:People of Jewish descent#rfc_455701D|Category talk:People of Jewish descent]] expired 2016-09-25 17:01 ===
* Id: 455701D
* User: Debresser
* Date: 2016-09-25 13:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|741124568|UNSORTED 741124568}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|741138649|UNSORTED 741138649}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In 2014 there was a very long discussion on this same talkpage, should [[:Category:People of Middle Eastern descent]] be added to this category. Obviously nobody disagrees that the Middle East is the cradle of Judaism and the Jewish people, but that is not the same. The conclusion of that discussion, in which both sides had several proponents, was that there is no consensus for the "Middle East" category. The category, that was added originally in 2012, was not removed at after that discussion, for reasons that do not matter much at this moment. The arguments against its inclusion remain the same, and are basically two-fold:
# Jews do not consider themselves to be of Middle Eastern descent.
# There have been many proselytes over the ages, making it doubtful (to a very high degree) that any person of Jewish descent is in fact of Middle Eastern descent.

The first point can benefit from some explanation. Jews who emigrated from Germany to, let's say, Israel or the United States, will call themselves German Jews. And the same for Jews from Syria, e.g., who call themselves [[Chalabi Jews]] wherever they are. But that is as far as it goes! Nobody ''knows'' in which countries their forefathers from more than a few generations ago lived, ''and nobody cares''! Certainly, if you'd ask any Jew straightforward, if they are of Middle Eastern decent, nobody would say they are because of the mere fact of being a Jew alone.

To further illustrate this point I retold a known Jewish joke in the previous discussion, about two Jews, let's say both 100% [[Ashkenazic]] Jews, where one tells the other: "Do you know you are an Iraqi Jew?" and then when the other guy vehemently denies he says "All Jews are descended from [[Abraham]] who came from [[Ur]] which is in [[Iraq]]". A similar proof [[ad absurdum]] regards mankind as a whole: most scientific and genetic research agrees that man comes from Africa, and nevertheless, not all "of .. descent" categories are part of "People of African descent", and it would be ridiculous to impose that scientific fact on descent categories, and the same is true in this case. The more so that in this case, where it is not a sure fact at all, in view of the second point regarding proselytes.

I propose to reach a conclusion that there is no place for "Middle East" categories, and per the same token "West Asian" or "Asian" categories, on any of the "Jewish descent" categories. There is at present no conformity on this issue in all of the "Jewish descent" categories, and of the many "Jewish descent" categories, some have one or more of the above. This Rfc strives to reach a conclusion that would be binding for all of them, and in my opinion that conclusion should be that those categories are out of place on all "Jewish descent" categories. [[User:Debresser|Debresser]] ([[User talk:Debresser|talk]]) 13:20, 25 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Axis: Bold as Love#rfc_DAB77B4|Talk:Axis: Bold as Love]] expired 2016-09-26 03:01 ===

This issue is being raised in response to {{u|GentleCollapse16}}'s recent removal of those three genres. [[User:Dan56|Dan56]] ([[User talk:Dan56|talk]]) 02:29, 27 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_D35E0CB|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2016-09-26 14:01 ===
* Id: D35E0CB
* User: NasssaNser
* Date: 2016-09-26 11:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|741264949|UNSORTED 741264949}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|741277980|UNSORTED 741277980}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have discovered a lot of templates that when a user prefers to be "gender-neutral", the template will use "they" instead of "it", which looks like that there are '''multiple''' people using the same account.

These templates include several from the [[Template:UAA|UAA]] series of templates, userboxes like [[Template:User not brave not admin|this]], and others.

I think that we should replace "they"s with "it"s, but want to know whether others agree.

[[User:NasssaNser|NasssaNser]] (<sup>[[User talk:NasssaNser|talk]]</sup>/<sub>[[Special:Contribs/NasssaNser|edits]]</sub>) 11:38, 26 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Jill Stein#rfc_9F464B0|Talk:Jill Stein]] expired 2016-09-27 13:01 ===
* Id: 9F464B0
* User: Snooganssnoogans
* Date: 2016-08-28 12:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|736584303|BIO 736584303}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|736584307|POL 736584307}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|741430042|BIO 741430042}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|741430044|POL 741430044}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As is the case when candidates make factually inaccurate claims, Wikipedia allows content from reliable sources to correct those claims. The Political positions of Donald Trump[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_positions_of_Donald_Trump] and Political positions of Hillary Clinton[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_positions_of_Hillary_Clinton] are full of this kind of content (just ctrl+F "PolitiFact", "Factcheck.org", "false" and so on). There is therefore no reason to remove the the content in bold which has caught attention by RS and been corrected:

* Stein accepts the scientific consensus on climate change, calling it a "national emergency".<ref name=":03" /> '''''[[FactCheck.org|Factcheck.org]]'' and the Washington Post fact-checker have however found that Stein has exaggerated the extent of projected global sea level rise due to climate change.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.factcheck.org/2016/08/stein-over-the-top-on-sea-level-rise/|title=Stein Over the Top on Sea Level Rise|website=www.factcheck.org|access-date=2016-08-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/energy-environment/wp/2016/08/17/jill-stein-just-went-overboard-on-sea-level-rise/|title=Jill Stein just went way overboard on sea level rise|website=Washington Post|access-date=2016-08-26}}</ref>''' She has described the [[Paris Agreement|Paris Climate Agreement]] as inadequate, saying it will not stop climate change.<ref name=":03" /> She has proposed to override the agreement and create a more effective one.<ref name=":03" />
* Stein has argued that the cost of transitioning to 100% renewable energy by 2030 would in part be recouped by healthcare savings, citing the experience of Cuba when it lost Soviet oil subsidies and Cubans experienced improvements in health outcomes.<ref name=":03" /> '''The Washington Post editorial board argued that "she improbably cited Cuba’s experience", noting that Cubans "became healthier because they could no longer afford to smoke or drink alcohol and because so many involuntarily lost weight."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/jill-steins-fairy-tale-candidacy/2016/08/25/3bf8ba1a-6b08-11e6-99bf-f0cf3a6449a6_story.html?hpid=hp_no-name_opinion-card-b%253Ahomepage%252Fstory&utm_term=.dac83ae6f609|title=Jill Stein’s fairy-tale candidacy|last=Board|first=Editorial|date=2016-08-25|newspaper=The Washington Post|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286|access-date=2016-08-26}}</ref>'''

It is not a violation of neutrality (as Wukai claimed when he removed this content) to correct false and misleading claims that candidates make in support of their positions. Should Donald Trump's false claims about climate change be allowed to stand without correction? If not, why should Stein's? If Clinton can't be allowed to make false claims about healthcare costs, solar energy, charter schools etc., why should Stein be allowed to make misleading health claims about her energy plan?  [[User:Snooganssnoogans|Snooganssnoogans]] ([[User talk:Snooganssnoogans|talk]]) 12:49, 28 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:New pages patrol/RfC for patroller right#rfc_4F5A3A2|Wikipedia:New pages patrol/RfC for patroller right]] expired 2016-09-27 15:01 ===
* Id: 4F5A3A2
* Date: 2016-08-28 14:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|736561419|PROP 736561419}}

=== [[Talk:Denial of the Holodomor#rfc_550D2E8|Talk:Denial of the Holodomor]] expired 2016-09-30 04:01 ===
* Id: 550D2E8
* User: Kingsindian
* Date: 2016-08-31 03:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|738575006|BIO 738575006}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|738575013|HIST 738575013}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|738575027|POL 738575027}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|741864648|BIO 741864648}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|741864655|HIST 741864655}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|741864660|POL 741864660}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the "Douglas Tottle and Others" section contain the following?
<blockquote>According to Canadian historians, "Eventually Tottle’s book lost credibility in all but the fringe Stalinist circles, but in the late 1980s material from it appeared in the American “Village Voice”<ref name="conlon">[[Jeff Coplon]], [http://www.chss.montclair.edu/English/furr/vv.html "In Search of a Soviet Holocaust"], ''[[The Village Voice]]'', January 12, 1988.</ref> and various student newspapers in Canada" [https://web.archive.org/web/20110706211152/http://www.ukrainianstudies.uottawa.ca/pdf/P_Serbyn_Danyliw07.pdf]. According to [[Cathy Young]], "the West has its own inglorious history with regard to the famine, starting with the deliberate cover-up by Pulitzer Prize-winning New York Times correspondent Walter Duranty. In the late 1980s, the famine gained new visibility thanks to [[Robert Conquest]]'s [[The Harvest of Sorrow]]: Soviet Collectivization and the Terror-Famine (1987) and the TV documentary Harvest of Despair, aired in the United States and Canada. A backlash from the left was quick to follow. Revisionist Sovietologist [[J. Arch Getty]] accused Conquest of parroting the propaganda of "exiled nationalists." And in January 1988, the [[Village Voice]] ran a lengthy essay by [[Jeff Coplon]] (now a contributing editor at New York magazine) titled "In Search of a Soviet Holocaust: A 55-Year-Old Famine Feeds the Right." Coplon sneered at "the prevailing vogue of anti-Stalinism" and dismissed as absurd the idea that the famine had been created by the Communist regime. Such talk, he asserted, was meant to justify U.S. imperialism and whitewash Ukrainian collaboration with the Nazis."<ref>{{cite web|author=Cathy Young |author-link=Cathy Young |url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/Content/Public/Articles/000/000/015/861rmjep.asp |title=Remember the Holodomor: The Soviet starvation of Ukraine, 75 years later |volume=14, No. 12 |publisher=The Weekly Standard |date=8 December 2008 |accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref> In a letter to the editors, [[Robert Conquest]] dismissed the article by Coplon as "error and absurdity".<ref>{{cite news|first=Robert|last=Conquest|author-link=Robert Conquest|publisher=Village Voice|location=New York|date=February 2, 1988|title=Letters to the editors|url=http://www.scribd.com/doc/16317836/The-Ukrainian-Weekly-198808|deadurl=unfit|archiveurl=https://wayback.archive.org/web/20151118072744/https://www.scribd.com/doc/16317836/The-Ukrainian-Weekly-1988-08|archivedate=18 November 2016}} – Reprinted by the ''[[The Ukrainian Weekly]]'', February 21, 1988</ref></blockquote>
[[User:Kingsindian|Kingsindian]]&nbsp;[[User Talk: Kingsindian|&#9821;]]&nbsp;[[Special:Contributions/Kingsindian|&#9818;]] 03:11, 31 August 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016#rfc_D512DA7|Talk:Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2016]] expired 2016-10-01 07:01 ===
* Id: D512DA7
* User: CFredkin
* Date: 2016-09-12 17:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|739082526|POL 739082526}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following statement be added to the "Controversies" section of this article:

At a fundraiser on September 9, 2016, Clinton stated "You know, to just be grossly generalistic, you could put half of Trump's supporters into what I call the basket of deplorables. Right? The racist, sexist, homophobic, xenophobic, Islamophobic — you name it."<ref>{{cite web |title=Hillary Clinton's 'Basket Of Deplorables,' In Full Context Of This Ugly Campaign |url=http://www.npr.org/2016/09/10/493427601/hillary-clintons-basket-of-deplorables-in-full-context-of-this-ugly-campaign |work=NPR |date=September 10, 2016 |accessdate=September 12, 2016}}</ref>  Clinton's comment was criticized by her opponents, and the following day she stated that she regretted saying 'half', and added "It’s deplorable that Trump has built his campaign largely on prejudice and paranoia and given a national platform to hateful views and voices, including by retweeting fringe bigots with a few dozen followers and spreading their message to 11 million people."<ref>{{cite web |title=Hillary Clinton Says She Regrets Part of Her ‘Deplorables’ Comment |url=http://time.com/4486601/hillary-clinton-donald-trump-basket-of-deplorables-half/ |work=Time |date=September 10, 2016 |accessdate=September 12, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Hillary Clinton Calls Many Trump Backers 'Deplorables,' and GOP Pounces |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/11/us/politics/hillary-clinton-basket-of-deplorables.html?_r=0 |work=New York Times |date=September 10, 2016 |accessdate=September 12, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Conservatives, progressives battle over ‘deplorables,’ leaving quote itself behind |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/09/12/left-and-right-battle-over-deplorables-leaving-the-quote-itself-behind/ |work=Washington Post |date=September 10, 2016 |accessdate=September 12, 2016}}</ref>[[User:CFredkin|CFredkin]] ([[User talk:CFredkin|talk]]) 17:37, 12 September 2016 (UTC)}}

Hello, I created two different discussions (maybe should have made one in retrospect) over on the noticeboards relating to a long standing (ad nauseam) discussion on this talk page (and archives) relating to if this page is [[WP:FRINGE]] (as is claimed by {{Ping|David Gerard}} and thus higher standards [[WP:FRIND]] sources must be used (largely excluding industry rag publications such as [[CoinDesk]] and [[CoinTelegraph]]). === [[Talk:Cedar Fire (2003)#rfc_8266959|Talk:Cedar Fire (2003)]] expired 2016-10-06 03:01 ===
* Id: 8266959
* User: Zackmann08
* Date: 2016-09-06 02:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|738575013|HIST 738575013}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|742835974|HIST 742835974}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am in the process of cleaning up this article in hopes of getting it to [[WP:GA]] status. One of the last main things that needs to be addressed is the list of fatalities. Now lets get one thing clear, no one is suggesting the loss of life is not tragic. The question here is does a LIST of those killed warrant placement in this article? If so, how and in what format. I took a look at [[WP:USEPROSE]] (thanks {{user|David Eppstein}} for pointing me there!) and it states ''Prose is preferred in articles as prose allows the presentation of detail and clarification of context, in a way that a simple list may not.'' Now I would like to point out the last 2 words '''''may''' not''. It is possible that a list is still the right format here. I am having a hard time seeing what would be gained by having a bunch of sequential sentences that give the name, age and location of death for each of the 15 people killed. I took a look at a couple of other articles that contain large lists of individuals killed: [[Yarnell Hill Fire]], [[Charles Whitman]] and [[Virginia Tech shooting]]. Each of these use a box on the right side of the page to list the names (not sure what the technical name for this box is... Not an infobox and not a navbox...). I am very much leaning in this direction. 

My proposal is to rewrite the [[Cedar Fire (2003)#Fatalities|fatalities section]] to have a paragraph or so about the causes of death, how the fire spread faster than predicted, how people thought they had time they didn't really have, etc. (All well referenced of course). Then to have a side box that contains a list of the killed to include Name, age and both date and location of death. Perhaps broken up by date. I welcome any and all feedback! --[[User:Zackmann08|<span style="color:DarkTurquoise;">Zackmann08</span>]] (<sup>[[User_talk:Zackmann08|Talk to me]]</sup>/<sub>[[Special:Contributions/Zackmann08|<span style="color:orange;">What I been doing</span>]]</sub>) 02:37, 6 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of awareness ribbons#rfc_C29DBCD|Talk:List of awareness ribbons]] expired 2016-10-08 10:01 ===
* Id: C29DBCD
* Date: 2016-09-08 09:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|738575033|SOC 738575033}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|743183210|SOC 743183210}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This list contains many entries which are plainly not in the least bit significant, large numbers sourced only to the organisation promoting the ribbon, a fair number sourced to blogs or other unreliable sources, and quite a few that have no source at all.

I think that as a matter of curating this content we need to adopt a firm and straightforward rule for inclusion: I propose that the following criterion is used:
; Each entry must be supported by one or more [[WP:RS|reliable independent sources]] establishing the significance and context of the ribbon campaign. Unsourced entries will be removed.
In fact this should be true of all content in Wikipedia but the issue here is the constant addition of poorly sourced content by well-meaning newcomers so I think we need to establish a precedent of removing unsourced or poorly sourced content. <b>[[User Talk:JzG|Guy]]</b> <small>([[User:JzG/help|Help!]])</small> 09:26, 8 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Songs#rfc_2EB593D|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Songs]] expired 2016-10-08 20:01 ===
* Id: 2EB593D
* User: Ojorojo
* Date: 2016-09-08 19:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|738575037|POLICY 738575037}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|738575038|TECH 738575038}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|743250769|POLICY 743250769}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|743250772|TECH 743250772}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It is unclear how the addition of "cover versions" and "alt Artist" fields is supposed to benefit song articles.  There are now 15 new fields for "covers": 5 for "alt Artist", 5 for "Recorded by", and 5 for "Performed by".  No guidance was provided and "alt Artist" seems to duplicate the "Recorded by" or "Performed by" fields.  Besides these overlaps, "cover songs" (even the use of the term) is a problem area in song articles.  [[WP:SONGCOVER]], which provides guidelines for the addition of song renditions to articles, is routinely ignored.  Large numbers of "covers", regardless of suitability and lacking sources, are added to articles.  Providing fields for cover versions in the infobox would compound the problem.

Except regarding the merger of Infobox standard with Infobox song,[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia%3ATemplates_for_discussion%2FLog%2F2014_July_30&type=revision&diff=620184563&oldid=620184535] the addition of cover versions was not discussed.
On March 16, 2015,&nbsp;"Cover versions" and "alt Artist" were added, along with the infobox standard parameters "Recorded by" and "Performed by".[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template%3AInfobox_song&type=revision&diff=651677830&oldid=604742131][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template%3AInfobox_song%2Fdoc&type=revision&diff=651676326&oldid=604741950] On July 18, 2016, these were expanded to include "alt Artist2–5", "Recorded by2–5", and "Performed by2–5", with the edit note "Support up to 5 cover versions".[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Infobox_song&diff=next&oldid=730294138]  Since this is a relatively new addition, it may have seen little or no use, so removing these parameters should not be disruptive and may be cleaned up easily.  Please indicate '''Support''' to remove or '''Oppose''' to retain "Cover versions"/"alt Artists" from {{tl|infobox song}}. —[[User:Ojorojo|Ojorojo]] ([[User talk:Ojorojo|talk]]) 19:25, 8 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Michael Gastauer#rfc_CC25DF1|Talk:Michael Gastauer]] expired 2016-10-09 14:01 ===
* Id: CC25DF1
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|743375281|BIO 743375281}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|743384420|BIO 743384420}}
* RFC Text:

The current article contains a number of claims that either have no source, or the source is a quote from Mr. Gastauer himself in an interview. Example claims would be that Mr. Gastauer is one of the 50 richest people in Germany, and that he has sold a company for $480m. Several news articles have raised doubts about these claims and disclosed allegations of fraud and wrongdoing, a lawsuit, and an arrest in relation to past business ventures, including pieces in the [[Financial Times]], [[Suddeutsche Zeitung]], and [[Neue Zürcher Zeitung]]. A number of editors are repeatedly removing references to these articles and their doubts, and restoring the article so that it only contains positive information. Should references to these articles raising doubt be included in this article?

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Automobiles#rfc_DB2A03F|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Automobiles]] expired 2016-10-09 21:01 ===
* Id: DB2A03F
* User: Springee
* Date: 2016-09-09 19:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|738575010|ECON 738575010}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|738575019|SCI 738575019}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|743477690|ECON 743477690}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|743477760|SCI 743477760}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This RFC covers two automotive articles with similar disputed material.  Please comment on either or both additions (please indicate an article if comments don't apply to both).  

*Should the Ford [[Ford F-650]] medium duty truck article include a mention in the body of the text or via a see also link the [[Oklahoma_City_bombing|Oklahoma City bombing]]?
*Should the [[Chevrolet Caprice]] article mention in the body or via a see also link the [[Beltway_sniper_attacks|Beltway Sniper]]'s use of a Chevrolet Caprice?

The specific addition to the Ford F-650 intro section page is below [[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ford_F-650&diff=737968318&oldid=736828156]]:
::''A 1993 [[Ford F-700]] was used in the 1995 [[Oklahoma City bombing]]. The truck's key code and axle serial number became significant evidence in the trial of [[Timothy McVeigh]].

::* {{Citation |newspaper=[[The Denver Post]] |url= http://extras.denverpost.com/bomb/bomb216.htm |title= Key a 'stroke of genius' |first= Peter G. |last= Chronis }}
::* {{Citation |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |title=Vehicles That Left Telltale Evidence Behind |first=Marcia |last=Berman |date= July 20, 2001 |url= http://www.nytimes.com/2001/07/20/automobiles/vehicles-that-left-telltale-evidence-behind.html }}

The specific addition to the Chevrolet Caprice page as a section titled ''Famous Owners'' is below [[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chevrolet_Caprice&diff=738251974&oldid=737142598]]:
::''The [[Beltway sniper attacks]] used a 1990 blue Caprice as a mobile snipers' nest. The car had been modified with a special opening for the rifle to shoot out the back of the trunk, and the back seat had been altered to allow entry to the trunk from within the passenger compartment. The snipers were abducted by the FBI while they slept in it. The events inspired a 2013 motion picture, ''[[Blue Caprice]]''.

::* {{cite news|last1=Harris|first1=Aisha|title=Brow Beat Slate's Culture Blog Sept. 13 2013 8:12 PM How Accurate Is the New Movie About the D.C. Snipers?|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2013/09/13/blue_caprice_true_story_fact_and_fiction_in_mostly_accurate_isaiah_washington.html|accessdate=7 September 2016|work=Slate|date=September 13, 2013}}
::* {{cite news|last1=Ruane|first1=Michael E.|last2=Horwitz|first2=Sari|title=In the End, Caprice Lost Its Invisibility|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/2003/10/08/in-the-end-caprice-lost-its-invisibility/a7bb5a70-0a44-4ba7-9183-2a8f2be98126/|accessdate=7 September 2016|work=Washington Post|date=October 8, 2003}}

[[User:Springee|Springee]] ([[User talk:Springee|talk]]) 19:29, 9 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Michael Gastauer#rfc_FC78502|Talk:Michael Gastauer]] expired 2016-10-10 04:01 ===
* Id: FC78502
* User: Fin3999
* Date: 2016-10-09 09:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|743403195|ECON 743403195}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|743544821|BIO 743544821}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|743544822|ECON 743544822}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
RFC - should news reports casting doubt on Mr. Gastauer's claims of business success be included in the article?

The current article contains a number of claims that either have no source, or the source is a quote from Mr. Gastauer himself in an interview. Example claims would be that Mr. Gastauer is one of the 50 richest people in Germany, and that he has sold a company for $480m. Several news articles have raised doubts about these claims and disclosed allegations of fraud and wrongdoing, a lawsuit, and an arrest in relation to past business ventures, including pieces in the [http://ftalphaville.ft.com/2016/10/03/2176457/farewell-wb21-we-hardly-knew-ya/ Financial Times], [http://www.gruenderszene.de/allgemein/wb21-fintech-michael-gastauer Grunderszene], [http://www.sueddeutsche.de/wirtschaft/finanzen-die-zweifelhafte-geschichte-eines-muenchner-star-unternehmers-1.3193207 Suddeutsche Zeitung,] and [http://www.manager-magazin.de/unternehmen/it/fintech-startup-wb21-weltbank-ohne-banklizenz-a-1115337.html manager-magazin.de]. A number of editors are repeatedly removing references to these articles and their doubts, and restoring the article so that it only contains positive information. Should references to these articles raising doubt be included in this article?

Relevant documents from United States Connecticut District Court case number 3:12-cv-00118, Apax Global Payment & Tech Ltd et al v. Arnold:
* [https://www.docdroid.net/UHTWoFf/19-main.pdf.html 19-Main], quote from Apax UK court-appointed liquidators that "the assets of Apax UK have been misappropriated" (page 11)
* [https://www.docdroid.net/E9yz6og/19-20-arnold-affadavit.pdf.html 19-20], affidavit from Apax UK and WB21 Chief Compliance Officer Peter Arnold stating that Michael Gastauer used the alias Michael Van Rijn, supposedly the CFO of Apax (page 1)
[[User:Fin3999|Fin3999]] ([[User talk:Fin3999|talk]]) 09:39, 9 October 2016 (UTC)}}
