{{rfcquote|text=
Can anyone propose any specific improvements to the following proposed text?  
Do you think it should be added to this page?  Why or why not?  

Thank you for the time invested in responding to this request for comment!  
 
<blockquote>The [[Clinton Foundation]] has been involved in Haiti both before and after the [[2010 Haiti earthquake]] with mixed results.<ref name="KQ_Haiti">{{cite web|last1=Katz|first1=Jonathan|title=The King and Queen of Haiti|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2015/05/clinton-foundation-haiti-117368|website=Politico|accessdate=September 21, 2016|date=May 4, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Katz|first1=Jonathan|title=The Big Truck That Went By: How the World Came to Save Haiti and Left Behind a Disaster|date=2013|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=978-0-230-34187-6|url=https://www.c-span.org/video/?310297-1/big-truck-went|accessdate=September 21, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Katz|first1=Jonathan|title=The Clintons’ Haiti Screw-Up, As Told By Hillary’s Emails|url=http://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2015/09/hillary-clinton-email-213110|website=Politico|accessdate=September 21, 2016|date=September 2, 2015}}</ref>. The Clinton Foundation and the US State Department's role in the creation of the [[Caracol, Nord-Est#Caracol Industrial Park|Caracol Industrial Park]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Haiti Libre Staff|title=Haiti - Economy : The SONAPI proud of its Caracol Industrial Park|url=http://www.haitilibre.com/en/news-6984-haiti-economy-the-sonapi-proud-of-its-caracol-industrial-park.html|website=Haiti Libre|accessdate=22 September 2016|date=24 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Hillary Clinton|title=Remarks at the Caracol Industrial Park Opening Ceremony|url=http://www.state.gov/secretary/20092013clinton/rm/2012/10/199451.htm|website=US Department of State|accessdate=September 23, 2016|date=October 22, 2012}}</ref> has been the source of significant criticism.<ref name="KQ_Haiti" /><ref>{{cite web|last1=Johnston|first1=Jake|title=Outsourcing Haiti: How disaster relief became a disaster of its own|url=http://www.bostonreview.net/world/jake-johnston-haiti-earthquake-aid-caracol|website=Boston Review|accessdate=September 22, 2016|date=January 16, 2014}}</ref> During Clinton's tenure at the State department,  the US Embassy, US AID, and the State Department opposed raising the minimum wage in Haiti.<ref>{{cite web|author1=CEPR staff|title=Ten Things Cheryl Mills May Prefer You Not Know About Haiti Today|url=http://cepr.net/blogs/haiti-relief-and-reconstruction-watch/ten-things-cheryl-mills-may-prefer-you-not-know-about-haiti-today|website=CEPR: Center for Economic Policy and Research|accessdate=September 23, 2016|date=January 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author1=Dan Coughlin|author2=Kim Ives|title=WikiLeaks Haiti: Let Them Live on $3 a Day|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/wikileaks-haiti-let-them-live-3-day/|website=[[The Nation]]|accessdate=September 22, 2016|date=June 1, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Dan Coughlin|author2=Kim Ives|title=Washington Backed Famous Brand-Name Contractors in Fight Against Haiti’s Minimum Wage Increase|url=http://www.haiti-liberte.com/archives/volume4-47/Washington%20Backed%20Famous.asp|website=Haiti Liberté|accessdate=September 22, 2016|date=25 May 2011|volume=4|number=45}}</ref> After the minimum wage was raised despite this opposition, garment factories across the country, including at Caracol Industrial Park, have not been applying the law.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Claire Lauterbach|author2=Elaine Zuckerman|title=Caracol Industrial Park Social and Gender Impacts of Year One of Haiti’s newest IFI - funded Industrial Park|url=http://www.genderaction.org/publications/caracol.pdf|website=GenderAction|publisher=Gender Action|accessdate=September 23, 2016|date=2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Regan|first1=Jane|title=Wage Hike in Haiti Doesn’t Address Factory Abuses|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2013/12/wage-hike-haiti-doesnt-address-factory-abuses/|website=InterPress Service|accessdate=September 23, 2016|date=December 3, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Katz|first1=Jonathan|title=A glittering industrial park in Haiti falls short|url=http://america.aljazeera.com/articles/2013/9/10/a-glittering-industrialparkfallsshortinhaiti.html|website=Al Jazeera|accessdate=September 23, 2016|date=September 10, 2013|quote=In fact, the question of minimum wage could be another drag on investors' interest. Under a recently enacted law, the minimum wage should now be roughly $6.85 a day for garment work. But factory owners have simply refused to pay the higher wages. A recent survey by the International Labor Organization found not a single factory in Haiti currently complying with the new law. Sae-A declined to comment on particulars, stating only that its employees "are compensated in accordance with local laws and regulations."}}</ref></blockquote>

{{reflist-talk}}
[[User:SashiRolls|SashiRolls]] ([[User talk:SashiRolls|talk]]) 16:37, 24 September 2016 (UTC)}}

I recently created [[WP:TDFTF|Tour de France task force]] as a central point for everything Tour de France, so please add you name to the [[WP:TDFTF#Members|members list]] if this interests you. === [[Talk:Leninism#rfc_66B40E9|Talk:Leninism]] expired 2016-10-11 11:01 ===
* Id: 66B40E9
* User: CrisisSandwich
* Date: 2016-09-26 01:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|741334523|HIST 741334523}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|743806482|HIST 743806482}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I think this section gives as it stands doesn't really clarify what Leninism is nor concerns around the theory. It reads like one side of a debate, when the observer isn't even here for it. I think that the section doesn't belong on this article and instead this should be redirected to criticism of another page or within the page. Furthermore, it doesn't really provide insights into the theory, Leninism, but rather a somewhat non-relevant historical account of what Stalin did wrong. While no doubt an important area of scholarship in its own right doesn't fit when discussing political philosophy of Lenin. It might be good under a page on Stalinism. The Philosophical successor component should be merged, but the exact mentions of a couple smaller communist parties removed and replaced with mentions around Mao Zedong Thought(Maoism) and albeit somewhat fringe: Hoxhaism. I propose delete deleting the existing paragraphs ins in this section and replacing it with the following verbage in bold:

'''In post–[[October Revolution|Revolutionary]] Russia, [[Marxism-Leninism]], which detractors at that time referred to as [[Stalinism]], and [[Trotskyism]] were the immediate principal philosophies of [[Communism]] that claimed legitimate ideological descent from Leninism. This lead to different tendencies to develop as factions within the Communist Party, each ideological faction denied the [[Legitimacy (political)|political legitimacy]] of the opposing faction.<ref>''Chambers Dictionary of World History'' (2000) p. 837.</ref> In the Soviet Union, [[Marxism-Leninism]] ended up winning authority. This political philosophy was likewise adopted internationally by Communist parties who belonged to the [[Comintern]]. Trotskyism found its voice through its own international forum, called the [[Forth International]].

'''Internationally, in the decades after the death of Lenin other political philosophies claimed descendancy from Leninism, including Mao Zedong thought, otherwise known as [[Maoism]], and [[Hoxhaism]].
'''
'''In academic settings, various fields of international relation studies, such as [[Dependency theory]] and later on [[World System Theory]], have been said to be inspired by Lenin's book [[Imperialism, the Highest Stage of Capitalism]].'''

I think this would provide a much more concise section, remove issues around undue weight, remove mentions of small political parties(it would be impossible to provide a full list of every Lenin inspired political party), and allow for a better understanding of the topic. It would also upon up the topic for future expansion from academic fields that utilize Leninist philosophy instead of a debate around the vices and virtues of trotsky and stalin.
{{Reflist talk}}

[[User:CrisisSandwich|CrisisSandwich]] ([[User talk:CrisisSandwich|talk]]) 01:30, 26 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Impact of the privatisation of British Rail#rfc_7DAB109|Talk:Impact of the privatisation of British Rail]] expired 2016-10-11 13:01 ===
* Id: 7DAB109
* User: Mathmensch
* Date: 2016-09-11 11:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|738847649|SCI 738847649}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|743820065|SCI 743820065}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Recently, I strove to make this article more neutral by inserting a diagram which plainly shows state subsidy, instead of dividing out the passenger kilometers which is increased to help the operators gain more money, with the effect that passengers must travel in more crowded trains. In this way, it would become apparent that state subsidy for the railway (which is what the diagram says it measures) has actually increased by a dramatic amount; this fact is hidden in the way the current diagram is "normalized". I urge bypassers to remind the coauthors who have obstructed myself of the principles of wikipedia, in particular [[WP:NPOV]], which indicates that diagrams should not be used to make a point for the privatisation by "massaging" them so that the increase in subsidy seems less severe. --[[User:Mathmensch|Mathmensch]] ([[User talk:Mathmensch|talk]]) 11:36, 11 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Cary Grant#rfc_2845952|Talk:Cary Grant]] expired 2016-10-12 17:01 ===
* Id: 2845952
* User: Engleham
* Date: 2016-09-12 15:08:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|739064896|BIO 739064896}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|744021170|BIO 744021170}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In the Personal Section: propose the following be added: "In 1921 Grant moved into the [[Greenwich Village]] apartment of Australian Orry George Kelly, later to be known as the Hollywood designer [[Orry-Kelly]]: the apartment was also shared with a fellow Australian, Charles 'Spangles' Phelps, a cross-dressing performer. Kelly and Grant lived together for five years, and it has been speculated they were lovers, but Kelly lost respect for Grant: he was particularly incensed by Grant's subsequent avoidance of military duty during World War II, and their friendship ended badly."  References are Kelly's own biography, recently discovered and published this year, and these additional sources:

Orry-Kelly ''Women I've Undressed: The Fabulous Life and Times of a Legendary Hollywood Designer'', Allen & Unwin, 2016; [http://www.smh.com.au/lifestyle/fashion/unravelling-secrets-of-man-who-dressed-the-stars-20121215-2bghp.html]; [http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/review/naked-truths-in-hollywood-costume-designer-orrykellys-memoir/news-story/0a965fad9a0a6dce64ec6dc9a1115f75]; [http://adb.anu.edu.au/biography/kelly-orry-george-jack-10677]; Eliot, Mark ''Cary Grant: A Biography'', Three Rivers Press, New York, 2004, pp42-63 [[User:Engleham|Engleham]] ([[User talk:Engleham|talk]]) 15:08, 12 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Disambiguation#rfc_64B8AEC|Wikipedia talk:Disambiguation]] expired 2016-10-15 17:01 ===
* Id: 64B8AEC
* User: Doncram
* Date: 2016-09-15 16:22:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|741184984|POLICY 741184984}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|744500467|POLICY 744500467}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Proposal: Change Disambiguation and Deletion policy pages to eliminate deletion of two-item disambiguation pages.

IMO, deletion of disambiguation pages based on [[wp:TWODABS]] ''NEVER'' makes sense.  If neither of two exact match items is primary, all should agree the dab is needed.  If one of two is primary, the dab page is not absolutely required, but if it is created, it should be kept.  Why?
*1. Readers seeking the primary use meaning get to it immediately, are unaffected by the dab.
*2. Avoid wasting editors' time in monitoring [[:Category:Disambiguation pages containing one non-primary topic]] to find dabs which can be eliminated, and time wasted by other editors in AFDs and other deletion processes.  
*3. <s>Disambiguation pages are glorified redirects, and [[wp:Redirects are cheap]]</s> Like the essay [[wp:redirects are cheap]] says about redirects, disambiguation pages also "take up minimal disk space and use very little bandwidth. Thus, it doesn't really hurt things if there are a few of them scattered around." (Restated per comments.)
*4. Another exact match may turn up soon, or eventually, and can be added.  
*5. A disambiguation page can hold other items useful to readers that are not exact matches, in the list of items being disambiguation or in "See also".  Readers don't necessarily know their target is not an exact match;  partial matches are helpful.
*6. Technically, we violate Wikipedia's promise to contributors that they will receive credit, each time a two-dabs page is deleted and then recreated later with two or more items.
*7. Deletions of two-dab pages are, like all other deletion actions, a negative that contributors often experience as an insult or dismissal or otherwise as a turnoff.  People need 7 or 8 positives to counter a negative experience.  Negativity drives down participation.

Why not?
*1. Readers seeking the non-primary use meaning will arrive at the primary use topic and, instead of seeing hatnote taking them directly to the non-primary use, they might be directed to the disambiguation page instead, requiring one more step.  '''But''':
**a) If the non-primary use name is long and would make the hatnote unwieldy, readers might already be directed to the disambiguation page, under current policy.
**b) '''We can simply choose not to require the hatnote to go to the disambiguation page.  Change wp:TWODABS to allow it explicity: "If there is only one non-primary use on the dab page, the hatnote can go directly to that."'''

The current process described in [[wp:Disambiguation]]'s [[wp:TWODABS]] section involves tagging TWODABS disambiguation pages with {{tl|Only-two-dabs}}, and allowing deletion if, after some non-defined length of time, other items are not added.  Let's stop the bureaucracy, reduce slightly the pipeline of articles into AFD, stop the slow churning that goes on here, and get rid of one small component of Wikipedia's negativity. --[[User:doncram|<font color="maroon">do</font>]][[User talk:Doncram|<font color="green">ncr</font>]][[Special:Contributions/doncram|<font color="maroon">am</font>]] 16:22, 15 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:I Am... Sasha Fierce#rfc_76754BD|Talk:I Am... Sasha Fierce]] expired 2016-10-17 03:01 ===
* Id: 76754BD
* User: Dan56
* Date: 2016-09-17 02:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|739801913|MEDIA 739801913}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|744732471|MEDIA 744732471}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=

=== [[Talk:The 100 (TV series)#rfc_9416EC0|Talk:The 100 (TV series)]] expired 2016-10-20 18:01 ===
* Id: 9416EC0
* User: Flyer22 Reborn
* Date: 2016-09-20 17:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|740377667|MEDIA 740377667}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|740377669|SOC 740377669}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|745364729|SOC 745364729}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As seen with [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_100_(TV_series)&curid=39350301&diff=740316434&oldid=740255604 this edit], what is essentially at dispute is the following sentence: "A national debate among writers and fans about the trope ensued, with Lexa emerging as an icon for perpetration of the trope." One editor feels that the current summary is enough and that the [[Lexa (The 100)]] article should cover the rest. The other editor feels that the fact that the character's death inspired a national debate, rather than simply a small, localized uproar, and that the character became the face of the "[[bury your gays]]" trope, should be relayed. The edit also shows that two references were removed, but the two references aren't really a deal-beaker in the dispute. More on the dispute is seen above this section on the talk page. [[User:Flyer22 Reborn|Flyer22 Reborn]] ([[User talk:Flyer22 Reborn|talk]]) 17:43, 20 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:European Open (snooker)#rfc_505977A|Talk:European Open (snooker)]] expired 2016-10-22 13:01 ===
* Id: 505977A
* User: Betty Logan
* Date: 2016-09-22 12:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|740665236|SOC 740665236}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|745652376|SOC 745652376}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{see also|Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/European Masters (snooker)}}

It is proposed by {{u|Creepy pasta}} to create a ''[[European Masters (snooker)]]'' article to house the 2016 entry, on the basis that he believes it belongs to a different family of tournaments to the ''European Open/Malta Cup''. This is a retrospective application because the article has already been created via a bold edit. The two options are:
# Split this article, resulting in retaining [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=European_Masters_(snooker)&oldid=740394548 ''European Masters (snooker)''] and [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=European_Open_(snooker)&diff=740520750&oldid=739400273 removing the 2016 content from ''European Open (snooker)''] 
# Retain [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=European_Open_(snooker)&oldid=738198247 ''European Open (snooker)'' in its pre-split form] and redirecting ''European Masters (snooker)'' to ''European Open (snooker)''.
[[User:Betty Logan|Betty Logan]] ([[User talk:Betty Logan|talk]]) 12:59, 22 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Category talk:People of Jewish descent#rfc_31FDCEA|Category talk:People of Jewish descent]] expired 2016-10-25 14:01 ===
* Id: 31FDCEA
* User: Debresser
* Date: 2016-09-25 13:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|741138639|RELI 741138639}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|741138643|SOC 741138643}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|746140625|RELI 746140625}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|746140627|SOC 746140627}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In 2014 there was a very long discussion on this same talkpage, should [[:Category:People of Middle Eastern descent]] be added to this category. Obviously nobody disagrees that the Middle East is the cradle of Judaism and the Jewish people, but that is not the same. The conclusion of that discussion, in which both sides had several proponents, was that there is no consensus for the "Middle East" category. The category, that was added originally in 2012, was not removed at after that discussion, for reasons that do not matter much at this moment. The arguments against its inclusion remain the same, and are basically two-fold:
# Jews do not consider themselves to be of Middle Eastern descent.
# There have been many proselytes over the ages, making it doubtful (to a very high degree) that any person of Jewish descent is in fact of Middle Eastern descent.

The first point can benefit from some explanation. Jews who emigrated from Germany to, let's say, Israel or the United States, will call themselves German Jews. And the same for Jews from Syria, e.g., who call themselves [[Chalabi Jews]] wherever they are. But that is as far as it goes! Nobody ''knows'' in which countries their forefathers from more than a few generations ago lived, ''and nobody cares''! Certainly, if you'd ask any Jew straightforward, if they are of Middle Eastern decent, nobody would say they are because of the mere fact of being a Jew alone.

To further illustrate this point I retold a known Jewish joke in the previous discussion, about two Jews, let's say both 100% [[Ashkenazic]] Jews, where one tells the other: "Do you know you are an Iraqi Jew?" and then when the other guy vehemently denies he says "All Jews are descended from [[Abraham]] who came from [[Ur]] which is in [[Iraq]]". A similar proof [[ad absurdum]] regards mankind as a whole: most scientific and genetic research agrees that man comes from Africa, and nevertheless, not all "of .. descent" categories are part of "People of African descent", and it would be ridiculous to impose that scientific fact on descent categories, and the same is true in this case. The more so that in this case, where it is not a sure fact at all, in view of the second point regarding proselytes.

I propose to reach a conclusion that there is no place for "Middle East" categories, and per the same token "West Asian" or "Asian" categories, on any of the "Jewish descent" categories. There is at present no conformity on this issue in all of the "Jewish descent" categories, and of the many "Jewish descent" categories, some have one or more of the above. This Rfc strives to reach a conclusion that would be binding for all of them, and in my opinion that conclusion should be that those categories are out of place on all "Jewish descent" categories. [[User:Debresser|Debresser]] ([[User talk:Debresser|talk]]) 13:20, 25 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Natalie Portman#rfc_C2C924A|Talk:Natalie Portman]] expired 2016-10-26 10:01 ===
* Id: C2C924A
* User: Jack Sebastian
* Date: 2016-10-26 04:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|746226791|UNSORTED 746226791}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|746233174|BIO 746233174}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|746233176|SOC 746233176}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|746243658|BIO 746243658}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|746243661|SOC 746243661}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|746269405|UNSORTED 746269405}}
* RFC Text:

can the editors use the qualifier "major role" to define the role, or is it [[WP:OR|original research]] to add the phrase without supporting citation? - [[User:Jack Sebastian|Jack Sebastian]] ([[User talk:Jack Sebastian|talk]])

'''Alternative phrasings'''

*'''Leave as is''', the editors should be allowed to evaluate the quality of the role without exact sourcing as to phrasing.
*'''Alternative #1''', "During the mid-1990s, Portman had roles in the films A, B and C and Beautiful Girls, '''garnering significant acclaim with the latte'''r.".
*'''Alternative #2''', "During the mid-1990s, Portman had roles in the films A, B and C. '''Her breakout role came in the 1996 film Beautiful Girls, where she garnered significant acclaim'''."
*'''Alternative #3''',''"'"During the mid-1990s, Portman had roles in the films A, B and C. '''Her performance in the small ensemble film Beautiful Girls garnered significant acclaim."''

'''Note'''

The question of phrasing had been the subject of two earlier RfCs, linked [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Natalie_Portman#RfC:_Is_the_language_biased.3F here] and [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Natalie_Portman#Does_a_.22major.22_role_need_to_be_cited_as_such_by_reliable_sources.3F here]. The first RfC's closing Admin took note of  the poor phrasing of the RfC and that use of the term "major role" was not biased. It was suggested that another, better crafted RfC be submitted to address the matter.<br>
The closing admin on the second RfC noted that, as one word had generated so much debate, it would have been wise to ''"rephrase the sentence altogether, and present the available information in another way."''<sup><small>[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Natalie_Portman&diff=732520000&oldid=731637535 1]</small></sup>

'''Note'''

There have been three previous discussions on this issue in the last six months, all started by the same editor. Two were RfCs linked above, and an earlier discussions at [[Talk:Natalie Portman/Archive 3#Major roles]]. Also see the discussion immediately above this current RfC at [[Talk:Natalie Portman#Revisiting "a major role" wording]]. The first RfC was closed with the statement "there is a very strong consensus that 'a major role' is not biased." The second RfC was closed with the comment "The rough consensus is that 'major role' is an evaluative qualifier that requires verification, but there is '''no consensus to require exact wording in sources''' as it is often described in different terms in cited sources across BLPs of actors." In all four discussions an important point argued for keeping the current consensus of "major role" is that other means of determining major role, such as Portman's top billing in the film, can be used.
:Er, you do see the notes section immediately above this that says the same thing, right? Your're supposed to present a neutral Notes section, without rendering your opinion. This is not very neutral. Allow people to weigh in, and stop being afraid. - [[User:Jack Sebastian|Jack Sebastian]] ([[User talk:Jack Sebastian|talk]]) 04:45, 26 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox observatory#rfc_C8426F2|Template talk:Infobox observatory]] expired 2016-10-26 13:01 ===
* Id: C8426F2
* User: Jc3s5h
* Date: 2016-09-26 12:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|741277974|SCI 741277974}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|746285320|SCI 746285320}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Does this "Infobox observatories" follow the letter, or spirit, of "[[Wikipedia:Requests for comment/Wikidata Phase 2]]", which discussed whether importing data from Wikidata (which is not a reliable source because it is based on data added by unvetted users, just as Wikipedia is not a reliable source because it is edited by unvetted users) adhered to the [[WP:V|verifiability policy]]. The conclusion was "It is appropriate to '''modify existing infoboxes to permit Wikidata inclusion when there is no existing English Wikipedia data for a specific field in the infobox'''". This infobox displays all the telescopes that can be found either entered by Wikipedia editors, or contained in the Wikidata item for the observatory. [[User:Jc3s5h|Jc3s5h]] ([[User talk:Jc3s5h|talk]]) 12:33, 26 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Category talk:Seyfert galaxies#rfc_C419CE6|Category talk:Seyfert galaxies]] expired 2016-10-27 04:01 ===

* User: Skylord a52
* Date: 2016-10-19 20:18:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|746393051|SCI 746393051}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A lot of the 3C Seyfert galaxies in this category are one-sentence stubs, and many of them are also orphans. Since they don't seem to be very notable, should we instead make a stand-alone [[List of Seyfert galaxies]] and just merge the contents of each stub to it? Should we delete them altogether? Or should we instead focus on expanding those pages, so that they become notable enough to include links from the main [[Seyfert galaxies#Examples]] page?

=== [[Talk:James Watson#rfc_A49BE93|Talk:James Watson]] expired 2016-10-27 22:01 ===
* Id: A49BE93
* User: Joe Roe
* Date: 2016-09-27 21:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|741499866|BIO 741499866}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|741499872|SCI 741499872}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|741499874|SOC 741499874}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|746516363|BIO 746516363}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|746516364|SCI 746516364}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|746516369|SOC 746516369}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
How should the lead section describe the comments that lead to Watson's resignation from CSHL in 2007?

'''Background'''

The current stable version of the lead of [[James Watson]] describes certain controversial comments that led to Watson's resignation in 2007 thusly:

:He was then appointed chancellor, serving until 2007<ref name="CSHL bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.cshl.edu/gradschool/Non-Research-Faculty/james-d-watson |publisher=cshl.edu |year=2013 |accessdate=June 12, 2013 |title=Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory James D. Watson |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130524143755/http://www.cshl.edu/gradschool/Non-Research-Faculty/james-d-watson |archivedate=May 24, 2013 }}</ref> when he resigned his position after making  controversial comments claiming a link between intelligence and geographical ancestry.<ref>{{cite web|last=Crawford|first=Hayley|title=Short Sharp Science:James Watson menaced by hoodies shouting 'racist!'|url=http://www.newscientist.com/blogs/shortsharpscience/2011/04/james-watson-menaced-by-hoodie.html|publisher=New Scientist|accessdate=24 April 2014|quote=... he was "inherently gloomy about the prospect of Africa" because "all our social policies are based on the fact that their intelligence is the same as ours, whereas all the testing says not really".}}</ref><ref name="Independent">Watson, J.D. [http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/james-watson-to-question-genetic-intelligence-is-not-racism-5328720.html "James Watson: To question genetic intelligence is not racism"], ''Independent'', October 19, 2007. Retrieved October 24, 2007</ref><ref name="cshl.edu">Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. October 18, 2007. [http://www.cshl.edu/public/releases/07_statement2.html Statement by Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Board of Trustees and President Bruce Stillman, PhD Regarding Dr. Watson’s Comments in The Sunday Times on October 14, 2007]. Press release. Retrieved October 24, 2007. {{wayback|url=http://www.cshl.edu/public/releases/07_statement2.html |date=20100910182221 }}</ref><ref name="LATimes">Wigglesworth, K.[http://articles.latimes.com/2007/oct/26/science/sci-watson26 DNA pioneer quits after race comments], ''L.A. Times'', October 26, 2007. Retrieved December 5, 2007</ref><ref name="Resign">"[http://www.cnn.com/2007/TECH/science/10/25/watson.resigns/index.html "Nobel prize-winning biologist resigns."]", ''CNN'', October 25, 2007. Retrieved on October 25, 2007.</ref>

Over the past months several editors (most recently myself) have attempted to change this wording to one which they argue more accurately represents third party coverage of Watson's comments (diffs: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=James_Watson&diff=721267252&oldid=721260231][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=James_Watson&diff=721450244&oldid=721267252][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=James_Watson&diff=730525194&oldid=730448318][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=James_Watson&diff=730630795&oldid=730525722][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=James_Watson&diff=733157247&oldid=730795729][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=James_Watson&diff=733159191&oldid=733157247][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=James_Watson&diff=739607607&oldid=739097329][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=James_Watson&diff=739629197&oldid=739607607][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=James_Watson&diff=740177315&oldid=739717994][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=James_Watson&diff=740193455&oldid=740177315]). Suggestions have included:
* ...after making controversial comments claiming a link between [[race and intelligence]].
* ...after making controversial comments about the intelligence of Africans and people of African descent.
* Watson resigned this position and was widely shunned after making comments implying black people are less intelligent than others.

These changes have been reverted by others who argue that they are not supported by the sources; or that they imply Watson is racist, and that this violates [[WP:NPOV]], [[WP:BLP]] and/or [[WP:ARBR&I]]. Lengthy discussions on this talk page have failed to resolve the dispute, and we think a wider discussion amongst uninvolved editors is sorely needed. [[User:Joe Roe|Joe Roe]] ([[User talk:Joe Roe|talk]]) 21:10, 27 September 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2016 UCI World Tour#rfc_3BCBFBD|Talk:2016 UCI World Tour]] expired 2016-10-28 00:01 ===
* Id: 3BCBFBD

There are many different subcategories of race that could be identified: why should GTs uniquely be colour coded?  They don't even make a homogenous group in terms of WT point allocations.  This appears to be one editor having tried to highlight his preferred type of race, and others assuming that this is some sort of unchallengeable convention.  If there is not a good reason for it, let's scrap this ugly and unnecessary intrusion. [[User:Kevin McE|Kevin McE]] ([[User talk:Kevin McE|talk]]) 18:42, 2 October 2016 (UTC)}}

#Made at least 500 undeleted edits to mainspace, ''and'' have a registered account for at least 90 days, plus appropriate experience of a kind that clearly demonstrates knowledge of article quality control.
#Grandfathering: Editors who have made 200 uncontested or unreverted patrols, maintenance, or deletion tags between 1 January 2016 and 06 October 2016 and who have a clean block log since 01 January 2016 will have the right automatically accorded to their account via [[Special:UserRights]]

With the resignation of {{u|SchroCat}} and long-term unavailability of {{u|Crisco 1492}}, the Featured List project is down to just Director {{u|Giants2008}} and Delegate {{u|PresN}}. === [[Talk:Ruger Mini-14#rfc_D550CCF|Talk:Ruger Mini-14]] expired 2016-10-31 15:01 ===
* Id: D550CCF
* User: CuriousMind01
* Date: 2016-10-01 14:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|742081379|HIST 742081379}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|742081381|SCI 742081381}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|742081384|POL 742081384}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|747116780|HIST 747116780}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|747116782|SCI 747116782}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|747116787|POL 747116787}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=

=== [[Talk:The Golden Palace#rfc_81D073C|Talk:The Golden Palace]] expired 2016-10-31 17:01 ===

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Dispute resolution noticeboard#rfc_9C96903|Wikipedia talk:Dispute resolution noticeboard]] expired 2016-10-31 23:01 ===
* Id: 9C96903
* User: Steven Crossin
* Date: 2016-10-31 05:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|747060668|PROP 747060668}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|747187405|PROP 747187405}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Hi all. I first founded DRN back in [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Dispute_resolution_noticeboard&diff=432344305&oldid=432344111 June 2011], and I think it's had a good run over that time. But I wonder if it's still effective. Back then, success rate on DRN was quite high and we had a good amount of volunteers. Nowadays, it seems we only have a handful, with one user doing most of the work {hats off to [[User:Robert McClenon|Robert]] for holding down the fort). That said, success seems quite low. DRN closes disputes for three reasons, successful (resolved successfully), failed (clearly unresolved) and general close (neither successful or unsuccessful, often procedural close due to inactivity/unsuitable request/incorrect forum).

I've done some digging, and here's the stats for this year: 208 cases filed, 8% (16) failed, 6 (3%) were successfully resolved, and the other 186 (89%) were closed for other reasons.

I'm hoping to get input from members of the community here. DRN was once a useful process with many volunteers, but I worry that it might have become too process-oriented and strict, and wonder how much value it's adding. What can we do to improve the process, or if nothing else, what dispute resolution alternatives do we have? <span style="font-family:Verdana;">[[User:Steven Crossin|<span style="color:#078330;">Steven</span>]] [[User talk:Steven Crossin|<span style="color:#2875B0;">Crossin</span>]]</span> 05:38, 31 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Jill Stein#rfc_3AECDA0|Talk:Jill Stein]] expired 2016-11-01 12:01 ===
* Id: 3AECDA0
* User: Snooganssnoogans
* Date: 2016-10-31 12:23:00
* RFC Text:

Should the following text be included in the article?

* Through mutual funds or index funds, Stein invests in energy companies (such as Exxon, Chevron, Duke Energy, Conoco Phillips, and Toho Gas), the financial industry (including big banks like JP Morgan Chase, Citigroup, and Deutsche Bank), pharamaceutical companies (such as Pfizer, Novartis, Johnson and Johnson, and Allergan), tobacco companies (such as Phillip Morris and Marlboro) and defense contractors (such as Raytheon). Explaining why she held investments in industries that she has been critical of, Stein said, "Like many Americans who hold retirement accounts, pension funds, or who invest in the American economy," the statement begins, "my finances are largely held in index funds or mutual funds over which I have no control in management or decision-making. Sadly, most of these broad investments are as compromised as the American economy—degraded as it is by the fossil fuel, defense and finance industries." Asked why she did not invest in socially responsible index funds or clean energy funds, Stein said that she had "not yet found the mutual funds that represent my goals of advancing the cause of people, planet and peace".[http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/10/26/jill-stein-s-ideology-says-one-thing-her-investment-portfolio-says-another.html} [[User:Snooganssnoogans|Snooganssnoogans]] ([[User talk:Snooganssnoogans|talk]]) 12:23, 31 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:England (disambiguation)#rfc_A4DB6D0|Talk:England (disambiguation)]] expired 2016-11-02 21:01 ===
* Id: A4DB6D0
* User: Triune
* Date: 2016-10-03 20:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|742458391|HIST 742458391}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|747518754|HIST 747518754}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should England be referred to as an '''erroneous''' metonym for the United Kingdom? (bolded word is the proposal)

We have been unable to reach a consensus on this issue.  I have attempted to add information to the effect that using the word "England" to refer to "the United Kingdom" is incorrect, hence the use of the word erroneous.  This is based on the definition of England as a country which borders Scotland and Wales and which is a constituent, along with those two countries, Northern Ireland and numerous overseas territories, of the United Kingdom.  Referring to a part of a country as the whole is incorrect, much like referring to New York and the whole of the USA.  This may be a colloquialism used in some parts of the world, but minor usage does not imply correctness.

I believe that either this definition should be removed completely, or it should be highlighted here that the usage is incorrect, as including it here seems to be attempted approval of the misuse, which I understand is against the purpose of this website.[[User:Triune|Triune]] ([[User talk:Triune|talk]]) 20:43, 3 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:United States presidential election, 2016#rfc_231F6F8|Talk:United States presidential election, 2016]] expired 2016-11-02 21:01 ===
* Id: 231F6F8
* User: Antony-22
* Date: 2016-10-23 00:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|745853224|POL 745853224}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|748399500|POL 748399500}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Let's move to [[WP:NOTVOTE|collecting !votes]] so we can actually determine what the consensus is on inclusion of Rocky De La Fuente and Laurence Kotlikoff in the infobox.  Keep in mind the previous consensus that the fundamental infobox inclusion criterion is that it is legally possible for the candidate to win a majority of the votes in the Electoral College, and that write-in access counts in principle (see [[#A call for consensus on McMullin and Castle]] above).  This consensus is not being revisited here.  The question here is what kind of write-in ballot access counts.  The main considerations are:
* Should we continue to require actual documentation that electors have been selected, as was done in 2012? (See [[Talk:United States presidential election, 2016/Archive 12#Auditing the write-in access|#Auditing the write-in access]] above.)
* Should we count the 54 electoral votes from the six "free write-in" states (AL, NH, NJ, PA, RI, VT), which do not have a process for advance filing as a write-in candidate?
* Should there be additional requirements for candidates who need write-in access to get to 270 electoral votes, such as requiring that they have on-ballot access for a certain number of states or electoral votes?
Please !vote whether to '''include''' or '''exclude''' De La Fuente and Kotlikoff, and explain your reasoning.  [[User:Antony-22|Antony&ndash;'''''22''''']] (<sup>[[User talk:Antony-22|talk]]</sup>⁄<sub>[[Special:Contributions/Antony-22|contribs]]</sub>) 00:07, 23 October 2016 (UTC)}}


=== [[Template talk:Marriage#rfc_D370747|Template talk:Marriage]] expired 2016-11-02 23:01 ===
* Id: D370747
* User: Richard Arthur Norton (1958- )
* Date: 2016-11-01 17:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|747315759|BIO 747315759}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|752520771|BIO 752520771}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have noticed there is a mixture of using just the start of marriage in the template: (m. 1900) while others are more complete with the "end=" parameter filled in, as in: (m. 1900; his death 1941) or (m. 1900; her death 1941) or (m. 1900; divorce 1941) or (m. 1900; annulled 1941). Should we always be filling in the "end=" parameter? --[[User:Richard Arthur Norton (1958- )|Richard Arthur Norton (1958- )]] ([[User talk:Richard Arthur Norton (1958- )|talk]]) 17:54, 1 November 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Dynamic a-list#rfc_5BBBB67|Template talk:Dynamic a-list]] expired 2016-11-03 05:01 ===
* Id: 5BBBB67
* User: 80.221.159.67
* Date: 2016-10-04 04:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|742515540|TECH 742515540}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|747582262|TECH 747582262}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The wording on this template is a bit awkward and not adapted. The current text is:

<blockquote>This article contains one or more [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Lists#Incomplete lists|incomplete lists]] which may never be able to satisfy particular standards for completeness. You can help by [{{fullurl:{{FULLPAGENAME}}|action=edit}} expanding it{{\}}them] with entries that are [[Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources|reliably sourced]].</blockquote>

I propose a new parameter and usage for articles that have multiple lists:

* <code><nowiki>{{Dynamic a-list|plural}}</nowiki></code>
* <code><nowiki>{{Dynamic a-list|plural=yes}}</nowiki></code> (alternative syntax)

This template could use a parameter <code>plural</code> to display the following message for multiple lists in article:

<blockquote>This article contains multiple [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Lists#Incomplete lists|incomplete lists]] which may never be able to satisfy particular standards for completeness. You can help by [{{fullurl:{{FULLPAGENAME}}|action=edit}} expanding them] with entries that are [[Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources|reliably sourced]].</blockquote>

In addition, the parameter syntax <code>plural=no</code> could be used to create the following message:

<blockquote>This article contains an [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Lists#Incomplete lists|incomplete list]] which may never be able to satisfy particular standards for completeness. You can help by [{{fullurl:{{FULLPAGENAME}}|action=edit}} expanding it] with entries that are [[Wikipedia:Identifying reliable sources|reliably sourced]].</blockquote>

The text without the plural parameter can be left as-is, mainly also for compatibility reasons and ease of use/ambiguity. <code>true</code> and <code>false</code> statements can be considered to be supported as well.

[[Special:Contributions/80.221.159.67|80.221.159.67]] ([[User talk:80.221.159.67|talk]]) 04:11, 4 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Surrender (military)#rfc_03770A3|Talk:Surrender (military)]] expired 2016-11-03 18:01 ===
* Id: 03770A3
* User: Barthateslisa
* Date: 2016-10-04 17:19:00

The following pic is one of the most iconic picture of any surrender by a military in the world. Its an actual, explicit picture of a  Lt Gen from a defeated army signing  a real instrument of surrender following his force's defeat. Its neither a portrait, nor a picture implying a surrender, it shows a real surrender. The picture should be added on the page. I invite people's input regarding objection or support to the said edit, for discussion. Thanks.

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Reference desk#rfc_5E8AE14|Wikipedia talk:Reference desk]] expired 2016-11-07 03:01 ===
* Id: 5E8AE14
* User: HOTmag
* Date: 2016-11-06 22:41:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|748197656|UNSORTED 748197656}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|748228384|UNSORTED 748228384}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Additionally, can Wikipedia suggest me a reasonable way to ask our editors  - a question continuously deleted from the Ref desk by two editors - who ''mistakenly'' think my question is not genuine?

Today, I asked a question at the reference desk <small>(for details about the question, see the last section below, in small letters)</small>.
Unfortunately, two editors who - ''instead of assuming a good faith'' - thought my question was not genuine, deleted it from the Ref desk, while adding a comment - on the summary edit - that there was no way to answer my question. However, I think that - instead of their deleting a (legitimate) question from the ref desk - they should have written their (unnecessarily correct) comment ''on the ref desk'', and should have let other editors try to answer my (legitimate) question.

<small>Actually, what happened was the following: Today I noticed, that some people had used the connection between the word Trump and the word trumpet, e.g. [http://spectator.org/let-trump-be-trumpet/ in this paper], so I wanted to know whether anybody before me has also noticed the connection between Trump's name and Trump's rival's husband's expertise in playing trumpet. I innocently asked about that - at the reference desk, but unfortunately my question was deleted (instead of assuming a good faith).</small>

[[User:HOTmag|HOTmag]] ([[User talk:HOTmag|talk]]) 22:41, 6 November 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Requests for comment/Pending Changes expansion RfC#rfc_A075E0E|Wikipedia talk:Requests for comment/Pending Changes expansion RfC]] expired 2016-11-07 05:01 ===
* Id: A075E0E
* User: とある白い猫/16
* Date: 2016-11-06 21:48:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|748189624|POLICY 748189624}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|748242684|POLICY 748242684}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
==Concern'''

I find this RFC not inline with "the encyclopedia ANYONE can edit" core value we have on this site. --<small> [[User:とある白い猫/16|A Certain White Cat]]</small> <sup>[[User talk:とある白い猫/16|chi?]]</sup> 21:48, 6 November 2016 (UTC)}}
'''Proposals'''

'''A: PC1 protection for all articles'''

'''Implement Level 1 Pending Changes protection for all articles.''' The protection itself would be performed by a bot created for this purpose. 

This solution would keep the general public from seeing vandalism or statements that are unsourced/poorly-written, perhaps saving Wikipedia the periodic public embarrassment it has to deal with whenever hoaxes and vandalism are viewed by readers (consider the [http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/13/politics/hillary-clinton-wikipedia-hacked/ widespread media attention] that Wikipedia recently received after [[Hillary Clinton]]'s article was replaced with an obscene image).  

''It is important to recognize that PC1 protection would not keep anyone from actually editing any page. It would simply require that a reviewer approve article edits by an anonymous or non-autoconfirmed user.''

'''Support A'''

#'''Strong Support'''. Long overdue. Globally, Wikipedia is the seventh most popular website. Millions upon millions of people rely on it every day for basic information. But yet we continue with a policy of letting any random person add anything they want on almost any article (even our most highly-viewed or highly-prized ones) without even reviewing most of those edits or requiring sources for them. We have no way of knowing how many inaccurate statements may exist on Wikipedia already, due to our ''laissez-faire'' quality requirements, and spreading potentially inaccurate or biased information to millions of people is no laughing matter, especially in subjects such as medicine. Such misinformation can have dangerous real-life effects, and it is our moral responsibility to take action to prevent such things.<p>Wikipedia has been publicly embarrassed many times, such as when [http://www.cnn.com/2016/10/13/politics/hillary-clinton-wikipedia-hacked/ a highly-visible article is grossly vandalized], or when hoaxes or inaccurate information are discovered to have existed for a long time on some articles. Wikipedia itself has a [[Reliability_of_Wikipedia#Notable_incidents|list of such incidents]]. It is long past time that this endless cycle stop. Why do we keep letting this happen? There's an old saying which says that "insanity is doing is the same thing over and over again and expecting different results." No one person is to blame for this, but what is to blame is the general anti-change environment.<p>So these problems are very much fixable, if we simply become willing to try new things and wake up to the need for common-sense changes. And this proposal is one of the simplest, low-impact, most common-sense way to start. '''An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.''' [[User:Biblioworm|Biblio]] ([[User_talk:Biblioworm#top|talk]]) <small>[[Wikipedia:WikiProject Reforming Wikipedia|Reform project.]]</small> 21:13, 6 November 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Requests for comment/Pending Changes expansion RfC#rfc_2D1D5E6|Wikipedia:Requests for comment/Pending Changes expansion RfC]] expired 2016-11-07 06:01 ===
* Id: 2D1D5E6
* Date: 2016-11-06 21:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|748189624|POLICY 748189624}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|748189629|PROP 748189629}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|748248571|POLICY 748248571}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|748248572|PROP 748248572}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This '''Pending Changes expansion RfC''' consists of several proposals regarding [[WP:PC|pending changes protection]]. 

The first two proposals concern the expansion of [[WP:PC1|Level 1 PC protection]] to either all articles or only ones of the highest quality and/or importance. PC1 protection requires that a reviewer approve any revision by an anonymous or non-autoconfirmed user before it becomes visible to the general public. The aim of these proposals is to ensure that the general public does not see vandalism, inaccurate/unsourced statements, or poorly-written content. In this way, Wikipedia's quality could hopefully be stabilized somewhat, allowing editors to eliminate backlogs without worrying about the backlog increasing yet again.

The third proposal would help PC reviewers deal with the increased backlog by means of more efficient reviewing systems.

As with all other RfCs, this RfC will run for thirty days.

21:14, 6 November 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Mumtaz (actress)#rfc_5CF2B3F|Talk:Mumtaz (actress)]] expired 2016-11-08 01:01 ===
* Id: 5CF2B3F
* User: Juhi47
* Date: 2016-11-07 09:52:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|748272934|UNSORTED 748272934}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|748399507|UNSORTED 748399507}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
As per the links https://web.archive.org/web/20130224033306/http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/suraiya-most-enduring-ethnic-beauty-mumtaz-close-behind-334273 and http://stars.topnews.in/271073-suraiyas-ethnic-look-voted-best Mumtaz was voted the second-most-popular beauty in the poll conducted as part of the celebrations of 100 years of Indian cinema, in association with the International Indian Film Academy (IIFA), in 2012. However, this information has been deleted from her page.

The site http://www.wiseshe.com/2013/05/10-most-beautiful-indian-women.html ranks Mumtaz as one of the 10 most beautiful Indian women. 
When Mumtaz was active in Hindi Cinema, Internet was unheard of. So, whatever critical information about her professional life is available, is actually in print media. Transcripts of some of the articles are available at www.angelfire.com/celeb/mumtaz/articles.html. Other sources are the sites which have been created with memories of various persons following her life; her interviews; or information from her family members, etc. However the information exchanged in communications would hardly be available in print. It's not only impossible but also unethical to record the conversations. Hence, there would a large amount of information which cannot be cross-referenced tangibly. Anyway, let's have look at a single article where every word, every phrase, every sentence, and every para is cross-referenced!

The statement that "Jeetendra and Mumtaz acted in a number of films together, including unsuccessful films such as ''Boond Jo Ban Gai Moti'' (1967), ''Himmat'', ''Kathputli'', and ''Roop Tera Mastana'', as well as successful one such as ''Jigri Dost'' (1969), ''Humjoli'' (where Mumtaz had a cameo role) and ''Ek Naari Ek Brahmchari'' (1971). Mumtaz also acted opposite Feroz Khan in ''Aag'' (1967), ''Aadmi Aur Insaan'', ''Upaasna'', ''Mela'', ''Apradh'', and ''Nagin''; and with Sanjay Khan in ''Upasana'', ''Dhadkan'', ''Mela''" does not seen contentious at all.

What's wrong in including the site "www.mumtaz.in" or "www.angelfire.com/celeb/mumtaz" which quotes a number of print media which are the national film magazines of India? [[User:Juhi47|Juhi47]] ([[User talk:Juhi47|talk]]) 09:52, 7 November 2016 (UTC)}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the comparison table in the [[Motion picture rating system#Comparison_table]] section in this article and at other articles such as [[Mobile software content rating system]], [[Television content rating systems]] and [[Video game rating system]] use a color scheme that is deemed [[WP:ACCESSIBLE]] to color-blind users? There are currently two schemes in contention:

=== [[Talk:Pierre Bourdieu#rfc_F5B91AE|Talk:Pierre Bourdieu]] expired 2016-11-09 11:01 ===
* Id: F5B91AE
* User: Vladimir Koznyshev#top
* Date: 2016-10-28 11:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|746986850|BIO 746986850}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|748641153|BIO 748641153}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[File:Pierre Bourdieu.jpg|thumb]]
[[File:Bourdieu Strasbourg crop.jpg|thumb]]
The discussion at hand concerns whether this image of Bourdieu should be in the infobox: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c1/Pierre_Bourdieu.jpg

Or this one: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/6b/Bourdieu_Strasbourg_crop.jpg

Why do I believe the former image is better than the latter? As I noted in my latest revision summary: it is aesthetically and functionally better, for it is not a grainy, cropped image taken from a random meeting with other people. It is professional and shows him speaking. It is moreover also the image used on all the other major language versions of the article (French, Spanish, Italian, etc.). Finally it shows him as he was best known to the public appearance-wise; the other image is of him when he was already quite old and shows him in a way that does not fit the public impression of him as established throughout his career (just do a google image search for him).

There are also downsides for that picture, however. It is somewhat blurry, and I hope someone with the requisite Photoshop skills can produce a better version of it as that is one of the main arguments I've seen from those who prefer the other image.

If better arguments are presented for why the other image is better, I am all ears and am open to changing my mind, as I hope others are as well, in particular when a better version of the first image is presented. [[User:Vladimir Koznyshev|Vladimir Koznyshev]] ([[User talk:Vladimir Koznyshev#top|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Vladimir Koznyshev|contribs]]) 11:36, 28 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Notability (sports)#rfc_124BFD7|Wikipedia talk:Notability (sports)]] expired 2016-11-10 08:01 ===
* Id: 124BFD7
* User: Osplace
* Date: 2016-10-19 15:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|745166222|BIO 745166222}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|745166227|SOC 745166227}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|750252669|BIO 750252669}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|750252673|SOC 750252673}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is an increase of the need of a '''Notability criteria for volleyball players''' since there are a lot of recent creation of BLP and clubs with dubious relevance. I would like to introduce this proposal:
;Volleyball players and head coachs are deemed notable if they meet any of the criteria below:
# Has competed in the [[Olympics]], [[FIVB World Cup|World Cup]], [[FIVB Club World Championship|Club World Championship]] or senior [[FIVB Volleyball World Championship|World Championships]].
# Has won a medal at one of the following competitions: [[FIVB Volleyball World Grand Champions Cup|World Grand Champions Cup]], [[FIVB Volleyball World League|World League]], [[FIVB World Grand Prix|World Grand Prix]], [[Goodwill Games]], [[Pan American Games]], [[Commonwealth Games]], [[Asian Games]], and any Senior Continental Championship.
# Has won a gold medal at the senior level at any other major elite international event (e.g. the [[All-Africa Games]], [[South American Games]]).
# Has been inducted into <s>a major hall of fame, such as</s> the [[Volleyball Hall of Fame]].
Note: College and youth players <s>are not notable unless they satisfy one of the statements above, or if they can be shown to meet the wider</s> will follow [[WP:NCOLLATH]] or the requirements of [[WP:GNG]].

I know that professional leagues and league players are being left for this proposal and an item about it should be added. Something like:
#Players who have played, and managers who have managed in a fully professional league, will generally be regarded as notable. See a [[WP:FPL|list of fully professional leagues kept by WikiProject Football]].
Another item that should be covered is beach volleyball. It should be something like:
;Beach volleyball players are deemed notable if they meet any of the criteria below:
# Has competed in the [[Beach volleyball at the Summer Olympics|Olympic Games]], [[FIVB Beach Volleyball World Championships|World Championship]] and the [[FIVB Beach Volleyball World Tour|World Tour]].
# Has won a medal at one of the following competitions: [[Pan American Games]], [[Commonwealth Games]], [[Asian Games]], and any Senior Continental Championship
# Has been inducted into <s>a major hall of fame, such as</s> the [[Volleyball Hall of Fame]].
Please let finish the discussion with a solid criteria. I hope this is not left unattended. --[[User talk:Osplace|Osplace]] 15:42, 19 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Category talk:Culture by city#rfc_323A604|Category talk:Culture by city]] expired 2016-11-10 16:01 ===
* Id: 323A604
* User: Bearcat
* Date: 2016-10-11 15:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|743844702|STYLE 743844702}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|748820364|STYLE 748820364}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the naming convention for this tree be "Culture '''of''' City" or "Culture '''in''' City"? My understanding was always that consensus had been established as "of", but after reviewing this category and the various country-specific subcategories in {{cl|Culture by nationality and city}}, I'm finding a much closer split than I expected — there are 305 ''ofs'', 238 ''ins'', and a handful of outliers that will have to be renamed either way because they're using non-standard formats like "City culture". (There was also one case, and I'm surprised not more, where "Culture of city" and "Culture in city" ''both'' existed for the same city — given the circumstances, I've temporarily merged them both into the form that was otherwise the "norm" in its ''own'' country, although obviously it can be renamed the other way if consensus settles on the other form.) [[User:Bearcat|Bearcat]] ([[User talk:Bearcat|talk]]) 15:40, 11 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Donald Trump#rfc_93DEA9E|Talk:Donald Trump]] expired 2016-11-10 18:01 ===
* Id: 93DEA9E
* User: EvergreenFir
* Date: 2016-10-17 23:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|744882113|BIO 744882113}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|744882116|POL 744882116}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|744882119|SOC 744882119}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|748966944|BIO 748966944}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|748966948|POL 748966948}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|749721830|SOC 749721830}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
;Summary of issue
There has been debates, reverts, and contentious editing regarding the lead of this BLP (see the above talk page sections: [[#Accusations of sexual misconduct in lead section]], [[#Removal of sexual misconduct allegations]], [[#RFC:Recent allegations in lede]], [[#Potential paragraph at end of lede on sex abuse allegations]], [[#Concern about the lede]], [[#Sentence on sexual misconduct in lede paragraph on campaign]], and [[#Access Hollywood tape in lead section]]). 

There are multiple objections and issues raised, but they all center around the inclusion or exclusion of allegations of sexual misconduct, harassment, assault, and crimes by Trump against a number of women. The relevant information in the body of the article can primarily be found at [[Donald Trump#Presidential campaign, 2016|§ Presidential campaign, 2016]], which summaries the fuller article [[Donald Trump sexual misconduct allegations]]. 

So far, the issues raise have been about (1) the existence of any mention in the [[WP:LEAD|lede]] and (2) the length of any such mention. Regarding (2), among those who think it should be included, some have suggested only one or two sentences be added while other suggest a stand-alone paragraph is warranted. Specific policies and guidelines raised in previous discussions include [[WP:DUE|due weight]], [[WP:RECENTISM|recentism]], [[WP:LEAD|lede guidelines]], potential [[WP:BLP|biography of living persons]] violations, and adherence to a [[WP:NPOV|neutral point of view]].

Examples of past lede edits: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Donald_Trump&diff=744499671&oldid=744494313 paragraphs], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Donald_Trump&diff=744864859&oldid=744863901 paragraph], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Donald_Trump&diff=744763397&oldid=744758492 sentence].

;Need for this RfC
Current discussions are disjointed, redundant, and contentious. Some attempts at consensus-building and !voting have been relative unfruitful. It is unclear if there is [[WP:CONSENSUS|consensus]] for anything. Unlike straw polls and other !votes, an RfC can help bring in new editors to voice their opinions and (hopefully) generate a stronger consensus. Per a request in the above section, I am making a good-faith attempt at creating a neutrally-worded RfC to assess consensus on the aforementioned issues. If you feel I have not adequately or correctly summarized the debate, please feel free to suggest clarification or changes to the background infomation. Because of the complicated nature of the issues and past discussion, please forgive my multi-question RfC. It is the only way I can see any RfC addressing the core issues and making any headway.

;Questions
#Should the lede of this BLP include any summary of the allegations of sexual misconduct against Trump?
#If the material is included, to what extent should it be covered in the lead?

Thank you for your time and input. [[User:EvergreenFir|'''<span style="color:#8b00ff;">Eve</span><span style="color:#6528c2;">rgr</span><span style="color:#3f5184;">een</span><span style="color:#197947;">Fir</span>''']] [[User talk:EvergreenFir|(talk)]] 23:39, 17 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of awards and nominations received by Game of Thrones#rfc_6E2E08E|Talk:List of awards and nominations received by Game of Thrones]] expired 2016-11-11 18:01 ===
* Id: 6E2E08E
* User: Darkwarriorblake
* Date: 2016-10-12 17:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|744039741|MEDIA 744039741}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|744039747|STYLE 744039747}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|748995979|MEDIA 748995979}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|748995983|STYLE 748995983}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This discussion is about the formatting of the awards table on the page. 

*'''Option A''' is to maintain the current single table. The reasoning given is that the table is sortable, allowing a user to sort through all of the awards, by year, type, recipient and outcome, allowing easier searching of particular items, for instance all awards won by Peter Dinklage.
*'''Option B''' is to use multiple tables as found in many other list articles, separating the awards by type, i.e. a table for Emmy's, a table for Golden Globes, etc, with the table focusing on that particular brand of awards. 

A RFC is requested for input. [[User: Darkwarriorblake|Darkwarriorblake]] / [[User talk:Darkwarriorblake|SEXY ACTION TALK PAGE!]] 17:14, 12 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Deferred changes/Request for comment 2016#rfc_E502B92|Wikipedia:Deferred changes/Request for comment 2016]] expired 2016-11-12 01:01 ===
* Id: E502B92
* Date: 2016-10-14 08:12:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|744287971|PROP 744287971}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|749043954|PROP 749043954}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This request for comment concerns '''[[WP:Deferred changes|deferred changes]]''', a way to defer for [[WP:reviewing|review]] edits by users who aren't autoconfirmed when they match certain [[WP:edit filter|edit filters]], are picked up by a bot (e.g. [[User:ClueBot NG]]) as warranting attention, or are considered damaging by [[WP:ORES|ORES]]. Until reviewed, the revision displayed to readers can be chosen to be either the latest revision as usual ('passive' defer) or the revision prior to the user edits<ref>The same revision that rollback would revert to.</ref> ('active' defer). Deferred edits appear at [[Special:PendingChanges]]. Should we request implementation of deferred changes? Specifically, should we allow it for the edit filter, bots and ORES, both passively and actively? 08:12, 14 October 2016 (UTC)}}

* Id: FFC3365
* User: Fyunck(click)
* Date: 2016-10-18 06:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|744917813|SOC 744917813}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|749992657|SOC 749992657}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In light of the President of France's recent speech on 15 October (examples at the [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3839625/86-white-roses-86-dead-France-pays-tribute-Bastille-Day-lorry-attack-victims-woman-lost-SIX-relatives-breaks-emotional-speech.html Daily Mail] and [http://www.gulf-times.com/story/517551/Hollande-invokes-unity-at-Nice-attack-ceremony Gulf Times]) it seemed to me, {{replyto|TTCTransportationFan4644}}, and a few others that it was time to add the 2016 Nice attack to our list. Since two have disagreed, and there have been a couple reverts, I thought it best to discuss here to iron things out. [[User:Fyunck(click)|Fyunck(click)]] ([[User talk:Fyunck(click)|talk]]) 06:02, 18 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Barack Obama religion conspiracy theories#rfc_18CE01B|Talk:Barack Obama religion conspiracy theories]] expired 2016-11-18 08:01 ===
* Id: 18CE01B
* Date: 2016-11-16 03:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|749789516|BIO 749789516}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|749789522|POL 749789522}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|749789526|RELI 749789526}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|750198518|BIO 750198518}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|750198520|POL 750198520}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|750198523|RELI 750198523}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The dispute can be found at [[Talk:Barack Obama religion conspiracy theories#Judgement of theological claims]]. The language of the lede section describes the subsequent information of the article body as "false." However, the article contains two distinct types of information: claims that are verifiable (i.e. those pertaining to Obama's religious beliefs) and those that are theological and unverifiable (i.e. what Obama represents to various religions or persons, e.g. "the antichrist). The dispute is whether both of those can be called false while complying with [[WP:NPOV]] or just the former. [[User:Ergo Sum|'''<span style="color:#0645AD">Ergo Sum</span>''']]  03:36, 16 November 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Eastern Orthodox Church#rfc_9EA7E41|Talk:Eastern Orthodox Church]] expired 2016-11-18 20:01 ===
* Id: 9EA7E41
* User: Jeppiz
* Date: 2016-10-19 19:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|745193177|RELI 745193177}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|745193179|STYLE 745193179}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|750276960|RELI 750276960}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|750276963|STYLE 750276963}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Two major Christian churches, the ''[[Catholic Church]]'' and the ''[[Orthodox Church]]'' both consider themselves both "catholic" and "orthodox". Sometimes a geographical qualification is given for both, as in the ''Roman Catholic Church'' and the ''Eastern Orthodox Church''. Should Wikipedia refer to these two major churches as<br>
1. The '''Catholic Church''' and the '''Orthodox Church''' (no geographical qualification).<br>
2. The '''Roman Catholic Church''' and the '''Eastern Orthodox Church''' (geographical qualification for both).<br>
3. The '''Catholic Church''' and the '''Eastern Orthodox Church''' (geographical qualification only for the latter)<br>
4. The '''Roman Catholic Church''' and the '''Orthodox Church''' (geographical qualification only for the former). [[User:Jeppiz|Jeppiz]] ([[User talk:Jeppiz|talk]]) 19:51, 19 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Disambiguation#rfc_F2215CB|Wikipedia talk:Disambiguation]] expired 2016-11-18 23:01 ===
* Id: F2215CB
* User: Gorthian#top
* Date: 2016-10-19 22:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|745235439|POLICY 745235439}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|750298752|POLICY 750298752}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Proposal: Change Disambiguation and Deletion policy pages to eliminate deletion of two-item disambiguation pages.'''

IMO, deletion of disambiguation pages based on [[wp:TWODABS]] ''NEVER'' makes sense.  If neither of two exact match items is primary, all should agree the dab is needed.  If one of two is primary, the dab page is not absolutely required, but if it is created, it should be kept.  Why?
*1. Readers seeking the primary use meaning get to it immediately, are unaffected by the dab.
*2. Avoid wasting editors' time in monitoring [[:Category:Disambiguation pages containing one non-primary topic]] to find dabs which can be eliminated, and time wasted by other editors in AFDs and other deletion processes.  
*3. <s>Disambiguation pages are glorified redirects, and [[wp:Redirects are cheap]]</s> Like the essay [[wp:redirects are cheap]] says about redirects, disambiguation pages also "take up minimal disk space and use very little bandwidth. Thus, it doesn't really hurt things if there are a few of them scattered around." (Restated per comments.)
*4. Another exact match may turn up soon, or eventually, and can be added.  
*5. A disambiguation page can hold other items useful to readers that are not exact matches, in the list of items being disambiguation or in "See also".  Readers don't necessarily know their target is not an exact match;  partial matches are helpful.
*6. Technically, we violate Wikipedia's promise to contributors that they will receive credit, each time a two-dabs page is deleted and then recreated later with two or more items.
*7. Deletions of two-dab pages are, like all other deletion actions, a negative that contributors often experience as an insult or dismissal or otherwise as a turnoff.  People need 7 or 8 positives to counter a negative experience.  Negativity drives down participation.

Why not?
*1. Readers seeking the non-primary use meaning will arrive at the primary use topic and, instead of seeing hatnote taking them directly to the non-primary use, they might be directed to the disambiguation page instead, requiring one more step.  '''But''':
**a) If the non-primary use name is long and would make the hatnote unwieldy, readers might already be directed to the disambiguation page, under current policy.
**b) '''We can simply choose not to require the hatnote to go to the disambiguation page.  Change wp:TWODABS to allow it explicity: "If there is only one non-primary use on the dab page, the hatnote can go directly to that."'''

The current process described in [[wp:Disambiguation]]'s [[wp:TWODABS]] section involves tagging TWODABS disambiguation pages with {{tl|Only-two-dabs}}, and allowing deletion if, after some non-defined length of time, other items are not added.  Let's stop the bureaucracy, reduce slightly the pipeline of articles into AFD, stop the slow churning that goes on here, and get rid of one small component of Wikipedia's negativity. 
<small>''RFC reopened by [[User:Gorthian|Gorthian]] ([[User talk:Gorthian#top|talk]]) 22:19, 19 October 2016 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Johannes Brahms#rfc_2FBCFE5|Talk:Johannes Brahms]] expired 2016-11-19 08:01 ===
* Id: 2FBCFE5
* User: Ravpapa
* Date: 2016-10-20 07:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|745284161|BIO 745284161}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|745284164|SOC 745284164}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|750368735|BIO 750368735}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|750368738|SOC 750368738}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the lead of the article on [[Johannes Brahms]] include the statement "He was a master of counterpoint, the complex and highly disciplined art for which Johann Sebastian Bach is famous"? 

This sentence was included by [[User:Marlindale|Marlindale]] in the paragraph describing Brahms's compositional style. [[User:Tony1|Tony]] deleted the sentence, contending that this is "a highly dubious claim in the text that counterpoint was central to Brahms's style" and that "To mount a case in a 'balanced' summary article that counterpoint was central to Brahms's style is, I believe, inappropriate."

I disputed this contention, noting that virtually all the musicologists who have written about Brahms's work have noted his extensive use of counterpoint as an essential element in his style. [[User:Ravpapa|Ravpapa]] ([[User talk:Ravpapa|talk]]) 07:37, 20 October 2016 (UTC)}}

Under a recently enacted law, the minimum wage should now be roughly $6.85 a day for garment work. But factory owners have simply refused to pay the higher wages. A recent survey by the International Labor Organization found not a single factory in Haiti currently complying with the new law. Sae-A declined to comment on particulars, stating only that its employees "are compensated in accordance with local laws and regulations."}}</ref><ref name="GenderAction">{{cite web|author1=Claire Lauterbach|author2=Elaine Zuckerman|title=Caracol Industrial Park Social and Gender Impacts of Year One of Haiti’s newest IFI - funded Industrial Park|url=http://www.genderaction.org/publications/caracol.pdf|website=GenderAction|publisher=Gender Action|accessdate=September 23, 2016|date=2013|page=35}}</ref>

'''new synthetic reference''' for consideration:  <ref name="nyt-McIntire">McIntire, Mike (October&nbsp;16, 2016). "[http://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/17/us/hillary-clinton-cheryl-mills.html Haiti and Africa Projects Shed Light on Clinton’s Public-Private Web]". ''New York Times. Retrieved 2016-10-17.</ref>
